ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 2-1-2-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL 

Sec. 2-16. - Composition; eligibility; term; vacancies; election. 
    The council shall consist of five (5) members, and all persons now eligible for the position of councilman under the laws governing cities of the third class shall be eligible to serve as councilmen under RSMo 78.430 to 78.630. The term of councilmen shall be three (3) years. Should a vacancy occur in the office of councilman by death, resignation or otherwise, the council shall select a successor who shall serve until the next regular election. All councilmen shall be elected at large. They shall qualify and their terms of office shall begin on the first Monday after their election. 
(Ord. No. 3511, § 5, 9-4-84) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 78.460. 
Sec. 2-17. - Organization. 
(a)  The council shall at the time of organizing elect one (1) of its members as mayor and another as chairman pro tem for a term of one (1) year. If the members of the council, within five (5) days after the time for their organizational meeting, are unable to agree upon a mayor or a chairman pro tem of such council, then a mayor or chairman pro tem or both, as the occasion may require, shall be selected from all the members of such council by lot and a record thereof shall be made upon the journal of the council. 
(b)  If the mayor is temporarily absent from the city or becomes temporarily disabled from any cause, his duties shall be performed during such absence or disability by the chairman pro tem. In the absence of both the mayor and chairman pro tem, the other members of the council shall select one (1) of their number to perform the duties of mayor. 
(Code 1970, § 2-15) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 78.560. 
Sec. 2-18. - Mayor's duties. 
(a)  The mayor shall preside at all meetings of the council and shall perform such other duties consistent with his office as may be imposed by the council. He shall have a voice and vote in the council's proceedings but shall have no veto. 
(b)  The mayor shall be recognized as the official head of the city by the courts for the purpose of serving civil process and by the governor for the purpose of military law and for all ceremonial purposes. The powers and duties of the mayor shall be such as are conferred upon him by RSMo 78.430 to 78.630, and no other sections thereof. 
(Code 1970, § 2-15) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 78.560. 
Sec. 2-19. - Meetings. 
    Regular meetings of the council shall be held at least once every month and special meetings may be called by the mayor at his own instance or upon written application of two (2) members of the council. 
(Code 1970, § 2-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 78.590; notice of meetings, when required, RSMo 610.020. 
Sec. 2-20. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The council shall have the care, management and control of the city and of the city's finances. The council shall have power to enact and ordain any and all ordinances not repugnant to the constitution and laws of this state as the council shall deem expedient for the good government of the city, the preservation of peace and good order, the benefit of trade and commerce and the health of the inhabitants of the city and to enact and ordain all other ordinances, rules and regulations as may be deemed necessary to carry such powers into effect and to alter, modify or repeal the same. The council shall have such power over and control of the administration of the city government as is provided in RSMo 78.430 to 78.630. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the council to pass all ordinances and other measures conducive to the welfare of the city and to the proper carrying out of RSMo 78.430 to 78.630. It shall appoint a suitable person, not a member of the council, to be the administrative head of the city government whose official title shall be city manager. The council shall also provide for all offices and positions in addition to those specified in this Code that may become necessary for the proper execution of the work of the city. It shall fix the salary and compensation of all officers and employees of the city not provided for in this Code. The council shall also provide office rooms at the city hall or at some other convenient and suitable place in the city for the transaction of the business of the city and for the convenience of its officers. 
(Code 1970, § 2-17) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 77.260, 78.570. 
Sec. 2-21. - Attendance of witnesses and production of papers; oaths. 
    The council shall have power to compel the attendance of witnesses and the production of papers relating to any subject under consideration in which the interest of the city is involved. The council shall have power to call upon the proper officer of the city or of the county to execute such process. The officer making such service shall be entitled to receive such fees as are allowed by law for similar service, to be paid by the city. The mayor or chairman pro tem shall have power to administer oaths to witnesses. 
(Code 1970, § 2-19) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 77.100. 
Sec. 2-22. - Quorum; voting; signature on ordinances or resolutions. 
    Three (3) members of the council shall constitute a quorum to do business, but no action shall be valid unless at least three (3) shall vote in favor of such action. Upon every vote the yeas and nays shall be called and recorded and every motion, resolution and ordinance shall be reduced to writing before the vote is taken thereon. Every resolution or ordinance passed by the council shall be signed by the mayor or, in his absence, by the chairman pro tem or by two (2) members of the council before the resolution or ordinance shall be enforced. 
(Code 1970, § 2-20) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 78.580. 
Sec. 2-23. - Qualifications. 
    No person shall be councilman unless he is at least twenty-one (21) years of age prior to taking office, a citizen of the United States, an inhabitant of the city for one (1) year next preceding his election and a resident of the ward from which he is elected for six (6) months next preceding his election. 
(Code 1970, § 2-21) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 77.060. 
Sec. 2-24. - Salary. 
    Beginning 2008, the salary of each member of the City Council of the City of Cameron shall be one thousand six hundred forty dollars ($1,640.00) annually and shall be paid on a quarterly basis. Each April, councilmembers may elect to accept a percentage increase equal to that realized by city employees for the current budget year, waive any increase, or waive any and all compensation. 
(Code 1970, § 2-22; Ord. No. 5180, § 1, 1-4-05; Ord. No. 5678, § 1, 7-18-11) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 78.590. 
Sec. 2-25. - Elections. 
(a)  Primary elections for the office of city council are hereby eliminated. 
(b)  All future city council elections shall be conducted pursuant to the provisions of RSMo 78.530. 
(Ord. No. 4481, §§ 1, 2, 12-17-96) 
Sec. 2-26. - Date. 
    A general election for the elective officers of the city shall be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in April of each year. 
(Ord. No. 4894, § 1, 12-4-01) 
Sec. 2-27. - Filing of candidates. 
    Any person desiring to seek elective city municipal office may do so by filing his/her name and the office for which he/she seeks election with the city clerk during normal working hours at the city clerk's office at 8:00 a.m. on the fifteenth Tuesday prior to the election, and the closing date shall be 5:00 pm. on the eleventh Tuesday prior to the election. For the purpose of determining the order in which declarations of candidacy are filed, the city clerk or his/her designee shall hold a lottery on the first day of filing at 8:00 a.m. if more than one (1) candidate is present at 8:00 a.m. to file their candidacy. The lottery held amongst the candidates present at 8:00 a.m. on filing day will determine the order upon which candidate's names shall appear on the ballot. This lottery shall be open to the public and shall be held in city hall. Declarations of candidacy received thereafter shall be placed on the ballot in the order they are received. The clerk or his/her designee shall continue to accept filings until filing has closed. A legal notice shall be published in at least one (1) newspaper of the general circulation prior to the opening of the filing. 
(Ord. No. 4894, § 2, 12-4-01; Ord. No. 6063, § 2, 3-4-19) 
Sec. 2-28. - Conformance with state law. 
    All city elections shall be conducted and held in conformance with the provisions of the revised statutes of the state in effect at the time of the holding of the election. 
(Ord. No. 4894, § 3, 12-4-01) 
Sec. 2-29. - Voters' qualifications. 
    All residents of the city who are qualified and properly registered voters shall be entitled to vote at city elections. 
(Ord. No. 4894, § 4, 12-4-01) 
Sec. 2-30. - Duties of police officers. 
    It shall be the duty of the city police officers to give any assistance or protection required by the election authority, any employee of the election authority or any election judge, and to comply with all lawful requests and directions of the election authority relating to such assistance. 
(Ord. No. 4894, § 5, 12-4-01) 
Sec. 2-31. - Certification of election results. 
    As soon as practicable after each city election, the election authority shall verify the count and certify the results of the election. Not later than the second Tuesday after the election, the election authority shall issue a statement announcing the results of each election and shall certify the returns to the city clerk. The city clerk shall issue to each person elected a certificate of election. 
(Ord. No. 4894, § 6, 12-4-01) 
Secs. 2-32-2-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - INITIATIVE AND REFERENDUM[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Initiative and referendum, RSMo 78.573, 78.575, 116.010 et seq. 

Sec. 2-41. - Authority of voters to file petition. 
    The legal voters of the city may file a petition with the council to adopt an ordinance or to protest an ordinance already adopted in accordance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 3523, § 1, 1-22-85) 
Sec. 2-42. - Contents of petition. 
    Petitions to adopt or protest an ordinance shall first state the ordinance to be adopted or ordinance being protested and shall be signed by at least twenty-five (25) percent of the registered voters of the city. Each petition page, if more than one (1) page, shall contain, in addition to the signature, the printed name and address of the legal voter signing the petition and shall be accompanied by an affidavit of one (1) or more legal voters of the city stating that he personally obtained the signatures of the registered voters on the petition or the page of the petition. 
(Ord. No. 3523, § 2, 1-22-85) 
Sec. 2-43. - Clerk to ascertain sufficiency of petition. 
    Within ten (10) days from the date of filing, the petition to adopt or protest an ordinance, the city clerk shall examine and, from the voters' register, ascertain whether or not the petition is signed by the requisite number of registered voters. If necessary, the council shall allow the clerk extra help for this purpose. After examination of the petition, the clerk shall attach to the petition his certificate showing the results of the examination. If the petition is insufficient it may be amended within ten (10) days from the date of the clerk's certification. The clerk shall, within ten (10) days after such amendment, make like examination of the amended petition and, if his certificate shall show the petition to be insufficient, the petition shall be returned to the person filing the petition without prejudice, however, to the filing of a new petition to the same effect. If the petition shall be deemed to be sufficient, the clerk shall submit the petition to the council within twenty (20) days of such certification. 
(Ord. No. 3523, § 3, 1-22-85) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 78.270, 78.573(2). 
Sec. 2-44. - Council action-Petition for ordinance. 
    When a petition to adopt an ordinance is signed by at least twenty-five (25) percent of the registered voters, the council shall pass the ordinance without alteration within twenty (20) days of the clerk's certification of the petition or shall submit it for a vote at the next municipal or state primary or general election. If a majority of the voters voting on the proposed ordinance vote in favor thereof, the proposed ordinance shall become a valid and binding ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3523, § 4, 1-22-85) 
Sec. 2-45. - Same-Petition protesting ordinance. 
    If a petition protesting an ordinance signed by at least twenty-five (25) percent of the registered voters of the city is presented to the council, the council shall reconsider such ordinance and, if it is not entirely repealed, submit the ordinance to the voters as provided by section 2-44 of this article. Such ordinance shall not remain in effect after the election unless a majority of the voters voting on the ordinance shall vote in favor of the ordinance remaining in effect. 
(Ord. No. 3523, § 5, 1-22-85) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, manner of submission, verification and certification of petition, RSMo 78.270, 78.573(4). 
Sec. 2-46. - Ballot. 
    The question on the ballot to adopt or protest an ordinance shall be submitted in substantially the following form: 
    Shall the following ordinance be (adopted) (repealed)? (Set out ordinance). 
(Ord. No. 3523, § 6, 1-22-85) 
Sec. 2-47. - Time limit for repeal or amendment of ordinance; council proposition to repeal or amend ordinance. 
    Any ordinance proposed by petition or which is adopted by a vote of the people cannot be repealed or amended by the council for a period of two (2) years after the adoption of the ordinance except by a unanimous vote of all members of the council. Any number of proposed ordinances may be voted upon at the same election. The council may submit a proposition for the repeal of any such ordinance or for amendment thereto, to be voted upon at any city election. Should the proposition receive a majority of the votes cast, the ordinance shall be repealed or amended accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 3523, § 7, 1-22-85) 
Sec. 2-48. - Ordinances not subject to initiative or referendum. 
    Any ordinance appropriating money, emergency ordinances, and ordinances for the levying of taxes shall not be subject to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3523, § 8, 1-22-85) 
Secs. 2-49-2-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DEPARTMENTS 

Sec. 2-61. - Designated; titles of department heads. 
    There shall be eight (8) departments of the city as follows: 
Department Name Title of 
Department Head Executive City manager Finance City manager Fire Fire chief Police Chief of police Public works Public works superintendent Community development Community development director Utilities Utilities superintendent Municipal court Municipal judge  
(Code 1970, §§ 2-27-2-30; Ord. No. 3511, § 7, 9-4-84) 
Sec. 2-62. - Executive department; duties of department head. 
(a)  The city manager shall be the directing head of the city and shall appoint all officers and employees of the city except the city clerk, the city treasurer and the city assessor who shall be appointed by the council as provided by law. 
(b)  The city manager shall perform the duties of the personnel officer and of the purchasing agent for the city. He shall specify the form of financial accounts and shall be the budget officer of the city. The director of the city band shall report to the city manager. The city manager may, by administrative regulation, provide for assistance from other city officers or employees in carrying out his duties as purchasing agent and as personnel officer. He may assign, by administrative regulation, new duties that may arise in the administration of the affairs of the city to one (1) of the departments established by this article, unless otherwise provided for by this article or by other ordinance provisions. 
(Ord. No. 3511, § 8, 9-4-84) 
State Law reference- City officers generally, RSMo 77.370; city manager form of government in third class cities, RSMo 78.430 et seq. 
Sec. 2-63. - Finance department; duties of department head; city assessor's duties. 
(a)  The city manager shall be chief finance officer of the city and shall keep the books of accounts of the city and of its utilities enterprises. He shall perform such other duties as specified by the statutes, this Code or other ordinances of the council. He shall be responsible for the collection of the revenues of the city and their proper accounting. He shall keep the city's books in the form and manner specified by good standard municipal accounting practice. 
(b)  The city assessor shall be included in and carry out his duties in cooperation with the finance department. 
(Ord. No. 3511, § 10, 9-4-84) 
Cross reference- Finance and taxation, Ch. 4. 
State Law reference- City assessor, RSMo 77.370. 
Sec. 2-64. - Fire department; fire chief. 
    The fire chief shall report to the city manager and shall be responsible for the discipline of the fire department's officers and employees. He shall be responsible for the proper reporting of fires on forms specified by the city manager, for carrying out fire prevention inspections and for the training of the firefighting force. 
(Code 1970, § 2-28) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention code, § 3-121 et seq.; refuse, § 5-31 et seq. 
Sec. 2-65. - Police department; chief of police. 
    The chief of police shall be responsible for the police equipment and the discipline of the police force. He shall perform the duties specified by the statutes for city marshals in third class cities and such other duties as assigned by the city manager or as the council, by resolution or ordinance, may direct. 
(Code 1970, § 2-27) 
State Law reference- Police departments in third class cities, RSMo 85.541 et seq. 
Sec. 2-66. - Public works, department. 
    The duties of the public works department shall include all activities related to garbage and trash collection and disposal, street maintenance and construction, street cleaning, traffic signs, signals and markings, drainage, public building maintenance, maps and surveys and technical engineering services, building safety enforcement, plumbing and electrical safety enforcement and zoning regulation. The department may be divided into divisions, and supervisors may be appointed therefor as the city manager sees fit and as allowed by the budget of the city adopted by the council. 
(Code 1970, § 2-29) 
Cross reference- Buildings, Ch. 3; health and sanitation, Ch. 5; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 7; streets, sidewalks and other public property, Ch. 9; water, sewage and electricity, Ch. 12. 
Sec. 2-67. - Utilities department; superintendent. 
    The duties of the utilities department shall include all activities related to obtaining, treating and distributing water for public consumption and use and for fire protection, sewers and sewage disposal, and all activities necessary to the generation and distribution of electrical energy for power and lighting purposes and for street lighting. The utilities superintendent shall be in charge of all activities of this department. He shall be assisted by such supervisory, technical and operating employees as provided for in the utilities budget recommended by the city manager and passed by the council. 
(Code 1970, § 2-32) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public property, Ch. 9; water, sewage and electricity, Ch. 12. 
Sec. 2-68. - Municipal court. 
    The Cameron Municipal Court, a division of the forty-third judicial circuit of the state, shall be presided over by the municipal judge for a term and with the qualifications, jurisdiction and powers as provided in Article VIII of this chapter and the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 3511, § 9, 9-4-84) 
State Law reference- Judicial circuit No. 43, RSMo 478.183; municipal courts, RSMo 479.010 et seq. 
Secs. 2-69-2-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 

Sec. 2-81. - Qualifications. 
    All officers elected or appointed to offices under the city government shall be voters under the laws and constitution of this state and, except the city sexton, the city attorney, appointed police officers and other employees having only ministerial duties, must be residents of the city. No person shall be elected or appointed to any office who shall at the time be in arrears for any unpaid city taxes, or forfeiture or defalcation in office. 
(Ord. No. 3511, § 3, 9-4-84) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 77.380; residence of municipal judge, RSMo 479.020(4). 
Sec. 2-82. - Appointment and discharge. 
    The council shall appoint a city manager, city clerk, city assessor and city treasurer. The offices of city clerk and city assessor may be filled by one (1) person. All other officers and employees of the city shall be appointed and discharged by the city manager. The council shall have power to make rules and regulations governing such appointments and discharges. 
(Code 1970, § 2-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 78.600. 
Sec. 2-83. - Oath; bond. 
(a)  Every officer of the city, his assistants and every councilman, before entering upon the duties of their offices, shall take and subscribe to an oath or affirmation before some court of record in the county or before the city clerk, that they possess all the qualifications prescribed for their offices by law; that they will support the Constitution of the United States and of the state, the provisions of all laws of this state affecting cities of this class and the ordinances of the city and that they will faithfully demean themselves in office. Such official oath or affirmation shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(b)  Each officer of the city, when required by law or ordinance, shall, within fifteen (15) days after his election or appointment and before entering upon the discharge of the duties of his office, give bond to the city in such sum and with such sureties as shall be designated by ordinance, conditioned for the faithful performance of his duty, and that he will pay over all moneys belonging to the city, as provided by law, that may come into his hands. If any person elected or appointed to any office shall fail to take and subscribe such oath or affirmation or to give bond as required in this section, his office shall be deemed vacant. For any breach of condition of any such bond, suit may be instituted thereon by the city or by any person in the name of the city for the use of such person. 
(Code 1970, § 2-8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 77.390. 
Sec. 2-84. - Compensation; term. 
    All officers of the city shall be paid in equal monthly installments for their services and all employees of the city shall be paid monthly or at such shorter periods as the council shall determine. The creation of all offices and salaries attached to such offices, which may be provided for by the council under RSMo 78.430 to 78.630, shall be by ordinance and such offices shall all be for indefinite terms. 
(Code 1970, § 2-10) 
Sec. 2-85. - Regulation of conflict of interest and lobbying. 
    RSMo 105.450 through 105.482 are hereby adopted by reference as if set out at length in this section. 
(Code 1970, § 2-11) 
Sec. 2-86. - City manager-Term; salary; oath; bond. 
    The city manager shall devote his entire time to the duties of his office. He shall be the administrative head of the government subject to the direction and supervision of the council and shall hold his office at the pleasure of the council or he may be employed for a term not to exceed one (1) year. He shall receive an adequate salary to be fixed by the council which shall not be diminished during the service of any incumbent without his consent. Before entering upon the duties of his office, the city manager shall take the official oath required by law and shall execute a bond in favor of the city for the faithful performance of his duties in such sum as shall be determined by the council. 
(Code 1970, § 2-12) 
Sec. 2-87. - Same-Duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the city manager to: 
(1)  Make all appointments to offices and positions provided for in RSMo 78.600; 
(2)  See that the laws and ordinances of the city are enforced; 
(3)  Exercise control of all departments and divisions that may be created by the council; 
(4)  See that all terms and conditions imposed in favor of the city or its inhabitants in any public utility franchises are faithfully kept and performed, and, upon information of any violation thereof, to take such steps as will be necessary to stop or prevent the further violation of such terms and conditions; 
(5)  Attend all meetings of the council with the privilege of taking part in the discussions but he shall have no vote; 
(6)  Recommend to the council for adoption such measures as he may deem necessary or expedient; 
(7)  Prepare and submit the annual budget, keep the council fully advised as to the financial conditions and needs of the city and perform such other duties that may be prescribed by this Code or that may be required of him by any ordinance or resolution of the council. 
(Code 1970, § 2-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 78.610. 
Sec. 2-88. - Same-Itemized monthly financial report. 
    The city manager shall prepare and file with the council a monthly itemized statement of receipts and expenditures of the city and a summary of the business transacted for the month preceding. Every three (3) months the unpublished reports shall be published in pamphlet form and printed copies thereof shall be furnished to the city library, the various newspapers of the city and citizens applying therefor at the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1970, § 2-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 78.620. 
Sec. 2-89. - City clerk's duties. 
    The city clerk shall, among other duties, keep minutes of the meetings of the council and a journal of the ordinances and resolutions of all proceedings. He shall safely and properly keep all records and papers belonging to the city which may be entrusted to his care. He is hereby empowered to administer official oaths and also to administer oaths to persons certifying to demands or claims against the city. 
(Ord. No. 3511, § 2, 9-4-84) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 77.410. 
Sec. 2-90. - Duties of city attorney or city counselor. 
    The city attorney's or the city counselor's duties, as the case may be, shall be as prescribed by state law. 
(Code 1970, § 2-5) 
State Law reference- Attorneys employed by the city, RSMo 98.330, 98.340. 
Sec. 2-91. - State and national criminal background check required for certain city employees. 
    This section is enacted pursuant to RSMo 43.535, to regulate the employment of people who are applying for employment or are currently employed by the City of Cameron and subject to a criminal background check. 
(1)  An applicant, employee, or volunteer seeking to engage in employment with the City of Cameron shall submit a set of his/her fingerprints taken by the Cameron Police Department. 
(2)  Upon receipt of the fingerprints, the Cameron Police Department will transmit both sets of fingerprints and appropriate fees (unless a satisfactory billing arrangement has been entered into between the municipality and the Missouri State Highway Patrol) to the Missouri State Highway Patrol. The Missouri State Highway Patrol will compare the subject's fingerprints against its criminal file and, (1) if no disqualifying conduct is found therein or (2) if necessary, submit the fingerprints to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a comparison with nationwide records. The results of the Federal Bureau of Investigation check will be returned to the Missouri State Highway Patrol, which will disseminate the state and national results to the Cameron Police Department. 
(3)  If an employer or organization is a public entity, the Cameron Police Department shall (1) render a fitness determination based upon the results of the criminal background check and communicate its fitness determination to such public entity or (2) disseminate the results of the criminal background check to the public entity for a fitness determination. 
(4)  In rendering a fitness determination, the Cameron Police Department will decide whether the record subject has been convicted of or is under pending indictment for (a) a crime which bears upon his/her ability or fitness to serve in that capacity; (b) any felony or a misdemeanor which involved force or threat of force, controlled substances, or was a sex-related offense; or (c) any crime involving stealing, burglary, robbery or similarly related offenses. 
(5)  A record subject may request and receive a copy of his/her criminal history record information from the Cameron Police Department. Should the record subject seek to amend or correct his/her record, he/she must contact the Missouri State Highway Patrol for a Missouri state record or the Federal Bureau of Investigation for records from other jurisdictions maintained in its file. 
(6)  If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on such application his disapproval and the reasons therefor and return the application to the city clerk. 
(7)  If, as a result of the investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant is found to be satisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on the application his approval and return the application to the city clerk for approval or disapproval by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 5511, § 1, 5-4-09) 
State Law reference- Municipal and county government, MULES criminal record review, RSMo 43.535. 
Secs. 2-92-2-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Sections 1, 2 of Ord. No. 4166, adopted September 7, 1993, were treated as superseding Art. VI, §§ 2-111-2-116, in its entirety. Formerly, §§ 2-111-2-116 pertained to the planning commission and derived from §§ 2-39-2-44 of the 1970 Code; and Ord. No. 4132, § 1, adopted February 2, 1993. Sections 1, 2 of Ord. No. 4166 were codified herein as §§ 2-111, 2-112 at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference- Subdivisions, Ch. 10; zoning, Ch. 13. 

Sec. 2-111. - Intent. 
    The city desires to promote the sound principles of health, safety, morals and welfare of the citizens of the city. The legislative body of such city, in order to avail itself of the powers conferred by RSMo 89.010 to 89.140, establishes an independent commission to make recommendations concerning matters of planning and zoning. 
(Ord. No. 4166, § 1, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 2-112. - Created; duties. 
    The mayor and city council hereby create and designate the city planning and zoning commission as authorized by RSMo 89.010. In accordance with RSMo 89.040, the city planning and zoning commission shall regulate land use in the city based upon a comprehensive plan. The planning and zoning commission shall be the lead agency in drafting such plan. 
(Ord. No. 4166, § 2, 9-7-93) 
Secs. 2-113-2-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PARK BOARD[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Pursuant to RSMo 90.500, the city levies a two-mill tax for free public parks as provided in Ord. Nos. 2691 and 2693. 
Cross reference- Use of parks, § 9-6. 
State Law reference- Maintenance of public parks, reduction of tax, RSMo 90.510. 

Sec. 2-131. - Appointment; qualifications. 
    The mayor shall, with the approval of the council, appoint a board of nine (9) directors for the public parks, chosen from the citizens at large with reference to their fitness for such office. No member of city government shall be a member of the board. 
(Code 1970, § 2-45) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 90.520. 
Sec. 2-132. - Term of office and removal of directors. 
    The park board of directors shall hold office, one-third for one (1) year, one-third for two (2) years and one-third for three (3) years, from June first following their appointment and, at their first regular meeting, shall cast lots for their respective terms. Annually after the first terms the mayor shall, before June first of each year, appoint as before three (3) directors who shall hold office for three (3) years and until their successors are appointed. The mayor may, by and with the consent of the council, remove any director for misconduct or neglect of duty. 
(Code 1970, § 2-46) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 90.530. 
Sec. 2-133. - Filling vacancies; compensation. 
    Vacancies in the park board of directors occasioned by removal, resignation or otherwise shall be reported to the council and shall be filled in like manner as original appointments. No director shall receive compensation as such. 
(Code 1970, § 2-47) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 90.540. 
Sec. 2-134. - Organization; rules and regulations; finances; powers. 
(a)  The park board of directors shall immediately after their appointment meet and organize by the election of one (1) of their number president and by the election of such other officers as they may deem necessary. They shall make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for their guidance and for the government of the parks as may be expedient, not inconsistent with this article. 
(b)  The park board shall have the exclusive control of the expenditures of all money collected to the credit of the park fund and of the supervision, improvement, care and custody of public parks. All moneys received for such parks shall be deposited in the treasury of the city to the credit of the park fund and shall be kept separate and apart from the other moneys of the city and drawn upon by the proper officers of the city upon the properly authenticated vouchers of the park board. 
(c)  The board shall have the power to purchase or otherwise secure ground to be used for such parks; shall have the power to appoint a suitable person to take care of such parks, to appoint necessary assistants for such person, to fix their compensation and to remove such appointees and shall in general carry out the spirit and intent of this article in establishing and maintaining public parks. 
(Code 1970, § 2-48) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 90.550. 
Sec. 2-135. - Annual report. 
    The park board of directors shall make, on or before the second Monday in June, an annual report to the council stating the condition of their trust on May first of that year, the various sums of money received from the park fund and other sources, how much money has been expended and for what purposes and with such other statistics, information and suggestions as they may deem of general interest. All such portions of such report as relate to the receipt and expenditure of money shall be verified by affidavit. 
(Code 1970, § 2-49) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 90.560. 
Secs. 2-136-2-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - MUNICIPAL COURT[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic violations bureau, § 7-626 et seq. 
State Law reference- Municipal courts, RSMo 479.010 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-151. - Established. 
    There is hereby established in this city a municipal court to be known as the "Cameron Municipal Court, a division of the Forty-Third Judicial Circuit Court of the State of Missouri." This court is a continuation of the police court of the city as previously established, and is termed, in this article, "the municipal court." 
(Code 1970, § 12-1) 
State Law reference- Judicial circuit No. 43, RSMo 478.183. 
Sec. 2-152. - Jurisdiction. 
    The jurisdiction of the municipal court shall extend to all cases involving alleged violations of the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1970, § 12-2) 
Sec. 2-153. - Superintending authority. 
    The municipal court of the city shall be subject to the rules of the circuit court of which it is a part and to the rules of the state supreme court. The municipal court shall be subject to the general administrative authority of the presiding judge and court personnel of the municipal court shall obey his directives. 
(Code 1970, § 12-3) 
State Law reference- Presiding judge, RSMo 478.240; Judges in judicial circuit No. 43, RSMo 478.750; rules of the circuit court, RSMo 479.020; procedural rules provided by supreme court, RSMo 479.080. 
Sec. 2-154. - Clerk's duties. 
    The city manager shall appoint a person as the clerk of the municipal court. The duties of such clerk shall be to: 
(1)  Collect such fines for violations of such offenses as may be described and the court costs thereof; 
(2)  Take oaths and affirmations; 
(3)  Accept signed complaints and allow the complaints to be signed and sworn to or affirmed before him; 
(4)  Sign and issue subpoenas requiring the attendance of witnesses and sign and issue subpoenas duces tecum; 
(5)  Accept the appearance, waiver of trial and plea of guilty and payment of fines and costs in traffic violations bureau cases or as directed by the municipal judge, and generally act as violation clerk of the traffic violations bureau; 
(6)  Perform all other duties as provided for by ordinance, by rules of practice and procedure adopted by the municipal judge and by the Missouri Rules of Practice and Procedure in Municipal and Traffic Courts and by statute; 
(7)  Maintain, properly certified by the city clerk, a complete copy of the ordinances of the city which shall constitute prima facie evidence of such ordinances before the court and further maintain a similar certified copy on file with the clerk serving the circuit court of the county. 
(Code 1970, § 12-25) 
State Law reference- Clerks of court, RSMo 483.241. 
Sec. 2-155. - Issuance and execution of warrants. 
    All warrants issued by the municipal judge shall be directed to the city marshal, chief of police or any other police officer of the city or to the sheriff of the county. The warrants shall be executed by the marshal, chief of police, police officer or sheriff at any place within the city limits of the county, and not elsewhere, unless the warrants are endorsed in the manner provided for warrants in criminal cases and, when so endorsed, shall be served in other counties as provided for in warrants in criminal cases. 
(Code 1970, § 12-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 479.100. 
Sec. 2-156. - Arrest without warrant. 
    The chief of police and any other police officer of the city may arrest on view, and without a warrant, any person he sees violating, or who he has reasonable grounds to believe has violated, any of the city's ordinances. A power of arrest authorized by this section is in addition to all other powers conferred upon law enforcement officers and shall not be construed to limit or restrict any other power of a law enforcement officer. 
(Code 1970, § 12-17) 
State Law reference- Arrest without warrant, RSMo 544.216. 
Sec. 2-157. - Duties of prosecuting attorney. 
    It shall be the duty of an attorney designated by the city to prosecute the violations of the city's ordinances before the municipal judge or before any circuit judge hearing violations of the city's ordinances. The salary or fees of the attorney and his necessary expenses incurred in such prosecutions shall be paid by the city. The compensation of such attorney shall not be contingent upon the result in any case. 
(Code 1970, § 12-19) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 479.120. 
Sec. 2-158. - Jury trials. 
    Any person charged with a violation of a city ordinance shall be entitled to a trial by jury, as in prosecutions for misdemeanors before an associate circuit judge. Whenever a defendant accused of a violation of a city ordinance demands a trial by jury, the municipal court shall certify the case to the presiding judge of the circuit court for reassignment, as provided in RSMo 478.255. 
(Code 1970, § 12-18) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 479.130, 479.150. 
Sec. 2-159. - Summoning of witnesses. 
    It shall be the duty of the municipal judge to summon all persons whose testimony may be deemed essential as witnesses at the trial and to enforce their attendance by attachment if necessary. The fees of witnesses shall be the same as those fixed for witnesses in trials before associate circuit judges and shall be taxed as other costs in the case. When a trial shall be continued by the municipal judge, it shall not be necessary to summon any witnesses who may be present at the continuance, but the municipal judge shall orally notify such witnesses, as either party may require, to attend before him on the day set for trial to testify in the case, and the judge shall enter the names of such witnesses on his docket. Such oral notice shall be valid as a summons. 
(Code 1970, § 12-14) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 479.160, fees of witnesses, RSMo 491.280. 
Sec. 2-160. - Jailing of defendants. 
(a)  If, in the opinion of the municipal judge, the city has no suitable and safe place of confinement, the municipal judge may commit the defendant to the county jail, and it shall be the duty of the sheriff, if space for the prisoner is available in the county jail, upon receipt of a warrant of commitment from the judge, to receive and safely keep such prisoner until discharged by due process of law. The city shall pay the board of such prisoner at the same rate as may now or hereafter be allowed by law to such sheriff for the keeping of other prisoners in his custody. The payment of board of prisoner shall taxed as cost. 
(b)  The municipal judge may not sentence a defendant to confinement for failure to pay a fine for a minor traffic violation or municipal ordinance violation, as defined in section 1-9(d)(1) and 1-9(e)(1) of this Code and RSMo 479.350, unless such nonpayment violates terms of probation or unless the due process procedures mandated by Missouri Supreme Court Rule 37.65 or its successor rule are strictly followed by the municipal judge. 
(Code 1970, § 12-20; Ord. No. 5948, § 2, 9-6-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 479.180; fees of sheriffs in criminal cases, RSMo 57.290. 
Sec. 2-161. - Parole and probation. 
    Any judge hearing violations of city ordinances may, when in his judgment it may seem advisable, grant a parole or probation to any person who shall plead guilty or who shall be convicted after a trial before such judge. 
(Code 1970, § 12-21) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 479.190. 
Sec. 2-162. - Right of appeal. 
(a)  When the judge is not a lawyer, the defendant shall have the right to trial de novo, even from a plea of guilty, before a circuit judge or an associate circuit judge. An application for a trial de novo shall be filed within ten (10) days after judgment and shall be in the form as provided by supreme court rules. 
(b)  When the judge is a lawyer, the defendant shall have the right to trial de novo in all cases tried before the municipal court, except when there has been a plea of guilty or when the case has been tried with a jury. Trial de novo shall be before a circuit judge or on assignment before an associate circuit judge. An application for a trial de novo shall be filed within ten (10) days after judgment and shall be filed with such form and perfected in such manner as provided by supreme court rules. 
(Code 1970, § 12-22) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 479.200. 
Sec. 2-163. - Appeal from jury verdicts. 
    In all cases in which a jury has been demanded, a record of the proceedings shall be made, and appeals may be had upon that record to the appropriate appellate court. 
(Code 1970, § 12-23) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 479.200. 
Sec. 2-164. - Breach of recognizance. 
    In the case of a breach of any recognizance entered into before a municipal judge or an associate circuit judge hearing a city ordinance violation case, the recognizance shall be deemed forfeited and the judge shall cause the breach of recognizance to be prosecuted against the principal and surety or either of them in the name of the city as plaintiff. Such action shall be prosecuted before a circuit judge or associate circuit judge, and if the case is caused to be prosecuted by a municipal judge, such shall be on the transcript of the proceedings before the municipal judge. All moneys recovered in such actions shall be paid over to the city treasurer to the general revenue fund of the city. 
(Code 1970, § 12-24) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 479.210. 
Sec. 2-165. - Installment payment of fine. 
    When a fine is assessed for violating an ordinance, it shall be within the discretion of the judge assessing the fine to provide for the payment of the fine on an installment basis under such terms and conditions as he may deem appropriate. 
(Code 1970, § 12-28) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 479.240. 
Sec. 2-166. - Court costs. 
    In addition to any fine that may be imposed by the municipal judge, there shall be assessed as costs, in all cases, the following: 
(1)  Costs of court in the amount of twelve dollars ($12.00); 
(2)  a.  In all cases, except those for non-moving traffic violations, the cost for training Cameron law enforcement officers in the amount of two dollars ($2.00). 
b.  In all cases, including non-traffic violation, the cost of one dollar ($1.00) to be deposited into the Peace Officers Standards and Training Commission Fund to be used statewide for training law enforcement officers, paid to the Treasurer of the State of Missouri and mailed to: Budget Director, Department of Public Safety, Post Office Box 749, Jefferson City, Missouri 65102. 
c.  In all cases for violation of an ordinance, a surcharge of seven dollars ($7.00) is to be collected by the municipal court and transmitted monthly to the Missouri Director of Revenue for the State Court Automation Fund as provided in RSMo 488.012.3(5) and 488.027. Such surcharge shall also be assessed in cases in which pleas of guilty are processed in the violations bureau. No such surcharge shall be collected when the proceeding or defendant has been dismissed by the court, when costs are waived, or when costs are paid by the state, county or municipality. 
d.  In all cases for violation of an ordinance, a surcharge of two dollars ($2.00) is to be collected by the municipal court and transmitted monthly to the City of Cameron for the inmate security fund as provided in RSMo. 488.5026. Such surcharge shall also be assessed in cases in which pleas of guilty are processed in the violations bureau. No such surcharge shall be collected when the proceeding or defendant has been dismissed by the court, when costs are waived, or when costs are paid by the state, county or municipality. 
(3)  Other costs, such as for the issuance of a warrant, a commitment or a summons as provided before the associate circuit judge in criminal prosecutions, or as may be required by state law or supreme court rule; 
(4)  Actual costs assessed against the city by the county sheriff for apprehension or confinement in the county jail; 
(5)  Mileage, in the same amount as provided to the sheriff in criminal violations, for each mile and fraction thereof the officer must travel in both directions in order to serve any warrant of commitment or order of this court. 
(Code 1970, § 12-26; Ord. No. 4112, § 2, 10-6-92; Ord. No. 4524, 6-17-97; Ord. No. 5503, § 2, 4-6-09; Ord. No. 5792, § 1, 9-11-13) 
State Law reference- Sheriff's fees in criminal cases, RSMo 57.290; court costs, filing fees, RSMo 479.260; fees for training of peace officers, RSMo 590.140. 
Sec. 2-167. - Costs assessed against prosecuting witness. 
    The costs of any action may be assessed against the prosecuting witness and judgment may be rendered against him that he pay the costs and stand committed until paid in any case where it appears to the satisfaction of the municipal judge that the prosecution was commenced without probable cause and from malicious motives. 
(Code 1970, § 12-27) 
State Law reference- Statutes of limitation, malicious prosecution, RSMo 516.140. 
Sec. 2-168. - Payment of fines to city treasurer. 
    The municipal court shall, within ten (10) days after the first of the month, pay to the city treasurer the full amount of all fines collected during the preceding months, if such amount has not previously been paid. 
(Code 1970, § 12-12) 
Sec. 2-169. - Reimbursement of costs for alcohol and drug-related offenses. 
(a)  Upon a plea of guilty, finding of guilt or conviction for violation of the provisions of sections 7-341.1 or 7-341.2, the court may, in addition to imposition of any penalties provided by law, order the person to reimburse the Cameron Police Department for the costs associated for such arrest. 
(b)  Such costs shall include the reasonable cost of making the arrest, including the cost of any chemical tests to determine the alcohol or drug content of the person's blood, and the cost of processing, charging, booking and holding such person in custody. 
(c)  The chief of police or his authorized representative may establish a schedule of such costs for submission to the court; however, the court may order the costs reduced if it determines that the schedule of costs is excessive given the circumstances of the case or for a good cause shown. 
(d)  These fees shall be calculated as additional costs by the municipal court and shall be collected by the court in the same manner as other costs and fees are collected and remitted to the city treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 4120, § I, 11-3-92) 
Secs. 2-170-2-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MUNICIPAL JUDGE 

Sec. 2-181. - Appointment. 
    The judge of the municipal court shall be known as a municipal judge of the Forty-Third judicial circuit court and shall be appointed by the city manager. 
(Code 1970, § 12-4) 
State Law reference- Municipal judge generally, RSMo 479.020. 
Sec. 2-182. - Qualifications for office; holding other employment. 
(a)  The municipal judge shall possess the following qualifications before he shall take office: 
(1)  He may reside within the city. 
(2)  He must be a resident of the state. 
(3)  He must be between the ages of twenty-one (21) and seventy-five (75) years. 
(4)  He may serve as municipal judge for any other municipality. 
(5)  He may not hold any other office within the city government. 
(6)  He need not be a licensed attorney qualified to practice law within the state. If not a licensed attorney, within six (6) months after his selection to the position he must have satisfactorily completed a course of instruction for municipal judge as prescribed by the state supreme court. 
(b)  The municipal judge shall be considered holding a part-time position and as such may accept other employment subject to the provisions of Missouri Supreme Court Rule 2. 
(Code 1970, § 12-8; Ord. No. 4773, § 2, 7-18-00) 
Sec. 2-183. - Term of office. 
    The municipal judge shall hold his office for a period of two (2) years and shall take office biannually on January 1 of odd-numbered years. If for any reason a municipal judge vacates his office, his successor shall complete that term of office even if the term is for less than two (2) years. 
(Code 1970, § 12-6) 
Sec. 2-184. - Vacation of office. 
    The municipal judge shall vacate his office under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Upon removal from office by the state commission on the retirement, removal and discipline of judges as provided in Missouri Supreme Court Rule 12; 
(2)  Upon attaining his seventy-fifth birthday; 
(3)  If not a lawyer, upon failing, within six (6) months of his selection, to satisfactorily complete a course of instruction for municipal judges as prescribed by the state supreme court; or 
(4)  If a lawyer, upon losing his license to practice law within the state. 
(Code 1970, § 12-7) 
State constitution reference- Commission on the retirement, removal and discipline of judges, Art. V, § 24. 
Sec. 2-185. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The municipal judge is hereby authorized to: 
(1)  Establish a traffic violations bureau as provided for in the Missouri Rules of Practice and Procedure in Municipal and Traffic Courts and RSMo 479.050; 
(2)  Administer oaths and enforce due obedience to all orders, rules and judgments made by him and may fine or imprison for contempt committed before him while holding court, in the same manner and to the same extent as a circuit judge; 
(3)  Commute the term of any sentence, stay execution of any fine or sentence, suspend any fine or sentence and make such other orders as he deems necessary relative to any matter that may be pending in the municipal court; 
(4)  Make and adopt such rules of practice and procedure as are necessary to implement and carry out the provisions of this article, make and adopt such rules of practice and procedure as are necessary to hear and decide matters pending before the municipal court and implement and carry out the provisions of the Missouri Rules of Practice and Procedure in Municipal and Traffic Courts. Any and all such rules made or adopted may be annulled or amended by an ordinance limited to such purpose provided that such ordinance does not violate or conflict with the provisions of the Missouri Rules of Practice and Procedure in Municipal and Traffic Courts or with state statutes. 
(b)  The municipal judge shall have such other powers, duties and privileges as are or may be prescribed by the laws of this state, this Code or other ordinances of this city. 
(Code 1970, § 12-5) 
State Law reference- Duties and powers of municipal judge, RSMo 479.070. 
Sec. 2-186. - Temporary municipal judge. 
    If a municipal judge is absent, sick or disqualified from acting, the mayor may designate some competent, eligible person to act as municipal judge until such absence or disqualification shall cease. The council shall provide by ordinance for the compensation of any person designated to act as municipal judge under the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1970, § 12-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 479.230. 
Sec. 2-187. - Conservator of the peace; docket and court records. 
    The municipal judge shall be a conservator of the peace. He shall keep a docket in which he shall enter every case commenced before him and the proceedings in such case, and he shall keep such other records as may be required. Such docket and records shall be records of the circuit court of the county. The municipal judge shall deliver the docket and records of the municipal court and all books and papers pertaining to his office to his successor in office or to the presiding judge of the circuit. 
(Code 1970, § 12-13) 
Sec. 2-188. - Report to council. 
    The municipal judge shall cause to be prepared within the first ten (10) days of every month a report indicating a list of all cases heard and tried before the court during the preceding month and the cases where there was an application for trial de novo, giving in each case the name of the defendant, the fine imposed if any, the amount of cost and the names of the defendants committed. The report shall be prepared under oath by the municipal court clerk or the municipal judge. This report will be filed with the city clerk who shall thereafter forward the report to the council for examination at its first session thereafter. 
(Code 1970, § 12-12) 
State Law reference- Appeals, trial de novo, RSMo 479.200. 
Sec. 2-189. - Disqualification from hearing particular case. 
    A municipal judge shall be disqualified from hearing any case in which he is in any way interested or in which, before the trial is commenced, the defendant or the prosecutor files an affidavit that the defendant or the city, as the case may be, cannot have a fair and impartial trial by reason of the interest or prejudice of the judge. Neither the defendant nor the city shall be entitled to file more than one (1) affidavit or disqualification in the same case. 
(Code 1970, § 12-9) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 479.220. 
Sec. 2-190. - Transfer of complaint to associate circuit judge. 
    If, in the progress of any trial before a municipal judge, it shall appear to the judge that the accused should be put upon trial for an offense against the criminal laws of the state and not be cognizable before him as municipal judge, he shall immediately stop all further proceedings before him as municipal judge and cause the complaint to be made before some associate circuit judge within the county. 
(Code 1970, § 12-11) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 479.170. 
Secs. 2-191-2-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - CIVIL DEFENSE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Fallout shelters in public buildings, § 3-19. 
State Law reference- Civil defense, RSMo 44.010 et seq. 

Sec. 2-211. - Organization-Created; responsibilities. 
    The is hereby created a civil defense organization known as Cameron Disaster Planning which is responsible for the preparation and implementation of emergency functions required to prevent, minimize and repair injury and damage due to disasters, to include emergency management of resources and administration of such economic controls as may be needed to provide for the welfare of the people and to include emergency activities, excluding functions for which the military forces are primarily responsible, in accordance with the Missouri Civil Defense Act, RSMo Chapter 44. 
(Code 1970, § 6A-1) 
State Law reference- Local disaster planning organization, RSMo 44.080. 
Sec. 2-212. - Same-Members. 
    The civil defense organization established by this article shall consist of a coordinator and other additional members to be selected by the coordinator in order to conform to the state organization and procedures for the conduct of emergency operations as outlined in the Missouri Disaster Operations Plan. 
(Code 1970, § 6A-2) 
State Law reference- Emergency management powers and duties of governor, RSMo 44.022, 44.032, 44.100. 
Sec. 2-213. - Same-Jurisdiction. 
    The civil defense organization established by this article shall perform civil defense functions within the territorial limits of the city and may conduct these functions outside of the territorial limits as may be required pursuant to the provisions of the Missouri Civil Defense Act, RSMo Chapter 44. 
(Code 1970, § 6A-3) 
State Law reference- Mutual-aid agreements, RSMo 44.090. 
Sec. 2-214. - Appointment, powers and duties of coordinator. 
(a)  The coordinator of the civil defense organization for the conduct of emergency operations established by this article will be appointed by the city manager and shall serve until removed by him. 
(b)  The coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration and operation of local disaster planning for civil defense, subject to the direction and control of the city manager or council, as provided by statute. 
(c)  The coordinator is authorized to select and obtain federal government surplus property through the state emergency management agency, the state department of elementary and secondary education or other state agency. The coordinator shall obtain the necessary approval to obligate the city for the handling charge imposed by the department of elementary and secondary education, state agency for surplus property. The coordinator may delegate authority to obtain surplus property at the state agency for surplus property warehouse with the approval of the city manager. 
(d)  The coordinator shall be responsible for maintaining records on the use and disposal of all items of equipment placed under the jurisdiction of the civil defense office. 
(e)  The coordinator is authorized to submit all materials and sign all documents requested by the state emergency management agency to qualify the city for participation in federal contributions for civil defense personnel and administrative expense program under P.L. 85-606. 
(f)  The coordinator shall appoint, provide or remove rescue teams, auxiliary fire and police personnel and other emergency operations teams, units or personnel who may serve without compensation. 
(Code 1970, § 6A-4) 
State Law reference- Surplus property, RSMo 37.075 et seq.; federal goods and services for civil defense, RSMo 44.028. 
Sec. 2-215. - Qualifications of members; oath of allegiance. 
    No person shall be employed or associated in any capacity in the civil defense organization established under this article who advocates or has advocated a change by force or violence in the constitutional form of the government of the United States or in this state or the overthrow of any government in the United States by force or violence or who has been convicted of or is under indictment or information charging any subversive act against the United States. Each person who is appointed to serve in the organization for civil defense shall, before entering upon his duties, take an oath, in writing, before a person authorized to administer oaths in this state, which oath shall be substantially as follows: 
    "I, _______, do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Missouri, against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence; and that during such a time as I am a member of the Cameron Disaster Planning, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence." 
(Code 1970, § 6A-8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 44.115. 
Sec. 2-216. - Procurement; waiver of bid requirements for public work; contracts. 
(a)  In an emergency and during such emergency only, as defined in the Missouri Civil Defense Act, RSMo Chapter 44, the coordinator of the civil defense organization created by this article is authorized on behalf of the city to procure such services, supplies, equipment or material without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to municipal contracts or obligations, as authorized by the Missouri Civil Defense Act, RSMo Chapter 44, provided that if the council meets at such time, he shall act subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by the council. 
(b)  In an enemy attack, the city manager may waive any time-consuming procedures and formalities otherwise required by statute pertaining to the advertisement for bids for the performance of public work or entering into contracts. 
(Code 1970, §§ 6A-6, 6A-7) 
State Law reference- Enemy attack, advertisement for bids unnecessary, RSMo 44.080(2), (3); emergency activities, RSMo 44.110. 
Sec. 2-217. - Location of office. 
    The city manager is authorized to designate space in any city owned or leased building for the civil defense organization created by this article as its office. 
(Code 1970, § 6A-9) 
Secs. 2-218-2-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - LIBRARY[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal tax for library purposes, RSMo 94.070(1); city libraries, RSMo 182.140 et seq.; libraries generally, RSMo 182.800 et seq.; use of library subject to regulations of library board, RSMo 182.230. 

Sec. 2-231. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Book means any book, record, encyclopedia, reference material or paper kept by the city library for use by the public within the library building or loaned to the public for outside use. 
    Librarian means the person employed by the city library to manage its daily affairs. 
    Library means the city library. 
(Code 1970, § 9B-1) 
Sec. 2-232. - Failure or refusal to return book within prescribed time. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone to obtain a book from the library and fail or refuse to return it within two (2) weeks or at the end of the period of time allowed by the librarian. 
(Code 1970, § 9B-6) 
State Law reference- Council may provide penalties for failure to return book, RSMo 182.240. 
Sec. 2-233. - Overdue notices. 
(a)  If any person obtains a book from the library and fails to return it within the time prescribed or extended or fails to pay for the book if it has been lost or destroyed, the librarian shall give such person notice by certified mail that such book is due and allow such person two (2) weeks to return it or pay the value thereof. 
(b)  Evidence of the receipt of the notice as required by this section shall be presumed upon proof of mailing. 
(Code 1970, § 9B-7) 
Secs. 2-234-2-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - ETHICS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-251-2-270. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONFLICTS OF INTEREST[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4037, §§ 1-5, adopted Aug. 13, 1991, did not specifically amend the Code and at the discretion of the editor said provisions have been included herein as Div. 2, §§ 2-271-2-275. 

Sec. 2-271. - Declaration of policy. 
    The proper operation of municipal government requires that public officials and employees be independent, impartial and responsible to the people; that government decisions and policy be made in the proper channels of the governmental structure; that public office not be used for personal gain; and that the public have confidence in the integrity of its government. In recognition of these goals, there is hereby established a procedure for disclosure by certain officials and employees of private financial or other interests in matters affecting the city. 
(Ord. No. 4037, § 1, 8-13-91) 
Sec. 2-272. - Conflicts of interest. 
    The mayor or any member of the city council who has a substantial personal or private interest, as defined by state law, in any bill shall disclose on the records of the city council the nature of his or her interest and shall disqualify himself or herself from council chambers during discussion and voting on any matters relating to this interest. 
(Ord. No. 4037, § 2, 8-13-91) 
Sec. 2-273. - Disclosure reports. 
    Each elected official and the city manager shall disclose the following information by May 1 if any such transactions were engaged in during the previous calendar year: 
(a)  For such person, and all persons within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity of such person, the date and the identities of the parties to each transaction with a total value in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00), if any, that such person had with the political subdivision, other than compensation received as an employee or payment of any tax, fee or penalty due to the political subdivision, and other than transfers for no consideration to the political subdivision; and 
(b)  The date and the identities of the parties to each transaction known to the person with a total value in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00), if any, that any business entity in which such person had a substantial interest, had with the political subdivision, other than payment of any tax, fee or penalty due to the political subdivision or transactions involving payment for providing utility service to the political subdivision, and other than transfers for no consideration to the political subdivision. 
(c)  The city manager also shall disclose by May 1 for the previous calendar year the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of each of the employer of such person from whom income of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or more was received during the year covered by the statement; 
(2)  The name and address of each sole proprietorship that he owned; the name, address and general nature of the business conducted of each general partnership and joint venture in which he was a partner or participant; the name and address of each partner or coparticipant for each partnership or joint venture unless such names and addresses are filed by the partnership or joint venture with the secretary of state; the name, address and general nature of the business conducted of any closely held corporation or limited partnership in which the person owned ten (10) percent or more of any class of the outstanding stock or limited partnership units; and the name of any publicly traded corporation or limited partnership that is listed on a regulated stock exchange or automated quotation system in which the person owned two (2) percent or more of any class of outstanding stock, limited partnership units or other equity interests; 
(3)  The name and address of each corporation for which such person served in the capacity of director, officer or receiver. 
(Ord. No. 4037, § 3, 8-13-91) 
Sec. 2-274. - Filing of reports-Generally. 
    The reports shall be filed with the city clerk and with the secretary of state prior to January 1, 1993, and thereafter with the ethics commission. The reports shall be available for public inspection and copying during normal business hours. 
(Ord. No. 4037, § 4, 8-13-91) 
Sec. 2-275. - Same-When filed. 
    The financial interest statements shall be filed at the following times, but no person is required to file more than one (1) financial interest statement in any calendar year: 
(a)  Each person appointed to office shall file the statement within thirty (30) days of such appointment or employment; 
(b)  Every other person required to file a financial interest statement shall file the statement annually not later than May 1 and the statement shall cover the calendar year ending the immediately preceding December 31; provided that any member of the city council may supplement the financial interest statement to report additional interests acquired after December 31 of the covered year until the date of filing of the financial interest statement. 
(Ord. No. 4037, § 5, 8-13-91) 
Secs. 2-276-2-300. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - TOURISM COMMISSION[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4781, §§ 1-7, set out provisions establishing a tourism commission for the city. Said ordinance did not specify manner of codification; hence, inclusion herein as Art. XII, §§ 2-301-2-307 was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 2-301. - Cameron Tourism Commission; established. 
    The Cameron Tourism Commission is hereby established. 
(Ord. No. 4781, § 1, 8-15-00) 
Sec. 2-302. - Powers. 
    The powers of said commission shall be to advise and recommend to the city council the utilization and expenditure of city resources regarding the promotion and development of tourism and tourism-related activities in the Cameron area; the marketing and funding thereof, and to perform such other acts as the council deems necessary to foster its tourism objectives. 
(Ord. No. 4781, § 2, 8-15-00) 
Sec. 2-303. - Membership. 
(a)  The membership of the commission shall be composed of five (5) commissioners as follows: 
(1)  One (1) representative of the Cameron motel industry; 
(2)  One (1) representative of Cameron fuel outlets; 
(3)  One (1) representative of Cameron restaurants; and 
(4)  Two (2) members to be chosen at large. 
(b)  Said commissioners shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. 
(c)  In the event no representatives of the categories described above can be found to serve, the council may appoint such persons as it deems appropriate to fill said positions. 
(Ord. No. 4781, § 4, 8-15-00) 
Sec. 2-304. - Compensation. 
    All commissioners shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 4781, § 4, 8-15-00) 
Sec. 2-305. - Officers. 
    The commission shall elect a chair, vice-chair and secretary/treasurer who shall serve for one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 4781, § 5, 8-15-00) 
Sec. 2-306. - Terms of members. 
    The terms of the commissioners shall be as follows: 
(1)  The term of each commissioner shall be for four (4) years except that, initially, two (2) members shall serve for four (4) years; one (1) member shall serve for three (3) years; one (1) member shall serve for two (2) years; and one (1) member shall serve for one (1) year. 
(2)  Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term by appointment as described above. 
(3)  The city council may remove any commissioner at any time. 
(4)  Any commissioner missing three (3) successive meetings shall be subject to removal by majority vote of the commission. 
(5)  Terms shall begin August 1, following the initial appointments and a commissioner shall hold office until a successor is appointed and confirmed. 
(Ord. No. 4781, § 6, 8-15-00) 
Sec. 2-307. - Meetings. 
    The commission shall convene monthly at a time and place to be determined by the commission and at such other times as the board may direct. All meetings shall be subject to the open meetings statute for the state. 
(Ord. No. 4781, § 7, 8-15-00)

(a)  It shall be unlawful to construct, alter or change any building or structure as provided in section 3-18 without first obtaining a building permit from the city. 
(b)  No permit shall be issued to make a change unless the changes are in conformity with the provisions of chapter 13. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the contractor constructing, altering or changing any building or structure to obtain the permit. When the owner of the affected real estate is doing the work, the owner then becomes the contractor and is responsible for obtaining the permit required by this section. 
(Code 1970, §§ 5-01, 5-46; Ord. No. 3990, §§ I, II, 10-16-90; Ord. No. 4715, §§ 1, 2, 10-19-99)

Sec. 3-20. - Fire limits; wooden buildings. 
    No person shall erect or construct any wooden building or add to any wooden building already erected within the following territory in the city: Lots one, two, three and four in block forty-four; all of block forty-five; all of blocks forty-six, fifty-four, fifty-five, fifty-six and the west half of block fifty-seven. No person shall move any wooden building or structure from outside such territory into such territory or move any wooden building or structure from any part of the territory to any other part of the territory. 
(Code 1970, § 8-1)
