    Person means any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, political subdivision or organization of any kind or the legal representatives, agents or assigns. 
    Processing means incinerating, composting, baling, shredding, salvaging, compacting and other processes whereby solid waste characteristics are modified or solid waste quantity is reduced. 
    Refuse means solid waste. 
    Rubbish means boxes, wood, construction or repair refuse, grass and shrubbery cuttings, tree limbs and other normal home, yard and business refuse other than garbage or trash. 
    Solid waste means unwanted or discarded waste materials in a solid or semisolid state including, but not limited to, garbage, ashes, street refuse, rubbish, dead animals, animal and agricultural wastes, yard wastes, discarded appliances, special wastes, industrial wastes, and demolition and construction wastes. 
(1)  Commercial solid waste means solid waste resulting from the operation of any commercial, industrial, institutional or agricultural establishment and any multiple housing facility with more than two (2) dwelling units. 
(2)  Residential solid waste means solid waste resulting from the maintenance and operation of dwelling units, excluding multiple housing facilities with more than two (2) dwelling units. 
    Solid waste container means a receptacle used by any person to store solid waste during the interval between solid waste collections. 
    Solid waste disposal means the process of discarding or getting rid of unwanted material; in particular, the final disposition of solid waste by man. 
    Solid waste management means the entire solid waste system of storage, collection, transportation, processing and disposal. 
    Storage means keeping, maintaining or storing solid waste from the time of its production until the time of its collection. 
    Trash means paper, empty food and drink containers, cans, bottles, glass and crockery. 
    Yard wastes means grass clippings, leaves and tree trimmings. 
(Code 1970, §§ 17-1, 17-4; Ord. No. 5676, § 2, 7-5-11) 
Sec. 5-32. - Littering. 
(a)  No person shall throw or place or cause to be thrown or placed any glass, glass bottles, wire, nails, tacks, hedges, cans, garbage, trash, refuse or rubbish of any kind, nature or description upon the city streets, alleys and public rights-of-way of the city or upon any public property owned by the city or upon any private property within the city without the consent of the owner of such property. 
(b)  This section shall not be applicable to the proper disposal of such items and materials in any receptacle, or on any premises, properly designated for such use. 
(Code 1970, § 17-3) 
State Law reference- Littering, RSMo 229.150, 577.070; clearing injurious substances from highways, RSMo 304.160. 
Sec. 5-33. - Burning of trash. 
    The burning of trash and rubbish shall not be permitted within the city limits of Cameron. 
(Code 1970, § 8-6; Ord. No. 4974, §§ 1, 2, 1-21-03) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention code, § 3-121 et seq. 
Sec. 5-34. - Burning yard wastes. 
(a)  The provisions of subsection 5-57(3), prohibited practices, to the contrary notwithstanding, within the corporate limits of Cameron, the open burning of residential yard wastes grown on a residential property is permitted during the following calendar periods and time-of-day restrictions: 
(1)  The third Saturday in October through the third Saturday in April, inclusive. 
(2)  A seven-day period within four (4) weeks of a weather-related event which causes an unusually large amount of natural vegetation debris to accumulate as determined by the city manager and fire chief; and 
(3)  The burning shall take place only between the daytime hours of 7:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. 
(b)  Open burning permitted by this section shall be subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  The minimum required distance from a structure or other combustible material shall be twenty-five (25) feet and the pile size shall be three (3) feet or less in diameter and two (2) feet or less in height. 
(2)  If the safety of the community or the public may be endangered, the city manager may invoke a temporary burning ban. 
(3)  All open burning shall be constantly attended until the fire is extinguished. A minimum of one (1) portable fire extinguisher with a 4-A rating or other approved on-site fire-extinguishing equipment such as dirt, sand, water barrel, garden hose or water truck, shall be available for immediate utilization. 
(4)  The "National Weather Service's" forecasted winds for the area do not exceed twelve (12) miles per hour and or wind gusts greater than fifteen (15) miles per hour. 
(5)  In no event shall a fire started under this section result in a building or structure catching on fire. 
(6)  All fires shall be on private property and not in the public right-of-way. 
(c)  The city manager shall cause each declaration made by him pursuant to this section to be publicly announced by means of broadcasting on a local radio station, and he may cause such declaration to be further announced in a local newspaper when feasible. Each such announcement shall describe the action taken by the city manager, including the time it became or will become effective. 
(d)  The intent of this section is not to require permits for, nor prohibit the use of, portable outdoor fireplaces, manufactured or purpose-built fire pits or cooking grills. 
(Ord. No. 4010, § 1, 2-5-91; Ord. No. 4110, § 2, 10-6-92; Ord. No. 4171, §§ 1, 2, 10-5-93; Ord. No. 5404, § 1, 12-17-07; Ord. No. 5568, § 1, 2-1-10) 
Secs. 5-35-5-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SOLID WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 

Sec. 5-51. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)  The director shall make, amend, revoke and enforce reasonable and necessary rules and regulations for solid waste collection and disposal governing, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Preparation, drainage and wrapping of garbage deposited in solid waste containers; 
(2)  Specifications for solid waste containers including the type, composition, equipment, size and shape thereof; 
(3)  Identification of solid waste containers and of the covers thereof and of equipment thereto appertaining, if any; 
(4)  Weight limitations on the combined weight of solid waste containers and the contents thereof and weight and size limitations on bundles of solid waste too large for solid waste containers; 
(5)  Storage of solid waste in solid waste containers; 
(6)  Sanitation, maintenance and replacement of solid waste containers; 
(7)  Schedules of and routes for collection of solid waste; 
(8)  Collection points of solid waste containers; 
(9)  Collection and disposal of solid waste; 
(10)  Processing facilities and fees for the use thereof; 
(11)  Disposal facilities and fees for the use thereof; 
(12)  Records of quantity and type of wastes received at processing and disposal facilities; 
(13)  Handling and transportation of special wastes such as toxic wastes, sludges, ashes, agricultural wastes, construction wastes, bulky items, tires, automobiles, oils, greases, etc. 
(b)  The city clerk or such other city official who is responsible for preparing utility and other service charge billings for the city is hereby authorized to make and promulgate reasonable and necessary rules and regulations for the billing and collection of solid waste collection and disposal service charges as provided for in section 5-55. 
(c)  A copy of any and all rules and regulations made and promulgated under the provisions of this section shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1970, § 17-9) 
State Law reference- Regulations of department of natural resources, RSMo 260.225. 
Sec. 5-52. - Storage and containers. 
(a)  The occupant of every dwelling unit and of every institutional, commercial, business, industrial or agricultural establishment producing solid waste within the corporate limits of the city shall provide sufficient and adequate containers for the storage of all solid waste except bulky rubbish and demolition and construction waste to serve each such dwelling unit or establishment and shall maintain such solid waste containers at all times in good repair. 
(b)  The occupant of every dwelling unit and of every institutional, commercial, industrial, agricultural or business establishment shall place all solid waste to be collected in proper solid waste containers, except as otherwise provided in this article, and shall maintain such solid waste containers and the area surrounding them in a clean, neat and sanitary condition at all times. Accumulation of waste in suitable containers shall not be stored upon residential or commercial establishments for a period longer than ten (10) days. 
(c)  Residential solid waste shall be bagged and stored in containers of not more than forty-five (45) gallons nor less than thirty (30) gallons in capacity. Containers shall be leak proof, waterproof and fitted with a fly-tight lid and shall be properly covered at all times except when depositing waste in the container or removing the contents from the container. The containers shall have handles, bails or other suitable lifting devices or features. Containers shall be of a type originally manufactured for residential solid waste, with tapered sides for easy emptying. They shall be of lightweight and sturdy construction. The weight of any individual container and contents shall not exceed seventy-five (75) pounds. Galvanized metal containers, rubber or fiberglass containers and plastic containers which do not become brittle in cold weather may be used. Disposable solid waste containers with suitable frames or containers as approved by the director may also be used for storage of residential solid waste. 
(d)  Commercial solid waste shall be stored in solid waste containers as approved by the director. The container shall be waterproof, leakproof, and shall be covered at all times except when depositing waste in the container or removing the contents from the container and shall meet all requirements set forth in section 5-51. 
(e)  Yard wastes shall be stored in containers so constructed and maintained as to prevent the dispersal of wastes placed in the containers upon the premises served, upon adjacent premises or upon adjacent public rights-of-way. The weight of any individual container and contents shall not exceed seventy-five (75) pounds. 
(f)  Solid waste containers which are not approved will be collected together with their contents and disposed of. 
(Code 1970, § 17-5; Ord. No. 6049, §§ 1, 2, 11-5-18) 
Sec. 5-53. - Collection. 
(a)  The city shall provide for the collection of solid waste as follows: 
(1)  The collection of all residential solid waste in the city shall be provided exclusively by the city. The city may provide such service by contracting with a person, county or other city or a combination thereof for the entire city or portions thereof as deemed to be in the best interests of the city. Such person so contracting with the city shall comply with all of the requirements of the ordinances, rules and regulations of the city the same as a person holding a permit. 
(2)  The city may, at its discretion, provide commercial solid waste collection services upon specific application of the owner or person in charge of the commercial establishment. However, in the event that such application is not made or approved or the city does not provide such service, it shall be the duty of such commercial establishment to provide for collection of all solid waste produced upon any such premises. If and when the city does provide commercial collection service, the provisions in this section concerning such service shall apply. 
(b)  All solid waste collected shall, upon being loaded into collection equipment, become the property of the collection agency. 
(c)  Tree limbs and yard wastes, as described in subsections (e) and (f) of section 5-52, shall be placed at the curb for collection. Solid waste containers as required by this article for the storage of other residential solid waste shall be placed at the curb for collection. Any solid waste containers, tree limbs, yard wastes or other solid waste permitted by this article to be placed at the curb for collection shall not be so placed until the regularly scheduled collection day. 
(d)  Bulky rubbish shall be collected by request to the director. The director shall establish the procedure for collecting bulky rubbish and the charges therefor. 
(e)  Solid waste collectors, employed by the city or a solid waste collection agency operating under contract with the city, are hereby authorized to enter upon private property for the purpose of collecting solid waste therefrom as required by this article. Solid waste collectors shall not enter dwelling units or other residential buildings for the purpose of collecting residential solid waste. Commercial solid waste may be removed from within commercial establishments upon written request of the owner and approval by the director. 
(f)  The following collection frequencies shall apply to collections of solid waste within the city: 
(1)  All residential solid waste, other than bulky rubbish, shall be collected at least once weekly. 
(2)  All commercial solid waste shall be collected once weekly and shall be collected at such lesser intervals as may be fixed by the director upon a determination that such lesser intervals are necessary for the preservation of the health and safety of the public. 
(g)  Residential solid waste containers shall be stored upon the residential premises. Commercial solid waste containers shall be stored upon private property, unless the owner shall have been granted written permission from the city to use public property for such purposes. The storage site shall be well-drained and fully accessible to collection equipment, public health personnel and fire inspection personnel. 
(h)  All collection vehicles shall be maintained in a safe, clean and sanitary condition and shall be so constructed, maintained and operated as to prevent spillage of solid waste therefrom. All vehicles to be used for collection of solid waste shall be constructed with watertight bodies and with covers which shall be an integral part of the vehicle or the entire bodies thereof shall be enclosed with only loading hoppers exposed. No solid waste shall be transported in the loading hoppers. However, other vehicles may be used to transport bulky rubbish which, because of its size or weight is not susceptible to being loaded and unloaded in vehicles described in this subsection, but in no event shall such vehicles be operated without adequate cover or binding to prevent spillage of waste therefrom and in accordance with rules and regulations made by the director. 
(i)  Permits shall not be required for the removal, hauling or disposal of earth and rock material from grading or excavation activities; provided, however, that all such material shall be conveyed in tight vehicles, trucks or receptacles so constructed and maintained that none of the material being transported shall spill upon the public rights-of-way. 
(j)  Transportation and disposal of demolition and construction wastes shall be in accordance with subsections (d) and (e) of this section. 
(Code 1970, § 17-6; Ord. No. 6049, § 3, 11-5-18) 
State Law reference- Vehicles transporting solid waste, weight limits, RSMo 260.218; securing loads on vehicles, RSMo 307.010. 
Sec. 5-54. - Disposal. 
(a)  Solid wastes shall be disposed of at a processing facility or disposal area approved by the city and complying with all requirements of the state department of health. 
(b)  The director may classify certain wastes as hazardous wastes which will require special handling, and such wastes shall be disposed of only in a manner acceptable to the director and which will meet all local, state and federal regulations. 
(Code 1970, § 17-7) 
State Law reference- Ordinance may require use of specific facility, RSMo 260.202; definitions relating to hazardous wastes, RSMo 260.360. 
Sec. 5-55. - Service charges. 
(a)  Purpose of system. The system of services established by the provisions of this article is designed as an integral part of the city's program of health and sanitation, to be operated as an adjunct to the city's system for providing potable water and the city's system for providing sewage disposal. 
(b)  Imposed. There is hereby imposed, for the collection and disposal of solid waste, a service charge for each dwelling unit and each commercial establishment to which such service shall be offered under the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Residential collection. Except as otherwise provided, the service charge for collection of residential solid waste shall be determined by current council approved contract per calendar month basis of each dwelling unit. The service charge for the recycling program shall be one dollar ($1.00) per calendar month of each dwelling unit. There shall also be a charge for landfill post closure, administrative, and other charges as the council so determines. The service charges imposed upon the occupant of each dwelling unit, and billing therefor, shall be made to the person contracting for city water and/or sewerage service or for other water service to each such dwelling unit. In the absence of information that such person is neither the owner nor the tenant of such dwelling unit, billing therefor shall be made to the owner. 
(d)  Exemption for elderly persons. Residents making application with the city who are elderly and derive their sole support from social security and/or old-age assistance shall be exempt from the monthly service charge. The city manager is hereby authorized to establish charges for such exempted persons upon the special circumstances in each individual case. 
(e)  Termination of service. The service and service charge shall be terminated upon presentation of satisfactory proof to the director that any such dwelling unit or commercial establishment is unoccupied and shall be commenced upon renewed occupancy thereof. 
(f)  Payment date; penalty for delinquency; legal action to collect. The city shall include the service charge on its utility bill as a separate charge which shall be paid to the city on or before the tenth day of the following month. A penalty of five (5) percent shall be added to the bill and five (5) percent each month thereafter until paid. The city may enforce collection of such charges by bringing proper legal action against the occupant of any premises to recover any sums due for such services, plus a reasonable attorney's fee to be fixed by the court. 
(Code 1970, § 17-11; Ord. No. 4257, § 1, 1-3-95; Ord. No. 4629, §§ 1, 2, 10-20-98; Ord. No. 4629, §§ 1, 2, 10-20-98; Ord. No. 4798, §§ 1, 2, 10-5-00; Ord. No. 4957, §§ 1, 2, 10-15-02; Ord. No. 5327, §§ 1, 2, 10-17-06; Ord. No. 5460, §§ 1, 2, 10-20-08; Ord. No. 6049, §§ 4, 5, 11-5-18) 
Sec. 5-56. - Permit and bond required for business of collecting, transporting, processing or disposing. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the business of collecting, transporting, processing or disposing of solid waste within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining an annual permit therefor from the city; provided, however, that this provision shall not be deemed to apply to employees of the holder of any such permit. 
(b)  No such permit shall be issued until and unless the applicant therefor, in addition to all other requirements set forth, shall file and maintain with the city clerk evidence of a satisfactory public liability insurance policy covering all operations of such applicant pertaining to such business and all vehicles to be operated in the conduct thereof in the amount of not less than current sovereign immunity limits and/or other required minimums. Should any such policy be cancelled, the city shall be notified of such cancellation by the insurance carrier in writing not less than ten (10) days prior to the effective date of such cancellation, and provisions to that effect shall be incorporated in such policy which shall also place upon the company writing such policy the duty to give such notice. 
(c)  Each applicant for any such permit shall state in his application the following: 
(1)  The nature of the permit desired as to collect, transport, process or dispose of solid waste or any combination thereof; 
(2)  The characteristics of solid waste to be collected, transported, processed or disposed; 
(3)  The number of solid waste vehicles to be operated thereunder; 
(4)  The precise location of solid waste processing or disposal facilities to be used; 
(5)  Boundaries of the collection area; 
(6)  If for processing or disposal, a copy of a permit issued by the state; and 
(7)  Such other information as required by the director. 
(d)  If the application shows that the applicant will collect, transport, process or dispose of solid wastes without hazard to the public health or damage to the environment and in conformity with the laws of the state and this article, the director shall issue the permit authorized by this section. The permit shall be issued for a period of one (1) year, and each applicant shall pay therefor a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each solid waste processing or disposal facility to be operated and a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each collection vehicle to be used. If, in the opinion of the director, modifications can be made to the application regarding service, equipment or mode of operation so as to bring the application within the intent of this article, the director shall notify the applicant in writing setting forth the modification to be made and the time in which it shall be done. 
(e)  If the applicant does not make the modifications pursuant to the notice in subsection (d) of this section within the time limit specified therein or if the application does not clearly show that the collection, transportation, processing or disposal of solid wastes will create no public health hazard or be without harmful effects on the environment, the application shall be denied and the applicant notified by the director, in writing, stating the reason for such denial. Nothing in this section shall prejudice the right of the applicant to reapply after the rejection of his application, provided that all aspects of the reapplication comply with the provisions of this section. 
(f)  The annual permit may be renewed simply upon payment of the fee designated in this section if the business has not been modified. If modifications have been made, the applicant shall reapply for a permit as set forth in subsections (b) and (c) of this section. No permits authorized by this section shall be transferable from person to person. 
(g)  In order to ensure compliance with the laws of this state, this article and the rules and regulations authorized in this article, the director is authorized to inspect all phases of solid waste management within the city. No inspection shall be made in any residential unit unless authorized by the occupant or by due process of law. In all instances where such inspections reveal violation of this article, the rules and regulations authorized for the storage, collection, transportation, processing or disposal of solid waste or the laws of the state, the director shall issue notice for each such violation stating therein the violation found, the time and date and the corrective measure to be taken, together with the time in which such corrections shall be made. 
(h)  In all cases, when the corrective measures have not been taken within the time specified, the director shall suspend or revoke the permit involved in the violation. However, in those cases where an extension of time will permit correction and there is no public health hazard created by the delay, one (1) extension of time not to exceed the original time period may be given. 
(i)  Any person who feels aggrieved by any notice of violation or order issued pursuant thereto of the director may, within thirty (30) days of the act for which redress is sought, appeal directly to the circuit court of the county in writing, setting forth in a concise statement the act being appealed and the grounds for its reversal. 
(j)  Each motor vehicle operating under any permit required by this section shall display the number of the permit on each side in colors which contrast with that of the vehicle, such numbers to be clearly legible and not less than three (3) inches high. Each permit for processing or disposal facilities shall be prominently displayed at the facility. 
(k)  Reserved. 
(l)  Each person obtaining a permit to collect, transport, process or dispose of solid waste within the corporate limits of the city shall post with the city a performance payment bond with corporate surety in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
(Code 1970, § 17-8; Ord. No. 3872, § 1, 1-17-89; Ord. No. 6049, § 6, 11-5-18) 
State Law reference- Permit from state department of natural resources, RSMo 260.205. 
Sec. 5-57. - Prohibited practices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Deposit solid waste in any solid waste container other than his own without the written consent of the owner of such container and with the intent of avoiding payment of the service charge required in section 5-55 for solid waste collection and disposal; 
(2)  Interfere in any manner with solid waste collection, equipment or with solid waste collectors in the lawful performance of their duties as such, whether such equipment or collectors shall be those of the city or those of a solid waste collection agency operating under contract with the city; 
(3)  Burn solid waste unless an approved incinerator is provided or unless a variance has been obtained from the appropriate air pollution control agency; 
(4)  Dispose of solid waste at any facility or location which is not approved by the city and the state department of health; 
(5)  Engage in the business of collecting, transporting, processing or disposing of solid waste within the corporate limits of the city without a permit from the city or operate under an expired permit or operate after a permit has been suspended or revoked. 
(6)  Place hazardous, infectious or regulated waste in a refuse container that is not intended for such wastes and marked as such. Any infectious wastes generated from residential sources must be placed in a rigid leak-proof, puncture resistant container with a tight fitting lid. Infectious wastes generated from commercial sources cannot be discarded into the municipal solid waste stream. 
(Code 1970, § 17-10; Ord. No. 5676, § 1, 7-5-11) 
State Law reference- Disposal of solid waste, prohibited acts, RSMo 260.210. 
Secs. 5-58-5-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ANIMALS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Animals in salvage yards or junkyards, § 6-70; nuisances, § 8-126 et seq. 
State Law reference- Municipal control of animals running at large, RSMo 77.510; agriculture and animals generally, RSMo Ch. 261 et seq.; neglected or abused animals, RSMo 578.005 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-71. - Animal neglect; penalty. 
(a)  A person is guilty of animal neglect when he has custody or ownership or both of an animal and fails to provide adequate care or adequate control. 
(b)  Animal neglect upon first conviction shall be punished by a fine not exceeding three hundred dollars ($300.00) or by imprisonment for a period of not exceeding fifteen (15) days or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(c)  Animal neglect upon the second and all subsequent convictions shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. All fines and penalties for a first conviction for animal neglect may be waived by the court, provided that the person found guilty of animal neglect shows that adequate, permanent remedies for the neglect have been made. Reasonable costs incurred for the care and maintenance of neglected animals may not be waived. 
(d)  Payments of additional fees and expenses required. In addition to the foregoing penalties, any person who violates the animal division(s) shall pay all expenses, including shelter, food, handling, veterinary care, and testimony necessitated by the enforcement of the provisions regarding animals at large and adequate restraint. 
(Ord. No. 6034, § 1, 8-6-18) 
State Law reference- Animal neglect, RSMo 578.009. 
Sec. 5-71.1. - Animal abuse. 
    A person is guilty of animal abuse when a person: 
(1)  Intentionally or purposely kills an animal in any manner not allowed by or expressly exempted from the provisions of state law; 
(2)  Purposely, intentionally or recklessly causes injury, suffering, or pain to an animal; 
(3)  Abandons an animal at any place without making provisions for its adequate care; 
(4)  Overworks or overloads an animal, or drives or works an animal unfit to work; or 
(5)  Having ownership or custody of an animal willfully fails to provide adequate care or adequate control. 
State Law reference- Animal abuse, RSMo 578.012. 
Sec. 5-71.2. - Responsibility of parent or guardian of minor owning animal. 
    The parent or guardian of a minor child is responsible for the adequate care of any animal owned by, in the control of or harbored by that minor child. 
State Law reference- Responsibility of parent or guardian of minor owning animal, RSMo 578.014. 
Sec. 5-72. - Running at large. 
    Any geese, ducks, chickens, other domestic fowl, hogs, swine, cattle, sheep or other livestock running at large are declared to be nuisances. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any such fowl or animals to permit such fowl or animals to be at large within the city. 
(Code 1970, § 4-5) 
Sec. 5-73. - Removal of dead bodies. 
    The owner or possessor of any animal or fowl which may die within this city shall, within twenty-four (24) hours after the death of such animal or fowl, remove or cause the dead animal or fowl to be removed beyond the city. If such animal or fowl is not in the possession of any person at the time of its death, and the dead animal or fowl is not removed within twelve (12) hours after its death, then it shall be the duty of the chief of police or any police officer to cause the dead animal or fowl to be removed at the cost of this city. 
(Code 1970, § 4-6) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to require removal of dead animal, RSMo 269.020. 
Sec. 5-74. - Pens and stockyards. 
    No person shall own, keep or use any stockyard, pen, place or premises in which or upon which any number of cattle, swine or sheep are so kept as to be offensive to any person residing in the vicinity thereof or which shall be an annoyance to the public. 
(Code 1970, § 4-7) 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate, suppress or abate stockyards, pigpens, cow stables, etc., RSMo 77.560, 94.110. 
Sec. 5-75. - Keeping of unconfined pigeons. 
    The keeping of unconfined pigeons within the city is declared a nuisance. The chief of police shall destroy all pigeons found within the city not confined within a secure cage. 
(Code 1970, § 4-3) 
State Law reference- Power of city to prevent, abate and remove nuisances, RSMo 77.530, 77.560. 
Sec. 5-76. - Animal excreta. 
    The owner of every animal shall be responsible for the removal of any excreta deposited by his/her animal(s) on public walks, recreational areas, including but not limited to parks, or private property. 
(Ord. No. 4843, § 1, 4-3-01) 
Secs. 5-77-5-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DOGS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Dogs, RSMo 273.010 et seq.; when dogs may be killed, RSMo 273.030, 322.030. 

Subdivision I. - Generally 

Sec. 5-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal shelter means any premises designated by action of the city for the purpose of impounding and caring for dogs found running at large in violation of this division. 
    At large means any dog that is off the property of its owner and not under control of a competent person. 
    Neutered male means any male dog which has been castrated or operated on so as to enable it incapable of impregnating. 
    Owner means any person, group of persons or corporation owning, keeping or harboring a dog. 
    Spayed female means any bitch which has been operated on and rendered incapable of conception. 
    Stray dog means any dog running at large and not wearing the vaccination tag or license tag as provided for in this division. 
    Tethering means the fastening of an animal to a stationary object or stake as a means of keeping the animal under control. Tethering does not refer to the periods when an animal is walked on a leash. 
    Vicious or dangerous dog means any dog, except one owned by or assisting a law enforcement officer in the cause of their official duties, which demonstrates any of the following: 
(1)  Any dog which is determined dangerous based on past behavior, violations of this chapter, or the nature of the animal in relation to persons or domestic animals. 
(2)  Having inflicted a severe or fatal injury on a human being on public or private property. "Severe injury" means any physical injury, resulting directly from an animal's bite or strike which results in death, broken bones, lacerations requiring stitches, or hospitalization. The victim receiving severe injuries must provide the supervisor of animal control a signed physician's statement documenting injury and treatment qualifying such as a severe injury or sign an authorization for release of such statement. 
(3)  Having killed a domestic animal, livestock, or poultry without provocation, while off the owner's property. 
(4)  Animals owned or harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of fighting or any animal trained for fighting. 
(5)  Having bitten a human being, without provocation, on public or private property other than the property of the owner. 
(6)  Having bitten while on the owner's property without provocation, a human being other than the owner or a member of the owner's family who normally resides at the place where the animal is kept. 
(7)  When unprovoked, chases or approaches a person upon the streets, sidewalks, or any public grounds, or private property other than that property of the owner, in a menacing fashion or apparent attitudes of attack, regardless of whether or not a person is injured by the animal. 
(8)  Possessing a known propensity, tendency or disposition to attack unprovoked, to cause injury, or to otherwise threaten the safety of human beings or domestic animals. 
(Code 1970, § 4-8; Ord. No. 4015, §§ 1, 2, 2-19-91; Ord. No. 5832, § 1, 6-16-14; Ord. No. 5957, § 1, 11-21-16) 
State Law reference- "Dog" defined, RSMo 273.010, 273.040. 
Sec. 5-92. - Right of entry of city officers. 
    For the purpose of discharging the duties imposed by this division and to enforce its provisions, any agent of the city or any police officer is empowered to enter upon the premises upon which a dog is kept or harbored and to demand the exhibition of such dog from the owner or the license for such dog. 
(Code 1970, § 4-37) 
Sec. 5-93. - Interference with officers. 
    No person shall interfere with, hinder or molest any agent of the city in the performance of any duty of such agent or seek the release of any animal in the custody of such agent except as provided in this division. 
(Code 1970, § 4-38) 
Sec. 5-94. - Certain dogs declared nuisances. 
    Any dog within the city limits is declared to be a public nuisance when such dog shall: 
(1)  Frighten, annoy, bark at or chase any person or vehicle; 
(2)  By loud and frequent yelping, barking or howling, annoy persons; 
(3)  Destroy any property not the property of the owner or keeper; 
(4)  Not have been inoculated against rabies if over six (6) months of age; or 
(5)  Not have a collar and license tag when required under section 5-124. 
(Code 1970, § 4-13) 
State Law reference- Recovery of damages for domestic animals killed by dogs, RSMo 273.020. 
Sec. 5-95. - Abatement of nuisance. 
(a)  Any person who owns or keeps at any time within the city limits any dog declared to be a public nuisance as defined in section 5-94 who shall fail, neglect or refuse to abate such nuisance within ten (10) days after notice thereof shall be deemed guilty of maintaining a public nuisance. 
(b)  Any dog found to be a public nuisance may be impounded and disposed of as provided in section 5-98, but any dog impounded for being a public nuisance may not be redeemed unless such redemption is authorized by any court having jurisdiction. 
(Code 1970, § 4-36) 
Sec. 5-96. - Removal of collar or tag. 
    No person shall remove or cause to be removed the collar or tag from a dog except during a dog show or at other recognized times for the removal thereof. 
(Code 1970, § 4-9) 
State Law reference- Dogs found without properly marked collars, RSMo 273.100. 
Sec. 5-97. - Running at large-Prohibited. 
    No person, owner or keeper of a dog shall allow such dog to run at-large within the city limits. Such animals shall be properly restrained by leash, fenced property, and/or monitored tethering to prevent the animal from violating the at-large ordinance. 
(Code 1970, § 4-15; Ord. No. 6034, § 2, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-98. - Same-Impoundment; disposal; citing owner; redemption; fees. 
(a)  Each dog found running at large and/or without a license required by this subdivision shall be picked up by animal control and impounded in the animal shelter and confined in a humane manner for a period of not less than five (5) days including a Saturday, and such dog may thereafter be disposed of in a humane manner, if not claimed by its owner. Dogs not claimed by their owners before the expiration of such five-day period shall become the property of the city and shall be disposed of at the discretion of the city. 
(b)  When a dog is found running at large without a proper license and its ownership is known to animal control, such dog need not be impounded but the agent may, at his discretion, cite the owner of such dog to appear in court to answer to charges of violation of this subdivision. 
(c)  Not later than the day after the impounding of any dog, the owner if known to animal control shall be notified. 
(d)  The owner shall be entitled to resume possession of any impounded dog, except as otherwise provided in this section in the case of certain dogs, upon compliance with the license provisions in section 5-121 and upon the payment of impoundment fees as set forth in this section. 
(e)  Any other animal impounded under the provisions of this division may be reclaimed by the owner upon the payment of the impoundment fees as set forth in this section. 
(f)  Any animal impounded under the provisions of this division and not reclaimed by its owner within five (5) days including a Saturday, may be humanely destroyed by the city or adopted by some person deemed to be a responsible and suitable owner who will agree to comply with the provisions of this division; provided, however, that if the animal is one in which the respective rights of the owner and the person in possession or custody are determined by state law, such law shall be complied with. However, no unspayed female dog or unneutered male dog which has been impounded because of its being a stray shall be allowed to be adopted from the animal shelter unless the prospective owner shall agree to have such female spayed or male neutered. 
(g)  Any animal impounded may be reclaimed as provided in this section upon the payment by the owner to the city of the sum of a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) pick-up fee for each animal and the additional sum of ten dollars ($10.00) for each day such animal is kept. 
(h)  Any animal impounded may be adopted as provided in this section upon the payment by the prospective owner to the city the current adoption fees for each animal. Such animal will be spayed or neutered before the adoption is finalized. 
(Code 1970, § 4-23; Ord No. 4739, §§ 1, 2, 2-15-00; Ord. No. 5491, §§ 1, 2, 3-2-09; Ord. No. 6034, § 3, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-99. - Reports of dogs taken into custody and disposition. 
    The animal control officer shall immediately, after the first day of each month, make a written report to the city manager showing the number of dogs taken into custody and the disposition of such dogs during the preceding month. 
(Code 1970, § 4-14; Ord. No. 6034, § 4, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-100. - Dogs in heat. 
(a)  The owner, keeper or person harboring any female dog in heat shall, during the period that such female dog is in heat, keep it securely confined and enclosed within a building except when on the owner's premises after removal from such building briefly for toilet purposes. 
(b)  Any female dog in heat, which is not confined and enclosed as provided in this section, is declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Code 1970, § 4-11; Ord. No. 6034, § 5, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-101. - Restraint of vicious or dangerous dogs. 
    Any person in the city who shall own, keep or harbor a vicious or dangerous dog as defined herein shall keep such dog muzzled securely, tied and otherwise effectively restrained, as provided in this section, when ordered to do so by either the city manager or his/her designee, or the chief of police: 
(1)  Determination of dangerousness upon complaint. When it is charged by any person that any dog is dangerous or vicious, a complaint shall be made by the person making such charge, and the municipal court shall have jurisdiction to determine whether or not such dog is dangerous or vicious. In the event it is determined by the court that said dog is vicious or dangerous in addition to imposing punishment as provided herein for violation of this section, the court shall also have the authority to order the dog killed or securely confined as provided in this section. 
(2)  Leash and muzzle. No person shall permit a vicious or dangerous dog to go outside its kennel or pen unless such dog is securely leashed with a leash no longer than four (4) feet in length. No person shall permit a dangerous dog to be kept on a chain, rope or other type of leash outside its kennel or pen unless a person is in physical control of the leash. Such dangerous dogs may not be leashed to inanimate objects such as trees, posts, buildings, etc. In addition, all dangerous dogs on a leash outside the dog's kennel must be muzzled by a muzzling device sufficient to prevent such dangerous dog from biting other persons or other animals. If an animal is deemed an immediate threat to the public or residents of a dwelling unit, the city designated animal control officer has authority to remove the vicious or dangerous dog from the city (or confined and restrained in house, or commercial kennel) once a citation is issued. The animal shall be confined for the interim time until the court date established in the citation. Unless such case as a bite which breaks the skin shall require immediate removal of animal by the city as required by the department of agriculture. 
(3)  Confinement. All vicious or dangerous dogs shall be securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen or kennel, except when leashed and muzzled as provided in section 5-101(2). Such pen, kennel or structure must have secure sides and a secure top attached to the sides. All structures used to confine dangerous dogs must be locked with a key or combination lock when such dogs are within the structure. Such structure must have a secure bottom or floor attached to the sides of the pen or the sides of the pen must be embedded in the ground no less than two (2) feet. All structures erected to house dangerous dogs must comply with all zoning and building regulations of the city. All such structures must be adequately lighted and ventilated and kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(4)  Confinement indoors. No dangerous dogs may be kept on a porch, patio or in any part of a house or structure that would allow the dog to exit such building on its own volition. In addition, no such dog may be kept in a house or structure when the windows are open or when screen windows or screen doors are the only obstacles preventing the dog from exiting the structure. 
(5)  Warning signs. All owners, keepers or harborers of vicious or dangerous dogs within the city as determined by municipal court shall display in a prominent place on their premises a sign easily readable by the public using the words "beware of dangerous dog." In addition, a similar sign is required to be posted on the kennel or pen of such dog. 
(6)  Registration. Owners of dangerous dogs within the corporate limits of the city shall be required to register their dogs with the animal control officer as a "dangerous dog" within thirty (30) days of the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, or upon the determination that the dog is a dangerous animal by the animal control officer, or a court of competent jurisdiction. The registration shall be accompanied by a registration fee in the amount provided in the city schedule of fees and charges. 
(7)  Identification photographs. All owners, keepers or harborers of dangerous dogs must, within ten (10) days of the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, provide to the animal control department two (2) color photographs of the dog clearly showing the color and approximate size of the dog. 
(8)  Duty to report changes in animal's status. All owners, keepers or harborers of dangerous dogs must within ten (10) days of the incident, report the following information in writing to the animal control department as required hereinafter: 
a.  The removal from the city or death of a dangerous dog. 
b.  The birth of offspring of a dangerous dog. 
c.  The new address of a dangerous dog owner should the owner move within the corporate city limits. 
d.  The deletion, expiration or change in liability insurance policies maintained as required in this section. 
(9)  Sale and transfer restricted. No person shall sell, barter, or in any other way dispose of a dangerous dog registered with the city to any person within the city unless the recipient person resides permanently in the same household and on the same premises as the registered owner of such dog; provided, that the registered owner of a dangerous dog may sell or otherwise dispose of a dangerous dog or offspring of such dog to persons who do not reside within the city. 
(10)  Liability insurance required. The owner or keeper of a dangerous dog shall present to the animal control department proof that the owner or keeper has procured public liability insurance in a single incident in the amount of at least three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for bodily injury to or death of any person or for damage to property owned by any persons which may result from the ownership of such dog. The policy must stay in effect while the dangerous dog is maintained in the city. This policy shall contain a provision requiring the city to be notified by the insurance company of any cancellation, termination or expiration of the policy. 
(11)  Violations and penalties . Any person violating or permitting the violation of any provision of this section shall upon conviction in municipal court be fined a sum not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00). In addition to the fine imposed, the court may sentence the defendant to imprisonment for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days. In addition to all other applicable penalties for violation of this chapter, upon violation of this article the court shall order the registration of the subject dog revoked and the animal removed from the city. Should the defendant refuse to move the dangerous dog from the city, the municipal court judge shall find the defendant owner in contempt and order the immediate confiscation and impoundment of the dog. Each day that a violation of this section continues shall be deemed a separate offense. In addition to all other applicable penalties the foregoing penalties, any person who violates this section shall pay all expenses, including shelter, food, handling, veterinary care and testimony necessitated by the enforcement of this section. 
(12)  Right of entry to dispose of dangerous dog. The animal control officer or any police officer of the city shall have the right to go on any property by order of the municipal court to dispose of any dog found by the court to be dangerous or vicious. 
(13)  Appeals. Any person who has been found guilty by municipal court of harboring, or owning a dangerous dog as defined herein may have their appeal heard in circuit court. 
(Code 1970, § 4-12; Ord. No. 5957, § 2, 11-21-16) 
State Law reference- Keeping other dangerous animals, RSMo 578.023. 
Sec. 5-102. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5958, § 1, adopted November 21, 2016, repealed § 5-102, which pertained to keeping of pit bull dogs prohibited and derived from Ord. No. 3915, adopted October 3, 1989. 
Sec. 5-103. - Guard dogs prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall own, keep, harbor, maintain or allow to be upon any premises occupied by him or under his charge or control any guard dog (for the purposes of this section here defined as a dog not owned by a governmental unit which dog is used to guard public or private property) without such dog being confined behind a fence from which it cannot escape, or within any part of a house or structure except when the windows are open or when screen windows or screen doors are the only obstacle preventing the dog from exiting the structure; and must not be used or maintained in a manner which, as determined by the code enforcement officer of the city, endangers individuals on or off the premises guarded. 
(b)  Any guard dog, including law enforcement dogs, used in the city by virtue of such use is hereby declared to be subject to the license and rabies vaccination requirements of this chapter. 
(c)  All guard dogs residing in or used as such in the city must be registered annually with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 3916, 10-3-89) 
Sec. 5-104. - Enhanced penalty. 
    Upon a plea of guilty to, or upon being found guilty of, a violation of this division, the court shall double the customary fine imposed for similar violations if the dog has not been spayed or neutered. The burden of proof that a dog has been spayed or neutered shall be upon the defendant. 
(Ord. No. 4015, § 2, 2-19-91) 
Editor's note- Provisions enacted by § 2 of Ord. No. 4015, adopted Feb. 19, 1991, and designated as § 5-102, have been redesignated at the discretion of the editor and included herein as § 5-104 in order to avoid duplicative section numbering. 
Sec. 5-105. - Tethering. 
(a)  Animal cannot be tethered unless an adult is home. 
(b)  Animal cannot be tethered between the hours of 10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. 
(c)  Animal must be attached to tether by a leather or nylon collar or harness. 
(d)  Collar must be circumference of animal's neck plus one (1) inch. 
(e)  No choke or pinch collars. 
(f)  Tether must be designed for animals-no log chains. 
(g)  Tether cannot weigh more than 1/8 of the animal's weight. 
(h)  Tether must be at least twelve (12) feet long. 
(i)  Tether must be unbroken and free of tangles. 
(j)  Tethered animals must be placed where the animal cannot be in danger of being strangled or hung. 
(k)  Placement of a tethered animal must be in an area free of debris and obstacles. 
(l)  Tethered animal must be able to reach water, shelter and dry ground. 
(m)  Tethered animal must not be out in extreme weather such as extreme heat greater than ninety (90) degrees Fahrenheit, freezing temperatures of thirty-two (32) degrees Fahrenheit or less, tornados, hail or rain. 
(n)  Each tethered animal must be tethered in separate areas so as not to become entangled. 
(o)  Any tethered animal shall not be allowed to reach within six (6) feet of: 
(1)  Public right-of-ways; 
(2)  Public access to the structure; 
a.  Sidewalk to the structure; 
b.  Any door that may be accessed by the public or emergency services; 
(3)  Neighboring property lines. 
(Ord. No. 5832, § 2, 6-16-14; Ord. No. 6034, § 6, 8-6-18) 
Secs. 5-106-5-120. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - License[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Payment of local option dog tax, RSMo 273.050. 

Sec. 5-121. - Listing dog with city clerk; payment of tax; immunization against rabies. 
    No person shall own or keep a dog or harbor or permit a dog to stray indefinitely upon premises occupied, owned, rented, leased or controlled by him in the city limits unless such person, or someone for him, shall list such dog with the city clerk, shall pay the tax imposed by this subdivision on or before January 1 of each year and shall immunize such dog against rabies, as provided in this division. The owner, keeper or harborer of an animal that is allergic to the required vaccines may be exempt from the vaccine as per section 5-122(b). 
(Code 1970, § 4-16; Ord. No. 6034, § 7, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-122. - Vaccination required. 
(a)  No person shall be entitled to obtain a city license required by this subdivision for a dog until such person submits proof of rabies vaccination of such dog. Such proof may be shown by production of the veterinarian's certificate described in section 5-142. 
(b)  The owner, keeper or harborer of dogs that are allergic to the required vaccines may submit an exemption form to the animal control officer. The form must be completed by a licensed veterinarian with the State of Missouri or a licensed veterinarian from another state. The exemption form must include the breed, sex, age, and name of animal, the reason for submittal, and the owner, keeper or harborer information. Exemption forms will only be accepted for dogs that are properly diagnosed by a licensed veterinarian. 
(Code 1970, § 4-17; Ord. No. 6034, § 8, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-123. - Issuance of license, plate and certificate. 
    The city clerk shall issue licenses to applicants and shall deliver to applicants a metallic plate having the number corresponding to that of the license stamped thereon and shall deliver to such person a certificate showing the number of the license, the year for which the license is granted, the name and residence of the owner of the dog and the sex, color and description of the dog for which the license is issued and the amount of the tax paid therefor. 
(Code 1970, § 4-19) 
State Law reference- Furnishing license tags and certificates for local option dog tax, RSMo 273.090. 
Sec. 5-124. - Metallic plate to be fastened to dog's collar. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner of every dog over the age of six (6) months to put around the neck of such dog a collar or harness to which shall be attached with a metallic fastening the metallic plate issued under this subdivision, and such metallic plate must be worn at all times. 
(Code 1970, § 4-21) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions as to local option dog tax, RSMo 273.080. 
Sec. 5-125. - Amount of tax; use of receipt or tag for other than licensed dog. 
(a)  The tax for each dog in the city licensed under this subdivision over the age of six (6) months shall be paid to the city clerk and shall be as follows: 
(1)  For each male dog or female dog the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) for spayed or neutered and fifteen dollars ($15.00) for unaltered dog per year; 
(2)  If the metallic tag issued for a dog shall be lost, the owner may obtain a duplicate tag upon payment to the city clerk of the sum of two dollars ($2.00); 
(3)  For each month or portion thereof after January 31 of each year, an additional penalty of five dollars ($5.00) will be due. 
(b)  No person shall use for any dog a license receipt or license tag issued for another dog. 
(Code 1970, § 4-18; Ord. No. 4498, 3-4-97; Ord. No. 6034, § 9, 8-6-18) 
State Law reference- Amount of local option dog tax, RSMo 273.060. 
Sec. 5-126. - Disposition of tax revenue; payment of expenses. 
    The city shall pay all money received for the dog license tax imposed under this subdivision into the city's general revenue fund. The city shall draw money for the expenses involved in purchasing tags, records and other miscellaneous expenses in executing the provisions of this division from the general revenue fund. 
(Code 1970, § 4-20) 
Sec. 5-127. - Applicability of provisions to dogs or cats owned by transients. 
    The provisions of this subdivision shall not apply to any dog or cat with or belonging to any transient person within this city when such dog or cat shall remain with the transient person. 
(Code 1970, § 4-24; Ord. No. 6034, § 10, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-128. - Kennel license-Required. 
    No person shall keep dogs within the city limits for the purpose of keeping, maintaining and raising of dogs for sale or for hire without first obtaining a kennel license. 
(Code 1970, § 4-40) 
Sec. 5-129. - Same-Requirements for issuance; fee; exceptions. 
    No person shall be issued a kennel license within any residential area of the city. Kennel licenses may only be issued within an area zoned for business. No kennel will be maintained or operated which does not have services to city sewer and water. All animals kept at a kennel must be within an enclosed building, and no animal will be permitted to be kept in any outside pen or cage. All kennels must be kept clean and free from any annoying odors. Upon acceptance of a license, the licensee agrees to permit any authorized agent of the city to inspect such kennel for health reasons at any reasonable time. Failure to permit such inspection will be cause for such license to be revoked by the city clerk. All kennel licenses will be subject to the approval of the council before such license is issued. The city clerk shall collect a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for such kennel license for one (1) year. Such license fee shall be due and payable on January 1 of each year and, in the first year of issuance of the license, the fee shall not be prorated. This section does not pertain to any licensed veterinarian clinic or any governmental agency. 
(Code 1970, § 4-41) 
Cross reference- Zoning, Ch. 13. 
Sec. 5-130. - Number of dogs. 
(a)  Limitation on number of dogs, cats, and pot-bellied pigs. It shall be unlawful and a public nuisance for any person to keep or allow to be kept at a single residence more than four (4) dogs, four (4) cats or four (4) pot-bellied pigs, or any combination of such animals exceeding four (4) in number, over six (6) months. 
(b)  Removal authorized. When animals in excess of the limit established in the preceding subsections are found at a residence, all of the animals found at the residence may be removed to an animal shelter to be handled as if stray animals, except that the person in charge of the residence, if present, may designate and retain up to four (4) licensed animals. 
(Ord. No. 4859, § 1, 6-5-01; Ord. No. 6034, § 11, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-131. - Dog park license. 
(a)  The owner, keeper or harborer shall first obtain a city dog tag and dog park license from the city clerk before entering dog parks within the city limits. 
(b)  City dog park license must be visible and attached to the dog(s) at all times. 
(c)  All dogs must be properly vaccinated with the rabies vaccine, Bordetella vaccine, and parvo distemper vaccine by a licensed veterinarian. 
(d)  Exemption from the vaccination requirement shall comply with section 5-122(b). 
(e)  Owner, keeper or harborer shall adhere to the dog park warning and safety rules at all times. 
(f)  Transient/non-resident visitors to the city dog park must adhere to all the requirements herein, except that a stand-alone dog park license must be obtained from the city clerk for ten dollars ($10.00), a city dog license is not required. 
(Ord. No. 6034, § 12, 8-6-18) 
Secs. 5-132-5-140. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Rabies Control[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Protection against rabies, RSMo 322.010 et seq. 

Sec. 5-141. - Vaccination-Required. 
    Every person residing within the city owning, keeping, harboring or permitting a dog to remain on premises owned or occupied by him or upon any other premises shall have every such dog over the age of six (6) months vaccinated against rabies each and every year by some licensed veterinarian. Every such person shall place upon such dog a collar, which collar may be the same as used for the license tag, to which shall be attached a metal tag showing that such dog has been vaccinated for the current year against ra- bies. Dogs that are six (6) months old or older at the time they are vaccinated, if vaccinated with chick embryo vaccine, shall be revaccinated immediately at the expiration of three (3) years and at the end of every three-year period thereafter. Dogs less than six (6) months old at the time of being vaccinated with chick embryo vaccine shall be revaccinated within six (6) months and again at the end of every three-year period. Should there be a rabies epidemic in the city and a quarantine is declared, all dogs whose vaccination is more than nine (9) months old shall immediately be revaccinated. Dogs vaccinated with other than chick embryo vaccine shall be revaccinated annually. 
(Code 1970, § 4-25) 
Sec. 5-142. - Same-Certificate; tag. 
    An owner or person having a dog vaccinated shall be furnished by the veterinarian who performs the vaccination a certificate giving the date, owner's or keeper's name and address, the breed, color, sex and weight of the dog and a tag number, as well as the name of the pharmaceutical company producing the vaccine and the lot number of the vaccine used. The veterinarian shall also furnish to the owner or person causing the vaccination to be performed a numbered tag bearing the year of vaccination. Such owner or person shall attach such tag to the dog's collar or harness. 
(Code 1970, § 4-26) 
Sec. 5-143. - Same-Records of veterinarians. 
    Veterinarians in the city shall keep a record of dogs vaccinated by them. 
(Code 1970, § 4-27) 
Sec. 5-144. - Biting of person-Confinement of dog; responsibility of owner. 
    Any dog which shall bite any person causing an abrasion of the skin shall be immediately delivered to a licensed veterinarian for purposes of confinement and observation by the licensed veterinarian for a period of not less than fourteen (14) days. The person owning, harboring or permitting any such dog to be about his premises shall be responsible for delivering such dog to a licensed veterinarian and paying the cost of keeping and confining the dog, for notifying animal control immediately upon knowledge or notice that such dog has bitten any person and, if such dog has been or will be immediately delivered to a licensed veterinarian for confinement and observation as provided in this section, for notifying the police of the name of such veterinarian. 
(Code 1970, § 4-30; Ord. No. 6034, § 13, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-145. - Same-Disposition after confinement. 
(a)  All dogs impounded under section 5-144 and which are not rabid shall be released at the expiration of fourteen (14) days, provided that such dog shall be provided with a collar and the metal tag as specified in section 5-141. 
(b)  All dogs which become rabid during the period of their confinement shall be killed and the animal control supervisor shall deliver the head with the brain of such dog to the state laboratory or other authorized laboratory for analysis. 
(Code 1970, § 4-31; Ord. No. 6034, § 14, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-146. - Same-Disposal by owner prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person with notice or knowledge that a dog owned, harbored or permitted to remain about his premises has bitten any person to dispose of such dog in any manner. 
(Code 1970, § 4-32) 
Sec. 5-147. - Same-Notice of death of dog; securing while confined. 
    The person in charge of the animal shelter or a veterinarian shall notify the animal control supervisor immediately of the death of any dog while under his observation or care. Each dog which has bitten any person shall be secured in such a manner as to prevent its biting other dogs or animals while such dog remains in the animal shelter or in the care of a veterinarian. 
(Code 1970, § 4-33; Ord. No. 6034, § 15, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-148. - Slaying of dangerous, fierce or vicious dog. 
    If any dangerous, fierce or vicious dog cannot be safely taken up or impounded, such dog may be slain by any police officer. In all cases where a dog, which has bitten a person or caused an abrasion of the skin, is slain by any police officer, whether by order of court or otherwise, and a period of less than fifteen (15) days has elapsed since the day upon which the dog bit any person or caused an abrasion of the skin of any person, it shall be the duty of the animal control supervisor to cause to be delivered, without delay, the head with the brain of such dog to the state laboratory or other authorized laboratory for an analysis. 
(Code 1970, § 4-34; Ord. No. 6034, § 16, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-149. - Quarantine order. 
    Whenever rabies becomes prevalent in the city, the mayor shall, according to the necessity of the case, issue a quarantine order requiring every owner or person in charge of any dog within the limits of the city to either kill or impound his dog or to have such dog immunized. The order shall be published once in the paper officially publishing the business of the city and, in the absence of such paper, shall be posted as in cases of sales of personal property. The mayor, by proclamation, may terminate any such quarantine whenever, in his judgment, the necessity for it no longer exists. 
(Code 1970, § 4-35) 
State Law reference- Quarantine order of mayor when rabies becomes prevalent, RSMo 322.040. 
DIVISION 3. - CATS 

Sec. 5-150. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal shelter means any premises designated by action of the city for the purposes of impounding and caring for cats found running at large in violation of this division. 
    At large means any cat that is off the property of its owner and not under the control of a competent person. 
    Owner means any person, group of persons or a corporation owning, keeping or harboring a cat. 
(Ord. No. 3976, 8-21-90) 
Sec. 5-151. - Running at large prohibited. 
    No person, owner or keeper of a cat shall allow such cat to run at-large within the city limits. Such animals shall be properly restrained by leash, fenced property, and/or monitored tethering to prevent the animal from violating the at-large ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 3976, 8-21-90; Ord. No. 5491, §§ 1, 2, 3-2-09; Ord. No. 6034, § 17, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-152. - Impoundment; disposal; citing owner; redemption. 
(a)  Each cat found running at large shall be picked up by animal control and impounded in the animal shelter and confined in a humane manner for a period of not less than five (5) days including a Saturday, and such cat may thereafter be disposed of in a humane manner, if not claimed by its owner. Cats not claimed by their owners before the expiration of such five-day period shall become the property of the city and shall be disposed of at the discretion of the city. 
(b)  When a cat is found running at large and its ownership is known to animal control such cat need not be impounded but the agent may, at his discretion, site the owner of such cat to appear in court to answer to charges of violation of this division. 
(c)  Not later than the day after the impounding of any cat, the owner if known to animal control shall be notified. 
(d)  Any cat impounded under the provisions of this section and not reclaimed by its owner within five (5) days including a Saturday, may be humanely destroyed by the city or adopted by some person deemed to be a responsible and suitable owner who will agree to comply with the provisions of this division; provided, however, that if the animal is one in which the respective rights of the owner and the person in possession or custody are determined by state law, such law shall be complied with. However, no unspayed female cat or unneutered male cat which has been impounded because of its being a stray shall be allowed to be adopted from the animal shelter unless the prospective owner shall agree to have such female spayed or male neutered. 
(e)  Any animal impounded may be reclaimed and/or adopted as provided in this section upon the payment by the owner to the city clerk of the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) pickup fee for each animal and the additional sum of ten dollars ($10.00) for each day such animal is kept. 
(f)  Any animal impounded may be adopted as provided in this section upon the payment by the prospective owner to the city clerk the current adoption fees for each animal. Such animal will be spayed or neutered before the adoption is finalized. 
(Ord. No. 3976, 8-21-90; Ord. No. 5491, §§ 1, 2, 3-2-09; Ord. No. 6034, § 18, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-153. - Reports of cats taken into custody and disposition. 
    The animal control supervisor shall immediately, after the first day of each month, make a written report to the city manager showing the number of cats taken into custody and the disposition of such cats during the preceding month. 
(Ord. No. 3976, 8-21-90; Ord. No. 6034, § 19, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-154. - Listing cat with city clerk; payment of tax; immunization against rabies. 
    No person shall own or keep a cat or harbor or permit a cat to stray indefinitely upon premises occupied, owned, rented, leased or controlled by him in the city limits unless such person, or someone for him, shall list such cat with the city clerk, shall pay the tax imposed by this subdivision on or before January 1st of each year and shall immunize such cat against rabies as provided in this division. If the owner, keeper or harborer of an animal that is allergic to the required vaccines, then section 5-122(b) shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 6034, § 20, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-155. - Vaccination-Required. 
(a)  No person shall be entitled to obtain a city license required by this subdivision for a cat until such person submits proof of the rabies vaccination of such cat. Such proof may be shown by production of the veterinarian's certificate described in section 5-142. 
(b)  The owner, keeper or harborer of cats that are allergic to the required vaccines may submit an exemption form to the animal control officer. The form must be completed by a licensed veterinarian with the State of Missouri or a licensed veterinarian from another state. The exemption form must include the breed, sex, age, and name of animal, the reason for submittal, and the owner, keeper or harborer information. Exemption forms will only be accepted for cats that are properly diagnosed by a licensed veterinarian. 
(Ord. No. 6034, § 21, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-156. - Issuance of license, plate and certificate. 
    The city clerk shall issue licenses to applicants and shall deliver to applicants a metallic plate having the number corresponding to that of the license stamped thereon and shall deliver to such person a certificate showing the number of the license, the year for which the license is granted, the name and residence of the owner of the cat and the sex, color and description of the cat for which the license is issued and the amount of the tax paid therefor. 
(Ord. No. 6034, § 22, 8-6-18) 
State Law reference- Furnishing license tags and certificates for local option dog tax, RSMo 273.090 
Sec. 5-157. - Metallic plate to be fastened to cat collar. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner of every cat over the age of six (6) months to put around the neck of such cat a collar or harness to which shall be attached with a metallic fastening the metallic plate issued under this subdivision, and such metallic plate must be worn at all times. 
(Ord. No. 6034, § 23, 8-6-18) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions as to local option dog tax, RSMo 273.080. 
Sec. 5-158. - Amount of tax; use of receipt or tag for other than licensed cat. 
(a)  The tax for each cat in the city licensed under this subdivision over the age of six (6) months shall be paid to the city clerk and shall be as follows: 
(1)  For each male cat or female cat the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) for spayed or neutered and fifteen dollars ($15.00) for unaltered per year; 
(2)  If the metallic tag issued for a cat shall be lost, the owner may obtain a duplicate tag upon payment to the city clerk of the sum of two dollars ($2.00); 
(3)  For each month or portion thereof after January 31st of each year, an additional penalty of five dollars ($5.00). 
(b)  No person shall use for any cat a license receipt or license tag issued for another cat. 
(Ord. No. 6034, § 24, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-159. - Disposition of tax revenue; payment of expenses. 
    The city shall pay all money received for the cat license tax imposed under this subdivision into the city's general revenue fund. The city shall draw money for the expenses involved in purchasing tags, records and other miscellaneous expenses in executing the provisions of this division from the general revenue fund. 
(Ord. No. 6034, § 25, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-160. - Number of cats. 
(a)  Limitation on number of dogs, cats, and pot-bellied pigs. It shall be unlawful and a public nuisance for any person to keep or allow to be kept at a single residence more than four (4) dogs, four (4) cats or four (4) pot-bellied pigs, or any combination of such animals exceeding four (4) in number, over the age of six (6) months. 
(b)  Removal authorized. When animals in excess of the limit established in the preceding subsections are found at a residence, all of the animals found at the residence may be removed to an animal shelter to be handled as if stray animals, except that the person in charge of the residence, if present, may designate and retain up to four (4) licensed animals. 
(Ord. No. 6034, § 26, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-160A. - Biting of person. 
    Any cat which shall bite any person causing an abrasion of the skin shall be immediately delivered to a licensed veterinarian for purposes of confinement and observation by the licensed veterinarian for a period of not less than fourteen (14) days. The person owning, harboring or permitting any such cat to be about his premises shall be responsible for delivering such cat to a licensed veterinarian and paying the cost of keeping and confining the cat, for notifying animal control immediately upon knowledge or notice that such cat has bitten any person and, if such cat has been or will be immediately delivered to a licensed veterinarian for confinement and observation as provided in this section, for notifying the police of the name of such veterinarian. 
(Ord. No. 6034, § 27, 8-6-18) 
DIVISION 4. - DANGEROUS AND PROHIBITED ANIMALS 

Sec. 5-161. - In general. 
(a)  The following animals are hereby declared to be dangerous and the keeping or harboring of such animals within the city is prohibited, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section: 
(1)  Lions, tigers, bears, leopards, ocelots, jaguars, cheetahs, margays, mountain lions, Canada lynx, bobcats, jaguarundi, hyenas, wolves, and coyotes; 
(2)  Nonhuman primates, raccoons, skunks, and foxes; 
(3)  Any deadly, dangerous, or poisonous reptile; 
(4)  Any nondomestic cat, wild/domestic cat hybrid, wolf/dog hybrid, or poisonous animal; 
(5)  Any other animal which is inherently dangerous because of past behavior, violations of this chapter, or the nature of the animal in relation to persons or domestic animals. 
(b)  The animals listed in subsection (a) of this section may be kept in a properly maintained and licensed zoological park, circus, scientific or educational institution, research laboratory, veterinary hospital or animal refuge, only after such animals have been registered with the supervisor of animal control. 
(c)  In the event any animal kept under subsection (b) of this section becomes a threat to humans or domestic animals, the animal control officer must complete a written report certifying the same based upon the guidelines set forth in this subsection (c). A copy of the report shall be submitted to the city clerk and mailed to the owner by regular U.S. mail. The following are guidelines for certification: 
(1)  Having inflicted a severe or fatal injury on a human being on public or private property. "Severe injury" means any physical injury, resulting directly from an animal's bite or strike which results in death, broken bones, lacerations requiring stitches, or hospitalization. The victim receiving severe injuries must provide the supervisor of animal control a signed physician's statement documenting injury and treatment qualifying such as a severe injury or sign an authorization for release of such statement; 
(2)  Having killed a domestic animal, livestock, or poultry without provocation, while off the owner's property; 
(3)  Owning or harboring primarily or in part for the purpose of fighting or any animal trained for fighting; 
(4)  Having bitten a human being, without provocation, on public or private property other than the property of the owner; 
(5)  Having bitten while on the owner's property without provocation, a human being other than the owner or a member of the owner's family who normally resides at the place where the animal is kept; 
(6)  When unprovoked, chases or approaches a person upon the streets, sidewalks, or any public grounds, or private property other than that property of the owner, in a menacing fashion or apparent attitudes of attack, regardless of whether or not a person is injured by the animal; 
(7)  Possessing a known propensity, tendency or disposition to attack unprovoked, to cause injury, or to otherwise threaten the safety of human beings or domestic animals. 
(d)  If the circumstances described in subsection (c) of this section are in dispute, then the owner has the option of submitting, within five (5) working days of receiving notice, a written request to the chief of police for a hearing on the matter as follows: 
(1)  A hearing board, consisting of the animal control officer, city manager, and a council representative, shall be convened within ten (10) working days after receipt of a written request from the owner. 
(2)  Pending the outcome of such a hearing, the animal must be confined in such a manner so as not be a threat to any person. The confinement may be on the homeowner's premises or with a licensed veterinarian. 
(3)  The hearing board shall determine whether the determination by the animal control supervisor is correct based upon evidence and testimony presented at the time of the hearing by the new owner, in addition to witnesses, animal control personnel, police or any other person possessing information pertinent to such determination. 
(4)  The hearing board shall issue written findings within five (5) days after the hearing.
