If the hearing board sustains the determination, the owner or possessor of the animal shall be required to maintain the animal as provided in subsection (d)(2) until action is taken according to subsection (e). 
(e)  Actions to be taken for an animal on which a determination has been made under subsection (c) or (d) of this section is as follows: The animal shall be humanely destroyed or removed from the city limits within forty-eight (48) hours after notification. 
(f)  Nonconforming animals described in section (a) that are currently existing in the city limits shall be removed within sixty (60) days of the passage of this division. The animal control supervisor will send notices to owners for any known violation. 
(Ord. No. 4521, 6-3-97; Ord. No. 6034, § 28, 8-6-18) 
DIVISION 5. - LIVESTOCK, POULTRY AND SWINE 

Sec. 5-162. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal means any live vertebrate creature, domestic or wild, except humans. 
    Domestic animal means any species of animal selectively bred by humans over generations to achieve desired qualities such as tameness, size, meat or fur quality, disease resistance and other characteristics. 
    Livestock includes horses, mules, cattle, sheep, goats, donkeys, elk, yak, bovine, equine, burro, deer, oxen, bison, ostrich, emus and related members of the species or other similar domestic animals excluding swine and household pets. 
    Poultry means any breed or variety of chickens, ducks, geese, turkey, doves, fowl, pigeons, game hens, quail or other domesticated or wild bird. 
    Small animal includes rabbits, chinchillas, mink, hamsters, gerbils and related members of the species or other similar domestic or wild animals excluding household pets. 
    Swine means any breed or variety of pigs, hogs, boars, pork and related members of the species except Vietnamese pot-bellied pigs. 
(Ord. No. 5243, § 1, 11-15-05) 
Sec. 5-162.1. - Livestock. 
    The keeping of livestock within the city limits shall conform to the following conditions: 
(1)  Minimum distance from neighboring dwelling: one hundred (100) feet 
(2)  Maximum density allowed: two (2) head/acre 
(3)  Minimum area required: one (1) acre 
(4)  Maximum number of aggregate animals allowed: six (6) head 
(5)  Minimum distance of barn or shed from property line: twenty-five (25) feet 
(6)  The calculation of area available shall not include dwellings, garages, outbuildings or other land which is not immediately accessible to the animals. 
(Ord. No. 5243, § 1, 11-15-05) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5243, § 1, adopted November 15, 2005, set out provisions intended for use as a duplicate § 5-162. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 5-162.1. 
Sec. 5-163. - Poultry and small animals. 
    The keeping of poultry and small animals in the city limits shall conform to the following conditions: 
(1)  Maximum number of animals allowed: twelve (12) animals 
(2)  All animals must be confined to pens. 
(3)  Minimum pen size allowed: one hundred forty-four (144) square feet 
(4)  Minimum distance of pen from neighboring dwelling: one hundred (100) feet 
(5)  Minimum distance of pen from property line: twenty-five (25) feet 
(Ord. No. 5243, § 1, 11-15-05) 
Sec. 5-164. - Swine-Prohibited. 
    The keeping of swine in the City of Cameron is prohibited, except Vietnamese pot-bellied pigs, which are considered to be household pets and shall be regulated the same as dogs and cats with the requirement that they be licensed, vaccinated and limited to four (4) adult animals per housing unit. 
(Ord. No. 5243, § 1, 11-15-05; Ord. No. 6034, § 29, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-165. - Sucklings. 
    Suckling offspring of the above-described animals shall be exempt from the above limitations on numbers and density permitted, however they must comply with the distance, setback and penning requirements set forth above. 
(Ord. No. 5243, § 1, 11-15-05) 
Sec. 5-166. - Livestock permit required. 
    No livestock, poultry or small animals as defined herein, except household pets, shall be kept without first having obtained a permit issued by the city. 
(1)  A livestock permit shall be issued to the owner or occupant. Any change in ownership or occupancy of the site for which a livestock permit has been granted shall terminate the permit. 
(2)  No license shall be issued unless the applicant shall comply with all ordinances of the city including, but not limited to, zoning, nuisance, health and sanitation, building and fire codes and the applicant shall not be delinquent in the payment of real estate taxes and personal property taxes. 
(3)  Each applicant for a livestock permit required by this article agrees to allow inspection of his premises by the city prior to issuance of the permit and periodically thereafter to determine if the permitee is in compliance. 
(4)  The city manager or his delegate is hereby granted the authority to deny a permit required by this division to an applicant who fails to comply with the provisions of this division and to revoke or suspend a permit upon determination that the permitee is in violation of any of the provisions of this division. 
(5)  In the event that the use for which the permit is issued is discontinued for a period of one (1) year or more, the permit shall terminate and all fencing which does not comply with Article 33, Fences, of Chapter 13, Zoning, shall be removed. 
(Ord. No. 5243, § 1, 11-15-05) 
Sec. 5-167. - Application for livestock permit. 
    Each applicant for a livestock permit shall provide the following information: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number of applicant. 
(2)  Name, address and telephone number of property owner. 
(3)  Signature of property owner signifying permission to use the property for the purpose proposed. 
(4)  Address and legal description of the property upon which animals are to be kept. 
(5)  Site plan, drawn to scale, showing dwellings, barns, sheds, pens, enclosures, and structures including those proposed or intended and dimensions thereof. 
(6)  Neighboring dwellings and distances thereto. 
(7)  Distances from barns, sheds, pens, and structures to property lines. 
(8)  Calculation of total available/suitable area in acres on which animals are to be kept. 
(9)  Location, height, material and type of all existing and proposed fences. 
(10)  Location and size of manure receptacles. 
(11)  Number and species of animals proposed to be kept. 
(Ord. No. 5243, § 1, 11-15-05) 
Sec. 5-168. - Fee. 
    A non-refundable fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be paid by each applicant for a livestock permit. 
(Ord. No. 5243, § 1, 11-15-05; Ord. No. 6034, § 30, 8-6-18) 
Sec. 5-169. - Fences for livestock. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of Article 33, Fences, of Chapter 13, Zoning, the following livestock fencing provisions shall be allowed: 
(1)  Upon application for a livestock permit, the applicant shall show the location, height, material and type of fencing desired. 
(2)  The city manager, or his delegate, shall have the authority to approve, disapprove or modify the height, material, type and other characteristics of the fencing allowed. 
(3)  Barbed wire, single-strand fences, electric fences or fences otherwise deemed dangerous shall not be permitted. 
(4)  In all other respects, the provisions of Article 33, Fences of the Cameron Zoning Ordinance shall be followed. 
(Ord. No. 5243, § 1, 11-15-05) 
Sec. 5-170. - A-1, Agricultural District-Exempt. 
    The provisions of this division shall not apply to the A-1 Agricultural District. 
(Ord. No. 5243, § 1, 11-15-05) 
Sec. 5-171. - Disposal of manure and feed containment. 
    Every stable, barn, shed, coop, pen or other structure where an animal, except household pets, is kept, shall have either within it or immediately adjoining, a container or receptacle for receiving and holding manure and litter. 
(1)  The receptacle shall be flyproof, ratproof, watertight and securely covered at all times except when being filled or emptied. 
(2)  The receptacle shall be emptied at least once each week and the contents removed to outside the city limits. Any manure allowed to accumulate outside the receptacle for more than forty-eight (48) hours shall be declared a nuisance. 
(3)  The city manager or animal control officer may order the immediate cleaning and disinfecting of all or any part of any premises where animals are kept upon finding a violation of this section or be subject to abatement as provided by law. 
(4)  All animal feed, except hay or grass, shall be stored in a secure, flytight, ratproof container. 
(Ord. No. 5243, § 1, 11-15-05) 
Chapter 6 - LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings, Ch. 3; finance and taxation, Ch. 4; health and sanitation, Ch. 5; streets, sidewalks and other public property, Ch. 9; subdivisions, Ch. 10; trailer coaches, Ch. 11; zoning, Ch. 13. 
State Law reference- Limitations on municipal licensing, RSMo 71.610 et seq.; municipal taxes, licenses, wharfage and other duties generally, RSMo 94.020; licensing of specific businesses, issuance, RSMo 94.110, 94.120. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 6-1-6-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GENERAL BUSINESS LICENSE 

Sec. 6-16. - Definition. 
    As used in this article, gross receipts means all receipts from any business, profession, grade or occupation including cash, credits, fees, commissions, brokerage charges, rentals and property of any kind either from sales made or services rendered, without deduction for the cost of property sold, cost of materials, labor, taxes, interest and discounts. 
(Code 1970, § 10-1) 
State Law reference- "Gross receipts" defined, RSMo 144.010(1), (3). 
Sec. 6-17. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is for tax revenue and for the regulation of business by the city under the laws of the state and the ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3529, § 2(10-2), 5-7-85) 
State Law reference- When municipal license tax may be imposed on businesses, RSMo 71.610. 
Sec. 6-18. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in any manufacturing, merchandising, business, trade or occupation without first having obtained a license therefor from the city clerk. 
(Code 1970, § 10-3) 
Sec. 6-19. - Time for making applications; penalty for delinquent applications. 
    Each person affected by the license required by this article shall be responsible for making application for such license no later than June thirtieth of each year. All license applications, other than those for new businesses, shall be considered delinquent after this date and subject to a penalty of five dollars ($5.00). 
(Code 1970, § 10-4) 
Sec. 6-20. - Compliance with other ordinances; payment of other taxes. 
    No license shall be issued unless the applicant shall comply with all ordinances of the city including but not limited to zoning regulations, nuisance ordinances and the fire code, and the applicant shall not be delinquent in the payment of real estate taxes and personal property taxes. 
(Ord. No. 3529, § 3(10-10(A)), 5-7-85) 
Sec. 6-20.1. - Evidence of workers' compensation insurance prior to license issuance. 
(a)  No license required under the provisions of this section shall be issued by the city clerk to any person until such person produces a copy of a certificate of insurance for workers' compensation coverage if the applicant for the license is required to cover his liability under RSMo 287. It is further made a violation of this section to provide fraudulent information to the city clerk. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to create or constitute a liability to or a cause of action against the city in regard to the issuance or nonissuance of any license for failure to provide evidence of workers' compensation coverage. 
(c)  The city clerk is directed to take appropriate actions including altering the license application form to require a statement and evidence of workers' compensation insurance. 
(Ord. No. 4157, § 1, 8-3-93) 
Sec. 6-20.2. - No tax due letter. 
    No person shall be issued an occupation license without submitting a "No Tax Due" letter from the State of Missouri Department of Revenue or notarized affidavit of sales tax exemption. (RSMo 144.083) 
(Ord. No. 5510, § 2, 4-20-09) 
Sec. 6-20.3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5936, § 1, adopted July 18, 2016, repealed § 6-20.3, which pertained to immigration compliance and derived from Ord. No. 5510, adopted April, 20, 2009. 
Sec. 6-21. - Inspection of premises. 
    Each applicant for a license required by this article agrees to allow the inspection of his place of business by the city manager or by someone appointed by him, prior to issuance of the license. Following the issuance of a license, the licensee agrees to allow periodic inspections of the premises to determine if the license is in compliance. 
(Ord. No. 3529, § 3(10-10(B)), 5-7-85) 
Sec. 6-22. - Effective date of license; period for determination of gross receipts; minimum fee for new business. 
    All full-year licenses shall take effect from the date of issue, June 1 of each year, and shall be based on the gross receipts volume for the previous calendar year, January first through December thirty-first. In the case of new business the minimum license fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be charged for the first year or any portion of a year. 
(Code 1970, § 10-9) 
Sec. 6-23. - Tax levied on certain businesses and occupations. 
    There is hereby levied a tax upon the license required by this article for the privilege of engaging, within the city, in any of the businesses or occupations enumerated in RSMo 94.110 or listed separately in this article. 
(Code 1970, § 10-5) 
Sec. 6-24. - Fee schedule-Gross receipts. 
    The fee schedule for the license required by this article shall be based upon gross receipts in accordance with the following schedule: 
Gross Receipts Amount Tax $ 0 -  24,999 $10.00  25,000 -  49,999 20.00 50,000 - 199,999 30.00 200,000 - 499,999 40.00 500,000 and over 50.00  
(Code 1970, § 10-6) 
Sec. 6-25. - Same-Occupations and businesses exempt from fees based on gross receipts. 
    The occupations and businesses named in this section and required to obtain a license under the provisions of this article are exempt from the gross receipts provisions of this article. The license fee schedule for such occupations and businesses is as follows: 
(1)  Fortunetellers, clairvoyants, spiritualists, palmists and phrenologists, whether or not admissions are charged and not for the benefit of charity, one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day; 
(2)  Carnivals and circuses, fifty dollars ($50.00) per day; 
(3)  Itinerant merchants, as established in Article VII of this chapter; 
(4)  Exchange telephone service companies, as established in Article III of this chapter. 
(Code 1970, § 10-7) 
Sec. 6-26. - Branch offices. 
    For purposes of obtaining a license as required by this article, one (1) license shall be required for the main office and one (1) license each shall be required for each branch office, warehouse and/or any structure used in the operation of the business or "conditional use permit." 
(Code 1970, § 10-8; Ord. No. 5510, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Sec. 6-27. - Inspection and audit of records of licenses. 
    The city, through its auditor or other authorized personnel, shall be permitted to make an inspection and audit of the records of any licensee for the purpose of determining the correctness of the licensee's application for a license required by this article. Such information is privileged, however, and such personnel are not permitted to divulge such information, except in a court proceeding brought to collect the tax provided for in this article. 
(Code 1970, § 10-12) 
Sec. 6-28. - Denial, revocation or suspension-Generally. 
(a)  The city manager is hereby granted the authority to deny a license required by this article to an applicant who fails to comply with the provisions of this article and to revoke or suspend a license to a licensee who is in violation of any of the provisions of section 6-20. 
(b)  If the city manager denies a license, he shall give written notice to the applicant stating the reasons for such denial and the right to appeal to the council. 
(c)  If the city manager suspends or revokes a license, he shall give written notice to the licensee fifteen (15) days in advance of the day his decision shall take effect, stating the reasons for his decision and advising the licensee of his right to appeal to the council. Mailing of the notice to the address of the licenseholder as shown on the license or application by certified mail, personal service of the notice upon the licensee or applicant or the posting of the notice on the front door of the licensee's business shall be considered as delivery of notice. 
(d)  Any licensee who holds a valid unexpired license shall not be denied the right to do business during the period of appeal. 
(Ord. No. 3529, § 3(10-10(C)-(F)), 5-7-85) 
Sec. 6-29. - Same-Appeal. 
(a)  An applicant for a license required by this article who has been refused a license or any licensee whose license has been suspended or revoked shall have the right to appeal the decision of the city manager to the council by giving notice to the council within ten (10) days after the receipt of notice of refusal, suspension or revocation. 
(b)  The council shall, as soon as possible but not earlier than the next regular council meeting, hold a hearing concerning the basis of the decision of the city manager to refuse a license or to suspend or revoke a license. The council shall, after hearing, make a decision to confirm or reverse the decision of the city manager or make such other decision as the facts shall require in accordance with the provisions of this article and the ordinances of the city. The decision of the council shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 3529, § 4(10-11), 5-7-85) 
Secs. 6-30-6-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXCHANGE TELEPHONE SERVICE COMPANIES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5287, § 1, adopted Apr. 20, 2006, amended Art. III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. III, §§ 6-41-6-43 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1970, §§ 10-13-10-15. 
State Law reference- Municipal license tax on telephone companies, RSMo 94.110; municipal regulation of telephone rates, RSMo 77.490. 

Sec. 6-41. - Definition. 
    As used in this article, the term "gross receipts" means the aggregate amount of all sales and charges, exclusive of sales and charges for the commodities or services relative to the business of supplying telephone or telephone service for compensation in the city during the period, less credits, refunds, sales taxes, and uncollectible accounts actually charged off during the period. Effective July 1, 2006, to the extent required by RSMo 92.083, as used in this article: 
(a)  The term "gross receipts" shall be construed to mean all receipts from the retail sale of telecommunications service taxable under RSMo 144.020, and from any retail customer now or hereafter exempt from state sales tax; and 
(b)  The terms "telephone service", "telecommunications service", "telecommunications", "local exchange service", "local exchange telephone transmission service", "exchange telephone service", and similar terms shall be construed to mean telecommunications service as defined in RSMo 92.077, which as of the date of adoption hereof provides that "telecommunications service" has the same meaning as such term is defined in RSMo 144.010, which in turn as of the date of adoption hereof provides that "telecommunications service" means the transmission of information by wire, radio, optical cable, coaxial cable, electronic impulses, or other similar means, further provides that as used in this definition, "information" means knowledge or intelligence represented by any form of writing, signs, signals, pictures, sounds, or any other symbols, and further provides that "telecommunications service" does not include the following if such services are separately stated on the customer's bill or on records of the seller maintained in the ordinary course of business: 
(1)  Access to the Internet, access to interactive computer services or electronic publishing services, except the amount paid for the telecommunications service used to provide such access; 
(2)  Answering services and one-way paging services; 
(3)  Private mobile radio services which are not two-way commercial mobile radio services such as wireless telephone, personal communications services or enhanced specialized mobile radio services as defined pursuant to federal law; or 
(4)  Cable or satellite television or music services. The phrase "to the extent required by law" shall mean that the action is required or permitted by state law in order for the city to continue to receive municipal telecommunications tax revenues under this article. 
(Ord. No. 5287, § 1, 4-20-06) 
Sec. 6-42. - Tax levied. 
    Every person now or hereafter engaged in the business of selling telephone or telegraph service, for compensation for any purpose in the city, shall pay to the city, as a license or occupation tax, 1.3 percent of the gross receipts from such business in the city. To the extent required by law, the city manager of the city is hereby authorized and directed to promulgate and publish the revenue neutral rates to be applied in the City of Cameron for bills to be rendered on or after July 1, 2006, based on the rate information supplied by the Director of Revenue of the State of Missouri. Effective July 1, 2006, to the extent required by law, notwithstanding the provisions of any municipal business license tax (as defined in RSMo 92.077) ordinance, this tax shall be based solely and exclusively on those gross receipts of telecommunications companies (being any company doing business in the State of Missouri that provides telecommunications service) for the retail sale of telecommunications services which are subject to taxation under RSMo 144.010 and 144.020. To the extent required or permitted by law, for bills rendered on and after July 1, 2006, the tax rate shall be 1.3 percent or the revenue neutral rates as promulgated and published herein, whichever is higher. To the extent required by law, for bills rendered on and after July 1, 2007 the tax rate shall be adjusted as promulgated and published by the Director of the Department of Revenue for the State of Missouri pursuant to RSMo 92.086. The city shall notify the Director of the Department of Revenue in writing within thirty (30) days of any change in the tax rate to the extent required by RSMo 92.086. 
(Ord. No. 5287, § 1, 4-20-06) 
Sec. 6-43. - Statement of gross receipts required; payment of tax; credit for service rendered city. 
    All persons engaged in the businesses described in sections 6-41 and 6-42 in the city are hereby required to file with the city manager a sworn statement showing the gross receipts of such business within the city. For the business transacted and the gross receipts each month, a statement shall be due and filed by the last day of the following month. At the same time the statement is required to be filed, payment of the tax due on the gross receipts reported in the statement shall be made to the City of Cameron at the rate set forth in section 6-42. The payment shall be a license to operate for the month immediately succeeding the month in which the payment is made. Effective July 1, 2006, to the extent required by law the Director of the Department of Revenue for the State of Missouri shall collect, administer, and distribute telecommunications business license tax revenues in accordance with the provisions of RSMo 92.074 to 92.098 and returns filed by telecommunications companies with the director and tax payments made by such companies to the director pursuant to such statutes shall take the place of the statements and payments described above. 
(Ord. No. 5287, § 1, 4-20-06) 
Sec. 6-44. - Tax to be in lieu of other occupation taxes. 
    The tax required to be paid under section 6-42 shall be in lieu of any other occupation tax required of any person engaged in any of the businesses described in sections 6-41 and 6-42. Except as otherwise required by RSMo 92.074 to 92.098, nothing contained in this article shall be construed to exempt any person to which this article is applicable from payment to the city of any taxes, other than occupation license taxes, levied by the city upon such person or the real or personal property of such person. 
(Ord. No. 5287, § 1, 4-20-06) 
Sec. 6-45. - Investigation of gross receipts statement. 
    The city manager and such other persons may be designated by the city council, from time to time, is and are hereby authorized to investigate the correctness and accuracy of any statement filed under the provisions of section 6-43, and for that purpose shall have access at all reasonable times to the books, documents, papers and records of any person filing such statement. Effective July 1, 2006, any audit of a telecommunications company for purposes of RSMo 92.074 to 92.098 shall be conducted pursuant to such statutes and any rules promulgated thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 5287, § 1, 4-20-06) 
Sec. 6-46. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Any person engaged in any of the businesses described in sections 6-41 and 6-42 who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-9, General Penalty of this Code. 
(b)  Delinquent taxes under this article shall be subject to the penalties as provided for by other ordinances of the city, now or hereafter enacted, relating to penalties upon delinquent taxes. 
(c)  To the extent required by law, unless specifically stated otherwise in RSMo 92.074 to 92.098, taxpayer remedies, enforcement mechanisms, tax refunds, tax protests, assessments, and all other procedures regarding the tax imposed by this article shall be the same as those provided in RSMo Chapter 144. 
(Ord. No. 5287, § 1, 4-20-06) 
Sec. 6-47 - Construction. 
    To the extent required by law, in all respects this article shall be interpreted, construed and applied consistent with the requirements of RSMo 92.074 to 92.098. 
(Ord. No. 5287, § 1, 4-20-06) 
Secs. 6-48-6-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - JUNK AND SALVAGE YARDS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Refuse, § 5-31 et seq. 
State Law reference- Junkyard near interstate or primary highway, RSMo 226.650 et seq.; motor vehicle salvage businesses, RSMo 301.217 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Junkyard means any yard, premises or tract of land in or upon which junk, old iron, pipe, secondhand material of metal, wood or rock, worn or discarded material of any kind, surplus brass, copper or other metals or empty bottles are stored for the purpose of wrecking, resale or reuse. 
    Salvage yard means any yard, premises or tract of land in or upon which nonoperating motor vehicles are stored or upon which motor vehicles are wrecked or dismantled for the purpose of wrecking or salvage. 
(Ord. No. 3532, § 10-20, 5-21-85) 
State Law reference- "Junk" and "junkyard" defined, RSMo 226.660. 
Sec. 6-62. - Compliance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to carry on, maintain or conduct a salvage yard or junkyard unless such establishment is carried on, maintained or conducted in compliance with the provisions of this article and article II of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3532, § 10-22, 5-21-85) 
Sec. 6-63. - Prohibited in residential areas. 
    No junkyard or salvage yard shall be allowed in the residential areas of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3532, § 10-21(E), 5-21-85) 
Sec. 6-64. - Access for inspections. 
    The material located in or on the premises of a salvage yard shall be so arranged that reasonable inspection of or access to all parts of the premises can be had at any time by the proper fire, health, police and building authorities. 
(Ord. No. 3532, § 10-29, 5-21-85) 
Sec. 6-65. - Fences, screening and enclosures-Required. 
    Every junkyard or salvage yard shall be carried on, maintained or conducted entirely inside an enclosed building or upon premises fenced on all sides. 
(Ord. No. 3532, § 10-23, 5-21-85) 
Sec. 6-66. - Same-Construction requirements in certain zoning districts. 
    Such fence required for junkyards or salvage yards by section 6-65, in a C-1 or C-2 zoned area, shall be at least eight (8) feet high and shall be of solid wood or metal or woven wire of at least 10-gauge line wire and 121/2-gauge filler or stay. If such fence is of wire, a sufficient number of shrubs or trees shall be planted along the fence to screen the premises from view. Property separated from the salvage yard by only a street, alley, easement or public way shall be considered as abutting or adjoining such salvage yard. A fence in an M-1 zoned area shall be the same as for a C-1 or C-2 zoned area except the fence shall not be required to have shrubs, trees, fillers or stays as a screen unless such business is within three hundred (300) feet of a residentially zoned area. 
(Ord. No. 3532, § 10-23, 5-21-85) 
Sec. 6-67. - Same-Maintenance. 
    The fence, wall, shrubbery or trees required by section 6-66 shall be maintained in a neat, substantially safe condition. A fence or wall shall be painted unless constructed of masonry, rust-proof metal or wire. 
(Ord. No. 3532, § 10-24, 5-21-85) 
Sec. 6-68. - Density of motor vehicles. 
    The density of motor vehicles on a salvage yard shall not exceed one (1) vehicle for each two hundred (200) square feet of land or floor area. However, the owner of any salvage yard that had a greater density of vehicles in the salvage yard on May 21, 1985, shall not be required to move any vehicles but shall not be permitted to place any more vehicles in the salvage yard until such time as it can be done without exceeding the density of one (1) vehicle per two hundred (200) square feet. No vehicles or material shall be stacked above the top of the fence required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 3532, § 10-27, 5-21-85) 
Sec. 6-69. - Removal of gasoline from vehicles. 
    All gasoline shall be drained and removed from any unregistered motor vehicle or other object to be junked or wrecked and located in a building or on the premises of a salvage yard. 
(Ord. No. 3532, § 10-28, 5-21-85) 
Sec. 6-70. - Vermin, rodents, reptiles and animals. 
    The salvage yard or junkyard shall be kept free from vermin, rodents, reptiles and animals of all kinds other than properly licensed dogs and cats. 
(Ord. No. 3532, § 10-26, 5-21-85) 
Cross reference- Animals, § 5-71 et seq. 
Sec. 6-71. - Accumulation of water. 
    Water shall not be permitted to accumulate in any junkyard, salvage yard or on car bodies until it becomes vile or stagnant. 
(Ord. No. 3532, § 10-25, 5-21-85) 
Sec. 6-72. - Weeds and vegetation. 
    Weeds and rank vegetation shall not be permitted on the premises of any junkyard or salvage yard. 
(Ord. No. 3532, § 10-25, 5-21-85) 
Secs. 6-73-6-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 6-91. - Required. 
    No person shall operate a junkyard or salvage yard within the city limits without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Ord. No. 3532, § 10-21(A), 5-21-85) 
State Law reference- Power of city to collect a license tax on all vocations, RSMo 94.110. 
Sec. 6-92. - Petition from property owners in certain zoning districts. 
    Any person desiring to obtain a license for a junkyard or salvage yard within the C-1 central zoned area or C-2 general commercial zoned area of the city must present to the council a petition signed by two-thirds of the property owners whose property abuts on the street or cross-street and within one thousand (1,000) feet of such proposed junkyard or salvage yard. 
(Code 1970, § 13-24; Ord. No. 3532, § 10-21(D), 5-21-85) 
Sec. 6-93. - Issuance. 
    Each license required by this division for a junkyard or salvage yard shall be issued by the council. 
(Ord. No. 3532, § 10-21(B), 5-21-85) 
Sec. 6-94. - Applicability of other provisions. 
    The license fee and regulations of article II of this chapter shall apply equally to a license obtained under this division. 
(Ord. No. 3532, § 10-21(C), 5-21-85) 
Secs. 6-95-6-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, adopted Feb. 16, 2010, repealed the former Art. V, §§ 6-111-6-186, and enacted a new Art. V as set out herein. The former Art. V pertained to similar subject matter. For a complete derivation of the former provisions, see the Code Comparative Table of this Code. 
State Law reference- Liquor Control Law, RSMo 311.010 et seq.; municipal licensing and regulation of liquor, RSMo 311.220 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-111. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Drinking establishment means any premises that sells, or makes available, intoxicating liquor by the drink. 
    Intoxicating liquor means and includes alcohol for beverage purposes, alcoholic, spirituous, vinous, fermented, malt or other liquors or combination of liquors, a part of which is spirituous, vinous or fermented and all preparations or mixtures for beverage purposes, containing in excess of one-half (1/2) of one (1) percent by volume. All beverages having an alcoholic content of less than one half (1/2) of one (1) percent by volume shall be exempt from provisions of this chapter, but subject to inspection as provided by RSMo 196.365 to 196.445. 
    Malt liquor means that intoxicating liquor manufactured from pure hops or pure extract of hops or pure barley malt or wholesome grains or cereals and wholesome yeast and pure water, containing in excess of three and two-tenths (3.2) percent of alcohol by weight but not in excess of five (5) percent by weight and commonly called and known as beer. 
    Managing officer means the person who is in active management and control, who may be designated by the corporation as the managing officer. 
    Original package means at least one (1) container of not less than eight (8) ounces of intoxicating liquor generally; three (3) or more standard bottles, cans or containers of malt liquor; or any package containing three (3), six (6), twelve (12) or twenty-four (24) small standard beer bottles. 
    Restaurant bar means any establishment having a restaurant or similar facility on the premises at least fifty (50) percent of the gross income of which is derived from the sale of prepared meals or food consumed on such premises or which has an annual gross income of at least two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) from the sale of prepared meals or food consumed on such premises. 
    Wine means light wine containing not in excess of fourteen (14) percent of alcohol by weight made exclusively from grapes, berries and other fruits and vegetables. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
State Law reference- "Intoxicating liquor" defined, RSMo 311.020; "original package" defined, RSMo 311.200(2); contents of malt liquor and wine, RSMo 311.090. 
Sec. 6-112. - Applicability of article to sales of intoxicating liquor by the drink. 
    Nothing contained in this article is intended to authorize or permit the sale of intoxicating liquor by the drink other than malt liquor and wine. If the sale of intoxicating liquor other than malt liquor and wine becomes lawful and is otherwise permitted by law, then the provisions of this article pertaining to the sale of intoxicating liquor shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
Sec. 6-113. - Time fixed for opening and closing premises; closed place defined; penalty. 
(a)  No person having a license under this article, nor any employee of such person, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, shall sell, give away, or otherwise dispose of, or suffer the same be done upon or about his/her premises, any intoxicating liquor in any quantity between the hours of 1:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on weekdays and between the hours of 1:30 a.m. Sunday and 6:00 a.m. Monday. If the person has a license to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink, his/her premises shall be and remain a closed place as defined in this section between the hours of 1:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on weekdays and between the hours of 1:30 a.m. Sunday and 6:00 a.m. Monday. Where such licenses authorizing the sale of intoxicating liquor by the drink are held by clubs or hotels, this section shall apply only to the room or rooms in which intoxicating liquor is dispensed; and where such licenses are held by restaurants whose business is conducted in one (1) room only and substantial quantities of food and merchandise, other than intoxicating liquors are dispensed, then the licensee shall keep securely locked during the hours and on the days specified in this section all refrigerators, cabinets, cases, boxes, and taps from which intoxicating liquor is dispensed. A "closed place" is defined to mean a place where all doors are locked and where no patrons are in the place or about the premises. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the sale or delivery of any intoxicating liquor during any of the hours or on the days specified in this section by a wholesaler to a person licensed to sell the intoxicating liquor at retail. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be deemed guilty of a class A misdemeanor. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the sale or delivery of any intoxicating liquor during any of the hours or on any of the days specified in this section by a wholesaler licensed under the provisions of this section to a person licensed to sell the intoxicating liquor at retail. 
(b)  Any person licensed pursuant to section 6-153 shall not be permitted to sell, give away, or otherwise dispose of or suffer the same to be done upon or about his/her premises, any intoxicating liquor in any quantity between the hours of 1:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on weekdays and between the hours of 1:30 a.m. Sunday and 6:00 a.m. Monday. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.290. 
Sec. 6-114. - Drinking in public. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drink or encourage another to drink or open any container or any original package containing intoxicating liquor, malt liquor or wine in or upon any public street, alley, sidewalk, park or public thoroughfare of the city or in any railway station, bus station, theater, picture show house, bus, taxi or other public conveyance or in any public school building or church. 
(b)  Insofar as subsection (a) of this section applies, it shall be considered evidence of drinking for a person to have in his/her possession an open bottle, can or other open container of intoxicating liquor, malt liquor or wine. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
Sec. 6-115. - Drinking in public allowed. 
(a)  During council approved events [dates and times to be determined by council], malt liquor, wine and intoxicating liquor, as defined by section 6-111, may be sold and consumed during the hours of opening and closing of premises established by section 6-113 by licensed vendors at the location(s) [to be determined by council], where sale and consumption shall not constitute a violation of section 6-114, drinking in public. 
(b)  Operation of a "malt liquor garden" on said premises shall not constitute a violation of section 6-114, drinking in public nor shall it constitute a violation of section 6-116, premises open to public view; obstructing or obscuring interior, each of which said ordinances shall otherwise remain in full force and effect but for the location(s) and date(s) as determined by council. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10; Ord. No. 5599, §§ 1, 2, 5-17-10; Ord. No. 5600, § 2, 5-17-10; Ord. No. 5655, § 1, 4-4-11; Ord. No 5764, § 1, 2, 3-4-13; Ord. No. 5780, § 1, 6-3-13; Ord. No. 6069, § 1, 4-15-19) 
Sec. 6-116. - Premises open to public view; obstructing or obscuring interior. 
(a)  The room or premises where intoxicating liquor, malt liquor or wine is sold at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises, shall be open to public view. 
(b)  No person shall sell intoxicating liquor by the drink for consumption on the premises in any place commonly known as a saloon, nor in any building or room where there are blinds, screens, swinging doors, curtains or any other thing in such building or room that will obstruct or obscure the interior of such room from public view. 
(c)  Operation of such premises in violation of the provisions of this section shall be unlawful. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
Sec. 6-117. - Opening original package where purchased. 
(a)  In no event shall intoxicating liquor sold in the original package be opened or consumed on the premises where purchased. 
(b)  In no event shall malt liquor or wine sold in the original package be opened or consumed on the premises where purchased when the licensee is not licensed to do so as classified under section 6-142. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
Sec. 6-118. - Covering stock when premises open during hours sales prohibited. 
    All persons holding an intoxicating liquor, malt liquor or wine original package sales license under this article, whose places of business remain open on the days and at the hours when the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages are prohibited by section 6-113, shall at all times on such days and at such hours, keep all intoxicating liquor, malt liquor or wine under cover in such a manner that such beverage stocks cannot be removed without being uncovered. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
Sec. 6-119. - Unauthorized liquor on premises licensed for sale by the drink. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee for the sale of any intoxicating liquor, malt liquor or wine at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold to keep or secrete or to allow any other person to keep or secrete in or upon the premises described in the license required by this article any intoxicating liquor, malt liquor or wine other than the kind of liquor expressly authorized to be sold by such licensee. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
State Law reference- Unauthorized liquors on premises licensed for sale by the drink, RSMo 311.330. 
Sec. 6-120. - Right of entry of police; seizure of unlawful objects. 
    The police chief or his authorized agent or any member of the police department shall have the right, at any time, to inspect any premises holding a license under this article, to manufacture or sell intoxicating liquor, malt liquor or wine and to seize any and all objects which may appear to be in violation of any provisions of this article and to hold in custody such objects as evidence until any matter pertaining to such violation is finally adjudicated. Upon such seizure, a receipt shall be given and, upon demand, objects shall be returned to their original owner after the matter is finally adjudicated. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
State Law reference- Search and seizure under the Liquor Control Law, RSMo 311.810 et seq. 
Secs. 6-121-6-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 6-141. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or expose for sale any intoxicating liquor, malt liquor or wine in any quantity without first obtaining a license therefor from the city. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
Sec. 6-142. - Classes/Fees established. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following classes of licenses are hereby created: 
License Fee 
(a)  For the sale of intoxicating liquor, malt liquor or wine in the original package: OPL-Original Package Liquor ..... $150.00 
(b)  For the sale of malt liquor or wine in the original package: 5OP-Original Package 5% Beer, (includes Sunday) ..... 75.00 
(c)  For the sale of malt liquor or wine 5% by the drink and in the original package: 5BD-5% By Drink (includes Sunday sales) ..... 75.00 
(d)  For sale of malt liquor and light wines containing not in excess of fourteen (14) percent of alcohol by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold: 5BDW-5% By Drink Wine ..... 75.00 
(e)  For the sale of intoxicating liquor for consumption on premises where sold issued to church, school, civic, service, fraternal, veteran, political or charitable club or organization: RBDP-Retail Liquor By Drink Picnic ..... 37.50 
(f)  For the sale of malt liquor or wine by the drink, at retail, for consumption on the premises where sold when the gross income derived from the sale of prepared meals or food consumed on the premises is at least seventy-five (75) percent of total sales: RBDR-Retail Liquor By the Drink Resort ..... 450.00 
(g)  For the sale of all intoxicating liquor, in the original package at retail, on Sunday: SOP-Sunday Original Package Liquor ..... 300.00 
(h)  For the sale of intoxicating liquor on Sunday by the drink at retail for consumption on the premises of any restaurant bar: SBD-Sunday By the Drink ..... 300.00 
(i)  To allow tasting on premises-limitations: OPT-Original Package Tasting ..... 37.50 
(j)  For the sale of liquor by the drink, cities, requirements-Sunday sales authorized for certain organizations: RBDE-Retail Liquor By the Drink Exempt ..... 450.00 
Sunday license ..... 300.00 
(k)  To allow consumption on premises-limitations: COL-Consumption of Intoxicating Liquor ..... 90.00 
(l)  Temporary location for liquor by the drink, caterers-permit: RBDC-Retail Liquor By Drink Caterer ..... 15.00 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
Sec. 6-143. - Qualifications for licenses-Resident corporation and financial interest defined. 
(a)  No person shall be granted a license hereunder unless such person is of good moral character and a qualified legal voter and a taxpaying citizen of the county, town, city or village, nor shall any corporation be granted a license hereunder unless the managing officer of such corporation is of good moral character and a qualified legal voter and taxpaying citizen of the county, town, city or village; and no person shall be granted a license or permit hereunder whose license as such dealer has been revoked, or who has been convicted, since the ratification of the Twenty-First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States, of a violation of the provisions of any law applicable to the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquor, or who employs in his or her business as such dealer any person whose license has been revoked or who has been convicted of violating such law since the date aforesaid; provided, that nothing in this section contained shall prevent the issuance of licenses to nonresidents of Missouri or foreign corporations for the privilege of selling to duly licensed wholesalers and soliciting orders for the sale of intoxicating liquors to, by or through a duly licensed wholesaler, within this state. 
(b)  (1)  No person, partnership or corporation shall be qualified for a license under this law if such person, any member of such partnership, or such corporation, or any officer, director, or any stockholder owning, legally or beneficially, directly or indirectly, ten (10) percent or more of the stock of such corporation, or other financial interest therein, or ten (10) percent or more of the interest in the business for which the person, partnership or corporation is licensed, or any person employed in the business licensed under this law shall have had a license revoked under this law or shall have been convicted of violating the provisions of any law applicable to the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquor since the ratification of the Twenty-First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States, or shall not be a person of good moral character. 
(2)  No license issued under this chapter shall be denied, suspended, revoked or otherwise affected based solely on the fact that an employee of the licensee has been convicted of a felony unrelated to the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquor. Each employer shall report the identity of any employee convicted of a felony to the division of liquor control. The division of liquor control shall promulgate rules to enforce the provisions of this subdivision. 
(3)  A "resident corporation" is defined to be a corporation incorporated under the laws of this state, all the officers and directors of which, and all the stockholders, who legally and beneficially own or control sixty (60) percent or more of the stock in amount and in voting rights, shall be qualified legal voters and taxpaying citizens of the county and municipality in which they reside, and who shall have been bona fide residents of the state for a period of three (3) years continuously immediately prior to the date of filing of application for a license, provided that a stockholder need not be a voter or a taxpayer, and all the resident stockholders of which shall own, legally and beneficially, at least sixty (60) percent of all the financial interest in the business to be licensed under this law; provided, that no corporation, licensed under the provisions of this law on January 1, 1947, nor any corporation succeeding to the business of a corporation licensed on January 1, 1947, as a result of a tax-free reorganization coming within the provisions of Section 112, United States Internal Revenue Code, shall be disqualified by reason of the new requirements herein, except corporations engaged in the manufacture of alcoholic beverages containing alcohol in excess of five (5) percent by weight, or owned or controlled, directly or indirectly, by nonresident persons, partnerships or corporations engaged in the manufacture of alcoholic beverages containing alcohol in excess of five (5) percent by weight. 
(4)  The term "financial interest" as used in this chapter is defined to mean all interest, legal or beneficial, direct or indirect, in the capital devoted to the licensed enterprise and all such interest in the net profits of the enterprise, after the payment of reasonable and necessary operating business expenses and taxes, including interest in dividends, preferred dividends, interest and profits, directly or indirectly paid as compensation for, or in consideration of interest in, or for use of, the capital devoted to the enterprise, or for property or money advanced, loaned or otherwise made available to the enterprise, except by way of ordinary commercial credit or bona fide bank credit not in excess of credit customarily granted by banking institutions, whether paid as dividends, interest or profits, or in the guise of royalties, commissions, salaries, or any other form whatsoever. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.060 
Sec. 6-144. - Application contents. 
    The applicant for a license required by this division shall file with the council a verified and acknowledged petition for a license, on a form to be furnished by the city clerk, setting forth the following: 
(a)  Full name; age; residence; place of birth; if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of naturalization; the length of time the applicant has resided at the residence stated; whether he is a registered voter and assessed taxpaying citizen at the residence stated; a copy of applicant's criminal history record information from the Missouri State Highway Patrol, Criminal Records Division; whether or not applicant has ever been convicted of a felony or a violation of any law regulating, controlling or prohibiting the sale of intoxicating liquor; whether or not applicant has ever been engaged in the manufacture or sale or distribution of intoxicating liquor or malt liquor, and, if so, when, where and the nature of the business. If the applicant is a corporation, the petition shall set forth all of the information required in this subsection with respect to its managing officer of the proposed establishment, identifying such officer and further stating the corporate name, the date and state of incorporation and the five (5) largest stockholders with their addresses and the percentage of stock held by each; 
(b)  Whether or not any distiller, wholesaler, wine maker, brewer or any employee, officer or agent of any such person has any financial interest or proposes to have any financial interest in the retail business for the sale of intoxicating liquor or malt liquor for which such applicant applied for a license; whether or not any such person, either directly or indirectly, has loaned, given or furnished or will give, loan or furnish any equipment, money, credit or property of any kind to such applicant except ordinary commercial credit for liquor sold to such applicant; and the names of all persons, directly or indirectly, financially interested in the proposed business of the applicant; 
(c)  The exact location of the place or premises where the applicant proposes to engage in such retail liquor business, including the street address of the premises, the name and address of the owner of record of the premises and the land upon which the building is situated and the correct legal description of the premises; 
(d)  The kind of business which the applicant proposes to conduct in such premises, particularly stating the hours which the applicant plans to keep his/her place open for business of any kind; 
(e)  Such other and additional information as the city clerk may require. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10; Ord. 5820, § 1, 3-17-14) 
Sec. 6-145. - Investigation of application and premises. 
(a)  Each new application for a license required by this article shall be submitted to the chief of police, the chief of the fire department, the building inspector and if applicable, the special events committee, who, through their duly authorized agents or employees or through such other departments or persons who may from time to time be designated by the council, shall make an immediate investigation of the statements contained in the petition and of the safety of the premises, sanitary conditions of the premises, impact on existing businesses in the area, and impact on the youth and citizens in general of the community and a verbal report of the findings of such investigations shall be made to the council. 
(b)  After a new application has been made and a license issued under this division, the council may, at any reasonable time, request a new investigation of the licensee or of the premises or both, and the results of such subsequent investigation shall be reported to the council. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
Sec. 6-146. - Special event liquor license guidelines. 
(a)  These guidelines are for events expected to or which have the potential to draw fifty (50) or more persons to the event. In particular, these guidelines pertain to any social event where alcohol/liquor is being sold and/or consumed at a specific, confined, designated location. This is to include any event issued a liquor license by the City of Cameron and the State of Missouri. 
(b)  Applicants must comply with all local, state and federal alcohol/liquor laws, current building codes, city ordinances, licenses and requirements. Applicants shall be required to obtain an occupation license with the City of Cameron. 
(c)  The City of Cameron and the Cameron Police Department reserve the right to immediately revoke the liquor license and/or terminate the event if the situation escalates to a level that is not controllable or safe for the guests. 
(d)  The liquor license applicant and/or the event sponsor will be reviewed by a special events committee which will consist of the Cameron City Manager, Cameron Police Chief, and a citizen of the community appointed by the city council. Incidents at prior events hosted by the applicant and/or sponsor will be used to determine the applicant's eligibility for a liquor license by the special events committee. The special events committee will not issue liquor licenses on behalf of the City of Cameron. The special events committee will review the special event after they receive the application for the liquor license. The special events committee's goal is to work with the applicant to ensure the safety of our citizens and persons attending the event. There will be no fee applied to the applicant by the special events committee. 
(e)  Some special events will be determined exempt from the special events committee even though their event may appear to fall under the guidelines. Examples of such events include but are not limited to; golf tournaments, Christmas parties, family reunions, [and] wedding receptions. 
(f)  Liquor license applicants and/or event sponsors shall attend the entire event and shall not consume alcohol. All employees of the liquor license applicant and/or event sponsor must also not consume alcohol. 
(g)  Alcohol servers must meet the minimum age requirement to serve alcohol. They must also be trained to serve alcohol and how to determine if a person has consumed too much alcohol and should not be served. 
(h)  No alcoholic beverages may be brought into the designated drinking areas from outside. 
(i)  A distinguishing form of identification such as colored wrist bands, hand stamps or some other method will be required and must be utilized to easily indicate people who have been properly identified as being eligible to purchase alcohol at the event. Initial identification must be valid and contain the date of birth and photograph of the guest wishing to purchase alcohol at the event. 
(j)  Liquor license applicants and/or the event sponsors will identify any person(s) acting on their behalf as security and/or age identification personnel. These persons shall be clearly discernible to guests and law enforcement officers at the event. (i.e., yellow/orange shirt with security printed and clearly visible on the shirt.) 
(k)  Security personnel/event employees shall immediately notify uniformed officers of all criminal activity witnessed during the event. 
(l)  Security personnel shall notify uniformed officers of guests who need to be removed from the event. At no time shall civilian security personnel be allowed to physically remove a guest from the event unless requested to assist a uniformed officer. 
(m)  Mandatory age checkpoint, as well as random age and identification checks, shall be made during the event by the applicant and/or sponsor or their designee(s). 
(n)  Ratio of age identification monitors and guests must be constantly assessed. The ratio shall not exceed fifty (50) guests to one (1) age identification monitor. 
(o)  A safety and security plan shall be developed between the liquor license applicant/sponsor of the event and emergency services (police/fire/EMS/building official) for the City of Cameron. An on-site safety plan will be conducted prior to the event. 
(p)  Two (2) off-duty, uniformed law enforcement officers will be required for any event that has the potential to provide up to fifty (50) guests. This is in addition to any security provided by the liquor license applicant and/or event sponsor. The liquor license applicant and/or the event sponsor must understand that the uniformed law enforcement officers have ultimate authority over the security and safety of the citizens and visitors at the event. In addition, the liquor license applicant and/or the event sponsor will compensate the officers providing security at the event. A suggested breakdown of the officer requirement is listed below: 
(1)  One hundred (100) guests or fewer, two (2) off-duty, uniformed officers. 
(2)  Two hundred (200) to three hundred (300) guests, four (4) off-duty, uniformed officers. 
(3)  Three hundred (300) to four hundred (400) guests, six (6) off-duty, uniformed officers. 
(4)  Four hundred (400) to five hundred (500) guests, eight (8) off-duty, uniformed officers. 
(5)  Five hundred (500) or more guests, the number of officers at an event of this size shall be determined by the special events committee and the liquor license applicant and/or the event sponsor prior to the event. 
(q)  In addition, if injuries and/or fire are possible at the event, the safety plan shall address having a fire truck, ambulance or off-duty emergency medical service crew present at the event. Any expenses associated with these services shall be discussed pre-event and be the responsibility of the liquor license applicant and/or event sponsor. 
(r)  The off-duty, uniformed officers shall be compensated at a rate determined by the City of Cameron at the beginning of the calendar year or a predetermined rate agreed to by the City of Cameron and the liquor license applicant and/or event sponsor. The minimum time charged will be two (2) hours. 
(s)  Applicant/event holders must comply with all current building codes (reference to occupancy loads, restrooms, fire apparatus). 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
Sec. 6-147. - Issuance; term. 
    If the council shall find that the applicant for a license required by this division or, if a corporation, the managing officer, is a person of good moral character, a registered voter and a taxpaying citizen of the city and the county of his/her residence; that no license theretofore issued by the city or the state to the applicant to sell intoxicating liquor or malt liquor has been revoked; that the applicant has not been convicted since the ratification of the Twenty-First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States of the violation of any law applicable to the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquor or malt liquor that the applicant does not employ in his/her business any person whose liquor license has been revoked or who has been convicted of violating the provisions of any law applicable to the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquor or malt liquor since the ratification of the Twenty-First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States; that the applicant plans and proposes to conduct business in compliance with the laws of the state and with this article; and that the premises where the business is to be conducted is safe and sanitary; then the council may authorize the issuance of a letter of approval to the applicant for use in procuring a State of Missouri liquor license. When the applicant presents a state liquor license to the city clerk, the city clerk shall then issue a city liquor license permitting him/her to conduct such business for a term expiring on June thirtieth succeeding the date of issuance of such license unless such license shall be revoked, withdrawn or cancelled before the expiration of such time. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
Sec. 6-148. - Location within certain distance of school, church or place of worship. 
(a)  No city license shall be granted for the sale of intoxicating liquor within one hundred (100) feet, measured from the closest building corner, of any school, church or other building regularly used as a place of religious worship, provided that the provisions of this subsection shall not apply to locations previously licensed by the city on or before August 5, 2003. 
(b)  The provisions of subsection (a) hereof shall not apply in the C-1, Central Business Zoning District, which is hereby, designated an exception to said distance requirement provided the provisions of RSMo 311.080 have been satisfied. This section shall constitute and be deemed as consent in writing by the Cameron City Council as required under the statute, and when the other required consent or consents have been received, and then the license shall be issued in accordance with the statute, which reads as follows: 
311.80. 
(1) No license shall be granted for the sale of intoxicating liquor as defined in this chapter, within one hundred (100) feet of any school, church or other building regularly used as a place of religious worship, unless the applicant for the license shall first obtain the consent in writing of the board of aldermen, city council, or other proper authorities of any incorporated city, town or village, except that when a school, church or place of worship shall hereafter be established within one hundred (100) feet of any such place of business licensed to sell intoxicating liquor, the license shall not be denied for this reason. Such consent shall not be granted until at least ten (10) days' written notice has been provided to all owners of property within one hundred (100) feet of the proposed licensed premises. 
(2) The board of aldermen, city council or other proper authorities of any incorporated city, town or village may by ordinance prohibit the granting of a license for the sale of intoxicating liquor within a distance as great as three hundred (300) feet of any school, church, or other building regularly used as a place of religious worship. In such cases, and where the ordinance has been lawfully enacted, no license of any character shall be issued in conflict with the ordinance while it is in effect; except, that when a school, church or place of worship is established within the prohibited distance from any place of business licensed to sell intoxicating liquor, the license shall not be denied for this reason. 
(3) Subsection (1) of this section shall not apply to a license issued by the supervisor of alcohol and tobacco control for the sale of intoxicating liquor pursuant to RSMo 311.218 or to a license issued to any church, school, civic, service, fraternal, veteran, political, or charitable club or organization which has obtained an exemption from the payment of federal taxes. 
(4) Subsection (1) of this section shall not apply to any premises holding a license issued before January 1, 2004, by the supervisor of alcohol and tobacco control for the sale of intoxicating liquor. To retain a license under this subsection, the licensed premises shall not change license type, amend the legal description, or be without a liquor license for more than ninety (90) days. 
(c)  When a school, church or place of worship is established within the prohibited distance from any place of business licensed to sell intoxicating liquor, the license shall not be denied pursuant to subsection (a) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
State Law reference- Sale of liquor near schools and churches, RSMo 311.080. 
Sec. 6-149. - Separate license for each place of business. 
    A license required by this division shall be required for each place of business operated under this article, whether in the same building or not. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
Sec. 6-150. - More than five (5) licenses by any one person prohibited; exception. 
(a)  No person, corporation, employee, officer, agent, subsidiary, or affiliate thereof, shall: 
(1)  Have more than five (5) licenses; or 
(2)  Be directly or indirectly interested in any business of any other person, corporation, or employee, officer, agent, subsidiary, or affiliate thereof, who sells intoxicating liquor at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises described in any license; or 
(3)  Sell intoxicating liquor at retail by the drink for consumption at the place of sale at more than five (5) places in this state. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter or municipal ordinance to the contrary, for the purpose of determining whether a person, corporation, employee, officer, agent, subsidiary, or affiliate thereof has a disqualifying interest in more than five (5) licenses pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, there shall not be counted any license to sell intoxicating liquor at retail by the drink for consumption on the following premises: 
(1)  Restaurants where at least fifty (50) percent of the gross income of which is derived from the sale of prepared meals or food consumed on the premises where sold; or 
(2)  Establishments which have an annual gross income of at least two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) from the sale of prepared meals or food consumed on the premises where sold; or 
(3)  Facilities designed for the performance of live entertainment and where the receipts for admission to such performances exceed one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per calendar year; or 
(4)  Any establishment having at least forty (40) rooms for the overnight accommodation of transient guests. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.260. 
Sec. 6-151. - Reserved. 
Sec. 6-152. - Sale of liquor by the drink; Sunday sales; authorized for certain organizations. 
(a)  A charitable, fraternal, religious, service or veterans' organization which has obtained an exemption from the payment of federal income taxes as provided in section 501(c)(3), 501(c)(4), 501(c)(5), 501(c)(7), 501(c)(8), 501(c)(10), 501(c)(19), or 501(d) of the United States Internal Revenue Code of 1954 as amended, may apply for, and the city council may issue, a license to sell intoxicating liquor, as defined in this article, by the drink at retail for consumption on the premises. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article to the contrary, any charitable, fraternal, religious, service or veterans' organization which has obtained an exemption from the payment of federal income taxes as provided in section 501(c)(3), 501(c)(4), 501(c)(5), 501(c)(7), 501(c)(8), 501(c)(10), 501(c)(19), or 501(d), of the United States Internal Revenue Code of 1954, as amended, may apply for, and the city council may issue, a license to sell intoxicating liquor, as defined in this article, between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and midnight on Sunday by the drink at retail for consumption on the premises described in the application. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article to the contrary, any person who possess the qualifications required by this article and RSMo 311.097, and who now or hereafter meets the requirements of and complies with the provisions of hereof and thereof, may apply for and the city council may issue a license to sell intoxicating liquor, as defined in this article, between the hours of 9:00 a.m. on Sunday and midnight on Sunday by the drink at retail for consumption on the premises of any restaurant bar described in the application. Applicants for a Sunday restaurant bar license must furnish the city with the application and a verified statement or certificate that the annual gross receipts meet the definition of a restaurant bar. The city council shall have the authority by resolution to order an audit of the books and records of any license holder under this subsection at the expense of the license holder for the purpose of determining if the sales requirements are satisfied. If the results of such audit shall show a violation of the provisions hereof, such license shall be immediately canceled with no rebate for the unused portion thereof. If shall be the burden of the applicant to maintain and produce records establishing, to the reasonable satisfaction of the council, the operation of a restaurant bar. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, RSMo 311.090. 
Sec. 6-153. - Intoxicating liquor package sales. 
(a)  No license shall be issued for the sale of intoxicating liquor in the original package, not to be consumed upon the premises where sold, except to a person engaged in, and to be used in connection with, the operation of one (1) or more of the following businesses: 
(1)  A drug store; 
(2)  A cigar and tobacco store; 
(3)  A grocery store; 
(4)  A general merchandise store; 
(5)  A confectionery or delicatessen store. 
(b)  No such license shall be issued to any such person who does not have and keep in his/her store a stock of goods having a value according to invoices of at least one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), exclusive of fixtures and intoxicating liquors. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.200. 
Sec. 6-153.1. - Wine and malt beverages, permit to allow tasting on premises. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter to the contrary, any person possessing the qualifications and meeting the requirements of this chapter, who is licensed to sell intoxicating liquor in the original package under section 6-142 may apply for a special permit to conduct wine, malt beverage and distilled spirit tastings on the licensed premises. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.294 
Sec. 6-154. - Sale of intoxicating liquor by the drink. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in sections 6-155 and 6-156, if the sale of intoxicating liquor other than malt liquor by the drink becomes lawful within the city, licenses for such sale by the drink under the provisions of subsection 6-142 may be issued to persons whose primary business at the licensed premises is other than the sale of such intoxicating liquor. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section, a business is primarily for other than the sale of intoxicating liquor if sixty (60) percent or more of the gross dollar sales volume of the business is for the sale of food and beverages other than intoxicating liquor, provided that such business has a seating capacity to seat at least one hundred (100) customers in its dining room, and further provided that food is available for sale at all hours that intoxicating liquors are offered for sale at any such building. 
(c)  No license for the sale of intoxicating liquor by the drink shall be issued to any person unless the primary business of such person is other than such sale of intoxicating liquor. 
(d)  It shall be the burden of the applicant to maintain and produce records establishing, to the reasonable satisfaction of the council, that the primary business of such applicant is other than for the sale of intoxicating liquor. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
State Law reference- Sale of liquor by the drink, RSMo 311.090. 
Sec. 6-155. - Sale of malt liquor and wine by the drink. 
(a)  Applicants for licenses for the sale of malt liquor and wine by the drink as classified in section 6-142 shall comply with all of the provisions of this section and with the provisions of this article that are not inconsistent with this section. 
(b)  Licenses shall be issued only to a person whose primary business at the licensed premises is for the sale of prepared meals or food consumed on the premises. 
(c)  Licenses shall be issued only to a person when the gross sales of prepared meals or food and beverages other than malt liquor and wine are seventy-five (75) percent or more of the gross dollar sales volume of such business. 
(d)  Anyone obtaining or holding a license as provided in this division shall have food available for sale at all hours that malt liquor and wine are offered for sale. 
(e)  An applicant for a license provided for in this division must furnish to the council, with the application, a verified statement or a certificate of a certified public accountant showing that at least seventy-five (75) percent of the gross income for the past one (1) year immediately preceding was derived from the sale of prepared meals or food and beverages other than malt liquor and wine consumed on the premises. An applicant who has not been in business one (1) year must verify in his/her application that such business will produce seventy-five (75) percent or more of its gross income from the sale of prepared meals or food and beverages consumed on the premises. The applicant shall then, immediately after ninety (90) days of operation, furnish a verified statement or certificate of a certified public accountant showing that the sale percentage required has been satisfied, and if not, the license will be cancelled with no rebate for the unused portion of the license. 
(f)  The council shall have the authority, by resolution, to order an audit of the books and records of any license holder by a certified public accountant at the expense of the license holder for the purpose of determining if the sales requirements of this section are being satisfied. If the results of such audit shall show a violation of the provisions of this section, such license shall be immediately cancelled with no rebate for the unused portion thereof. 
(Ord. No. 5573, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-10) 
Sec. 6-156. - Sale of liquor by the drink by resorts, seasonal resort restaurants and restaurants. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article to the contrary, any person who possesses the qualifications required by RSMo 311.095, and who now or hereafter meets the requirements of and complies with the provisions of this article, may apply for, and the city council may issue, a license to sell intoxicating liquor, as in this article defined, by the drink at retail for consumption on the premises of any resort as described in the application. 
(b)  As used in this section the term resort means: 
(1)  Any establishment having at least thirty (30) rooms for the overnight accommodation of transient guests and having a restaurant or similar facility on the premises of which at least sixty (60) percent of the gross income is derived from the sale of prepared meals or food; or 
(2)  A restaurant provided with special space and accommodations where, in consideration of payment, food without lodging is habitually furnished to travelers and customers, and which restaurant establishment's annual gross food sales for the past two (2) years immediately preceding its application for a license shall not have been less than seventy-five thousand dollars ($75,000.00) per year; or 
(3)  A seasonal resort restaurant with food sales as determined in subsection (c) of this section; or 
(4)  A new restaurant establishment having been in operation for at least ninety (90) days preceding the application for such license, with a projected experience based upon its sale of food during the preceding ninety (90) days which would exceed not less than seventy-five thousand dollars ($75,000.00) per year. 
(c)  A seasonal resort restaurant is a restaurant which is not a new restaurant establishment which is opened for eight (8) or fewer consecutive months in any calendar year. Fifty (50) percent of all gross sales of such restaurants shall be sales of prepared meals. Any new seasonal resort restaurant establishment having been in operation for less than twelve (12) weeks may be issued a temporary license to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink at retail for consumption on the premises for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days if the seasonal resort restaurant establishment can show a projection for annualized gross sales of which fifty (50) percent shall be sales of prepared meals.
