    Before any permit required by this article shall be issued for making a cut or excavation, the applicant for the permit shall give a bond on a form to be supplied by the city in the penal sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) with two (2) or more good and sufficient sureties or a surety bond in some approved company licensed to do business in the state, conditioned upon the person proposing to make such cut or excavation to hold the city harmless from damages or injury to persons or property by reason of any such cut or excavation and conditioned upon doing the cut or excavation and all work and duties in connection therewith in accordance with the provisions of this article and in a good workmanlike manner, provided that if the person requesting the permit is an owner of real estate in the state and can supply adequate proof of such ownership of a clear value of not less than the amount of the bond, no commercial bond or personal sureties may be required, at the discretion of the city manager, if the owner of such real estate shall sign and execute such bond. 
(Code 1970, § 19-7) 
Sec. 9-30. - Deposits. 
    Before any permit shall be issued under this article for making any cut or excavation, the applicant or someone for the applicant shall deposit with the city clerk a sum of lawful money of the United States sufficient to cover and pay for the cost of refilling, repaving, resurfacing and repairing the street, alley, parkway, curbing or other public place where such work is to be done. Such sum shall be based upon the city's estimate of the cost. The city manager shall have the power and authority to establish, by rule and regulation, estimates and ways for making estimates of such amounts to be so deposited. If no rule or regulation is established at the time application is made for a particular cut or excavation, the estimate shall be made under the supervision and approval of the city manager or other executive head of the city then exercising the city manager's position. Any amount not used by the city in doing the refilling, resurfacing, repaving or repairing work shall be refunded. The city shall keep an accurate and itemized record of the work actually done and the actual cost for each such job it does. 
(Code 1970, § 19-8) 
Sec. 9-31. - Payment of costs exceeding deposit. 
    If the actual cost of resurfacing and repairing including refilling, if done by the city, of the cut or excavation under the requirements of this article exceeds the amount deposited, the person who obtained the permit shall pay the excess cost to the city, and the city shall bring suit, if necessary, to collect the costs. 
(Code 1970, § 19-16) 
Sec. 9-32. - Compliance required. 
    The cutting or excavating of any street, alley, parkway, curbing or other public place shall be done and made in conformity with the application and permit for the cut or excavation and with this article. 
(Code 1970, § 19-9) 
Sec. 9-33. - Manner of work generally. 
    The person doing the cutting or excavating in, through or under any street, alley, sidewalk, street curbing, parkway or other public place shall cause the excavation or cut to be done with the least possible injury to the pavement, sidewalk, curbing, parkway or other surface and shall place the materials from the excavation or cut where they will cause the least possible inconvenience to the public and permit the uninterrupted passage of water along the gutters. The width of the excavation or cutting shall be no greater than is necessary for doing the work. 
(Code 1970, § 19-10) 
Sec. 9-34. - Walkways or driveways. 
    Whenever a person shall excavate the full width of any street, sidewalk, alley, parkway or other public place, it shall be his duty to maintain a substantial walkway or driveway across the excavation or cut until the excavation or cut is refilled and put back in a safe condition. 
(Code 1970, § 19-19) 
Sec. 9-35. - Time for completing work; completion by city. 
    The making and refilling of cuts and excavations under the requirements of this article and the placing or repairing of facilities shall be done as expeditiously as possible, consistent with good construction practice. If the work is not so done, the city shall have the right to perform or cause the remaining work to be done and charge the cost for doing the work against the deposit of the person to whom the permit was issued and shall have the right to recover from such person for any cost in excess of the deposit. 
(Code 1970, § 19-17) 
Sec. 9-36. - Lights and safeguards-Generally. 
    Every person who shall make or cause to be made any cut or excavation as contemplated by this article shall not leave any part or portion of the cut or excavation open and unguarded or in any condition unsafe to persons or property and shall not leave any part or portion of the cut or excavation obstructed with rubbish, building material or other material during the time the work is being done, but such person shall cause the cut or excavation to be enclosed with good, substantial and sufficient barriers not less than three (3) feet high and at nighttime shall cause at least one (1) red light or flare to be securely and conspicuously posted in or near such cut or excavation, building material or obstruction. If the obstruction extends more than eight (8) feet in length but less than sixteen (16) feet, at least two (2) red lights or flares, at least one (1) at each end, shall be so placed. If the length exceeds sixteen (16) feet, an intermediate red light or flare shall be placed between the two (2) end lights and an additional intermediate red light or flare shall be placed for each eight (8) feet of additional length of the cut or excavation, building material or obstruction. When the cut or excavation, building material or obstruction is in the direction of travel, a red light shall be placed at each end. When the cut or excavation, building material or obstruction is as much as twenty (20) feet but less than fifty (50) feet in length and also when it is over fifty (50) feet in length, one (1) intermediate light shall be placed on the cut or excavation, building material or obstruction for each additional fifty (50) feet or fraction thereof. Such person shall keep or cause such lights in all the instances enumerated in this section to be kept burning from sunset to sunrise. 
(Code 1970, § 19-18) 
Sec. 9-37. - Same-Sidewalks. 
    Whenever a cut or excavation as contemplated by this article is made in, through or under a sidewalk, the person to whom the permit was given to make the cut or excavation shall barricade the cut or excavation and place warning lights on the sidewalk and on the barricade or on or near the cut or excavation and shall keep such lights burning from sunset until sunrise until the cut or excavation is refilled and put back in a safe condition. 
(Code 1970, § 19-20) 
Sec. 9-38. - Refilling-Notice. 
    The person making a cut or excavation under the requirements of this article shall notify the city clerk at least three (3) hours prior to the commencement of refilling any cut or excavation. 
(Code 1970, § 19-11) 
Sec. 9-39. - Same-Methods of making. 
    The person making a cut or excavation under the requirements of this article shall refill the cut or excavation as soon as practicable after the cut or excavation is ready for refilling by: 
(1)  Refilling with clean unfrozen earth free from trash, rubbish or rocks over three (3) inches in maximum dimension in layers not exceeding six (6) inches in depth and each layer shall be compacted thoroughly; 
(2)  Refilling with sand to a point eight (8) inches below the surface with clean unfrozen earth for the top eight (8) inches. Such earth shall be thoroughly compacted. 
(Code 1970, § 19-13) 
Sec. 9-40. - Same-Cleaning up and resurfacing. 
    The person doing the cutting or excavating under the requirements of this article shall immediately, after the work is completed and the refill is made, clean up and haul away all surplus earth, rock, debris or other rubbish. The city shall resurface and maintain the cutting or excavation after it is properly refilled. 
(Code 1970, § 19-12) 
Sec. 9-41. - Same-Repairs when defective. 
    If settlement of the cut or excavation required by this article occurs because of defective refill, the city shall have the right to make whatever repairs are required to restore the excavation or cut to a proper condition and to charge the cost thereof to the person to whom the permit was issued and whose duty it was to make a proper refill. Such person shall not be issued another permit until such cost has been paid, and the person may be sued by the city to recover such cost. 
(Code 1970, § 19-14) 
Sec. 9-42. - Same-Work by city; notice; recovery of costs. 
    If an excavation or cut is not refilled within a reasonable time after it is ready for refilling as required by this article, the city clerk shall notify the person to whom the permit was issued that if the cut or excavation is not refilled within six (6) days after date of such notice, it will be refilled by the city and that such person shall be charged for the cost of same. In such an event, if the person fails to make such refill, the city may do it and recover the cost of doing such work by suit, if necessary, from such person. The city shall not issue any additional cut or excavation permit to such person until such cost is paid. 
(Code 1970, § 19-15) 
Secs. 9-43-9-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CEMETERIES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal acquisition of cemetery property, RSMo 77.010; general powers as to cemeteries, RSMo 77.120; conveyance of cemetery lots, RSMo 77.130, 214.030; cemeteries generally, RSMo 214.010 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 9-61. - Deed to burial space. 
    Purchasers of burial spaces in the city's cemeteries shall be entitled, upon the payment of the full purchase price of six hundred dollars ($600.00) for burial space in all city cemeteries, to a deed for the space purchased. Such deed vest in the purchaser, his/her heirs and assigns, a right in fee simple to such space for the sole purpose of sepulcher alone, for human bodies, only, subject to the rules and regulations and ordinances governing the cemeteries. 
(Code 1970, § 6-1; Ord. No. 4079, § 3, 5-19-92; Ord. No. 4766, §§ 1, 3, 6-6-00; Ord. No. 5837, § 2, 8-4-14) 
Sec. 9-62. - Rights of purchaser of burial plot; control of city over cemetery property; compliance with cemetery rules and regulations. 
    The purchaser of a burial plot in the city cemeteries purchases only burial right on that plot; the city reserves control of all the cemetery property. Owners of lots shall abide by and be governed by all the rules and regulations which are now in effect or which may be enacted in the future. 
(Code 1970, § 6-2) 
Sec. 9-63. - Transferability of burial spaces. 
    No transfer or assignment of any burial space in the city or interest in such burial space shall be valid without the consent of the city. 
(Code 1970, § 6-3) 
Sec. 9-64. - Right of city to enter upon lot to work. 
    The city reserves the right to enter upon any cemetery lot and change the surface level thereof to conform with the surrounding ground and to do any such work considered to be for the betterment of the cemeteries as a whole. 
(Code 1970, § 6-4) 
Sec. 9-65. - Liability of city for damages. 
    The city shall take reasonable precautions to protect cemetery lot owners and the property rights of owners within the cemeteries from loss or damage, but the city expressly shall not be liable for loss or damage beyond its control and, particularly, from damage caused by the elements, an act of God, common enemy, thief, vandal and the like, whether the damage is direct or consequential. 
(Code 1970, § 6-5) 
Sec. 9-66. - Fences or enclosures around lots. 
    No fences or enclosures around cemetery lots shall be permitted. 
(Code 1970, § 6-6) 
Sec. 9-67. - Plantings, trees and shrubbery. 
    No planting of any kind is permitted in the cemeteries. The planting of trees and appropriate shrubbery shall be done by the cemetery to harmonize with a general landscaping scheme. 
(Code 1970, § 6-7) 
Sec. 9-68. - Removal of plantings, jugs or bric-a-brac by city. 
    Any plantings, jugs or bric-a-brac of any description placed on any cemetery lot may be removed by the city. 
(Code 1970, § 6-8) 
Secs. 9-69-9-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CEMETERY ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 9-86. - Purpose. 
    The council deems it to the best interests of the city to create a city cemetery advisory board for the purpose of aiding the council and the city manager in administering and improving the city cemeteries. 
(Code 1970, § 6-30) 
Sec. 9-87. - Created, composition, qualifications and terms. 
    There is hereby created a board to be known as the city cemetery advisory board. There shall be five (5) members on the board and all five (5) members shall be qualified residents and voters of the city. Each member shall serve at the pleasure of the council. 
(Code 1970, § 6-31) 
Sec. 9-88. - Duties. 
    The function of the cemetery advisory board shall be advisory only and the board shall advise the council and the city manager with respect to the management, administration and improvement of the city cemeteries. 
(Code 1970, § 6-32) 
Sec. 9-89. - Meetings; officers. 
    The cemetery advisory board shall meet at such times as it deems expedient and reasonable and shall have the privilege of meeting in the council chambers at city hall. The board may organize with a chairman of the board or a president of the board, as it deems fit. 
(Code 1970, § 6-33) 
Secs. 9-90-9-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - INTERMENTS 

Sec. 9-106. - Payment for lot prior to burial. 
    Burials shall not take place on any city cemetery lot until the full purchase price has been paid for the lot. 
(Code 1970, § 6-10) 
Sec. 9-107. - Interments; charges for opening and closing graves. 
Open and close standard grave ..... $500.00 
Open and close standard grave on Saturday ..... 600.00 
Open and close standard grave on Sunday ..... 700.00 
Open and close standard grave on holiday ..... 800.00 
Open and close infant grave ..... 300.00 
Open and close infant grave Saturday/Sunday/holiday ..... 400.00 
Open and close cremation ..... 300.00 
Open and close cremation on Saturday ..... 400.00 
Open and close cremation on Sunday ..... 500.00 
Open and close cremation on holiday ..... 600.00 
(Code 1970, § 6-9; Ord. No. 4079, § 4, 5-19-92; Ord. No. 4766, § 2, 6-6-00; Ord. No. 4901, §§ 1, 2, 1-15-02; Ord. No. 5260, § 1, 1-17-06; Ord. No. 5666, § 1, 5-2-11; Ord. No. 6027, § 1, 5-21-18; Ord. No. 6077, § 1, 5-20-19) 
Sec. 9-108. - Responsibility for arrangements. 
    Arrangements for interments in the city cemeteries shall be made by the owner of the burial space or by members of his family authorized to act in his behalf. 
(Code 1970, § 6-12) 
Sec. 9-109. - Notice to city clerk. 
    Notice of interment in any of the city cemeteries shall be given to the city clerk at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance and preferably forty-eight (48) hours in advance. 
(Code 1970, § 6-13) 
Sec. 9-110. - Documents furnished by funeral directors. 
    Funeral directors shall furnish the city with death certificates, certificates of transit or other evidence of legal right to interment in the city cemeteries as required by the laws of the state. 
(Code 1970, § 6-15) 
State Law reference- Embalmers and funeral directors, RSMo 333.011 et seq. 
Sec. 9-111. - Limitations on interments. 
(1)  There shall be no more than one (1) body buried in one (1) grave space in any of the city cemeteries, except that an infant child may be buried with its mother if the overall height of the infant's casket or vault does not exceed eighteen (18) inches. 
(2)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (1) above, one (1) grave space may be used for the burial of not more than four (4) cremated bodies. 
(3)  As a minimum, all standard interments, i.e. non-cremations, will incorporate the use of a casket in a concrete grave liner with lid in which the casket will be placed. Cremated interments shall incorporate the use of a container approved by the city. 
(Code 1970, § 6-11; Ord. No. 3946, §§ 1, 2, 4-17-90) 
Sec. 9-112. - Work to be done by city. 
    All graves in the city cemeteries shall be dug by the city or its designee as well as all filling, sodding, boxing, mounding or other earth work. 
(Code 1970, § 6-14; Ord. No. 6027, § 2, 5-21-18) 
Sec. 9-113. - Remuneration to lot owners. 
    An owner of any city cemetery lot is forbidden to allow an interment to be made in his lot for any remuneration. 
(Code 1970, § 6-16) 
Sec. 9-114. - Liability for delay; protests. 
    The city shall in no way be liable for any delay in the interment of a body in any city cemetery where a protest to the interment has been made or where the rules and regulations have not been complied with. The city shall be under no duty to recognize any protest of interment unless the protest is in writing and filed in the office of the city manager. 
(Code 1970, § 6-17) 
Sec. 9-115. - Correction of errors by city. 
    The city reserves and shall have the right to correct any errors that may be made by the city in making interments, disinterments or removals and in the description, transfer or conveyance of any interment property. Such errors may be corrected by cancelling such conveyance and substituting and conveying such other property of equal value and similar location as far as is reasonably possible, or as may be selected by the city, or in the sole discretion of the city by refunding the amount of money paid on account of the purchase. If such error shall involve the interment of the remains of any person in such property, the city reserves and shall have the right to remove and transfer such remains so interred to such other property of equal value and similar location as may be reasonably substituted and conveyed in lieu thereof. 
(Code 1970, § 6-18) 
Secs. 9-116-9-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - MONUMENTS, VAULTS, ETC. 
Subdivision I. - Generally 

Sec. 9-131. - Foundations-Required; installation. 
    Monument work and grave markers of every description in the city cemeteries shall have suitable foundations which shall be installed at the lot owner's expense. 
(Code 1970, § 6-20) 
Sec. 9-132. - Same-Specifications; approval by city. 
    All foundations for markers in the city cemeteries shall be prepared with a minimum of thirty (30) inches of concrete. No marker may be set until the foundation has been approved by the city. Failure to comply with this inspection procedure shall result in removal of the marker. 
(Code 1970, § 6-21) 
Sec. 9-133. - Slabs as grave coverings; surface vaults. 
    Slabs of any kind shall not be permitted as coverings for graves in the city cemeteries. Surface vaults shall not be permitted. 
(Code 1970, § 6-22) 
Sec. 9-134. - Graceland Memorial Cemetery monuments. 
    Graceland Memorial Cemetery is a memorial-type cemetery and no monument types shall be allowed except as follows: 
(1)  Monuments shall be made of granite or shall be approved government markers if used for veterans. 
(2)  All monuments shall be flush with the ground surface to allow for complete and unrestricted use of lawn mowing equipment. 
(3)  Monuments for infants of preschool age may be a minimum dimension of ten (10) inches wide and twenty (20) inches long. 
(4)  Monuments shall be a minimum thickness of four (4) inches and shall have a flat-sawed bottom. Except as provided in subsection (3) of this section, single grave markers shall be twenty-eight (28) inches long and eighteen (18) inches wide. Double grave markers shall be forty-eight (48) inches long and eighteen (18) inches wide. 
(Code 1970, § 6-19; Ord. No. 5751, § 1, 12-3-12) 
Sec. 9-135. - Removal of dilapidated, offensive or injurious vaults, tombs or mausoleums. 
    If any vault, tomb, mausoleum or like structure in which a body is entombed in any city cemetery shall fall into a state of dilapidation or decay or shall be determined by the city to be offensive or in any way injurious to the appearance of the cemetery, no adequate provisions having been made by the owner for repair and preservation of such structure, the city shall have the right to remove the structure and to inter any body contained in the structure in the earth of the lot upon which such structure was located, and the city shall maintain such lot thereafter in good and similar condition as done with other lots in the cemetery. 
(Code 1970, § 6-23) 
Secs. 9-136-9-150. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Construction Permit 

Sec. 9-151. - Required; fee. 
    No person shall do any construction work of any kind whatsoever, except opening of graves, nor cause any such work to be done in any city cemetery without first obtaining a permit to do such work from the city clerk or without first paying to the city one dollar ($1.00) for each such permit. 
(Code 1970, § 6-20) 
Sec. 9-152. - Scope of work. 
    The construction work as contemplated by this division shall include, but not be limited to, erecting and placing grave markers in the city cemeteries, erecting and placing of foundations for grave markers and the erecting or placing of any object, except wreaths and flowers, of a permanent nature on any grave lot, but the work shall not include the opening or digging of graves for which no permit or one dollar ($1.00) fee shall be required. 
(Code 1970, § 6-29) 
Sec. 9-153. - Application; issuance. 
    The person desiring to do any construction work as contemplated by this division shall apply for a permit at city hall and the city clerk may issue the permit on a form to be supplied by the city or, if no such form is immediately available, on an informal writing or form; provided, however, that the city clerk shall not issue a permit to do any work or to do anything that is not in conformity, compliance and obedience with or to this Code or other city ordinances. The city shall not be estopped to take any appropriate action if a permit is given to do work forbidden by this Code or other ordinances. 
(Code 1970, § 6-25) 
Sec. 9-154. - Separate for each job; assignability. 
    The permit required in this subdivision shall be for one (1) job or one (1) piece of work only and shall not be assignable. 
(Code 1970, § 6-26) 
Sec. 9-155. - Use by another. 
    No person shall obtain or take out a construction permit required by this subdivision for the purpose of permitting someone else to use the permit. 
(Code 1970, § 6-27) 
Sec. 9-156. - Time for completion of work. 
    The work for which any permit under this subdivision is given shall begin within thirty (30) days from the date of the permit and if the work is not so begun, another permit shall be obtained and paid for before such work may begin or be completed. 
(Code 1970, § 6-28) 
Secs. 9-157-9-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - REGULATIONS FOR LANDS HELD FOR WATERWORKS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3991, adopted Oct. 16, 1990, did not specifically amend the Code and at the discretion of the editor §§ 1-11 have been included herein as Art. IV, §§ 9-201-9-211. 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, Ch. 5; alcoholic beverages, § 6-111 et seq.; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 7; miscellaneous offenses, Ch. 8; water, sewage and electricity, Ch. 12. 

Sec. 9-201. - Motor vehicles and traffic. 
    The provisions of Chapter 7, Motor Vehicles and Traffic, of the Cameron City Code shall apply to all lands held by the city for waterworks purposes. 
(Ord. No. 3991, § 1, 10-16-90) 
Sec. 9-202. - Littering. 
    The provisions of Section 5-32 of the Cameron City Code, Littering, shall apply to all lands held by the city for waterworks purposes. 
(Ord. No. 3991, § 2, 10-16-90) 
Sec. 9-203. - Property damage. 
    The provisions of Section 8-21, Property Damage, of the Cameron City Code shall apply to all lands held by the city for waterworks purposes. 
(Ord. No. 3991, § 3, 10-16-90) 
Sec. 9-204. - Trespassing. 
    The provisions of Section 8-24, Trespassing, of the Cameron City Code shall apply to all lands held by the city for waterworks purposes. 
(Ord. No. 3991, § 4, 10-16-90) 
Sec. 9-205. - Weapons. 
    The provisions of Section 8-32, Weapons-Unlawful Use, of the Cameron City Code shall apply to all lands held by the city for waterworks purposes. 
(Ord. No. 3991, § 5, 10-16-90) 
Sec. 9-206. - Peace disturbance. 
    The provisions of Section 8-37, Peace Disturbance, of the Cameron City Code shall apply to all lands held by the city for waterworks purposes. 
(Ord. No. 3991, § 6, 10-16-90) 
Sec. 9-207. - Alcoholic beverages. 
    The provisions of Section 6-181, Purchase of Possession of Alcoholic Beverages by Persons Under 21 Years of Age, of the Cameron City Code shall apply to all lands held by the city for waterworks purposes. 
(Ord. No. 3991, § 7, 10-16-90) 
Sec. 9-208. - Wading or swimming. 
    No person shall wade or swim in the bodies of water located upon any lands held by the city for waterworks purposes. 
(Ord. No. 3991, § 8, 10-16-90) 
Sec. 9-209. - Operation of motorized vehicle. 
    No person shall operate a motorized vehicle at any place where official signs prohibit the operation of motorized vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 3991, § 9, 10-16-90) 
Sec. 9-210. - Term defined. 
    For the purpose of this article only, the word "city" when used in any of the Code sections referred to above shall have the meaning "Lands held by the city for waterworks purposes." 
(Ord. No. 3991, § 10, 10-16-90) 
Sec. 9-211. - Penalty. 
    The violation of the rules and regulations enacted in this article shall be punished by a fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 3991, § 11, 10-16-90) 
Chapter 10 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings, Ch. 3; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 6; streets, sidewalks and other public property, Ch. 9; trailer coaches, Ch. 11; water, sewage and electricity, Ch. 12; zoning. 
State Law reference- Subdivisions and plats, RSMo 89.400 et seq.; plats generally, RSMo 445.010 et seq. 

Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    Block (Platted block): A piece of land composed of a specified number of lots as set forth in a platted and recorded subdivision, usually specified by an assigned number or letter. Blocks are usually divided into numbered lots. 
    Commission: Cameron Planning and Zoning Commission. 
    Lot (Platted lot): An individual piece of land as shown on the recorded plat of a subdivision, usually specified by an assigned number or letter, several of which may make up a block on said plat. 
    Lot split: Division of a platted lot into not more than two (2) lots, each of which continues to meet minimum frontage and area standards. 
    Minor subdivision: Subdivision of land into no more than five (5) contiguous lots in which no substandard-sized lots nor new streets are created. 
    Owner: Any person or persons, firm or firms, corporation or corporations, or any other legal entity having title to the land. 
    Parcel or tract: All of the contiguous land under single ownership whether single or multiple lots, or a single legal description, or several combined legal descriptions. 
    Plat: A map indicating the subdivision or re-subdivision of land. A plat sets forth the division of land by indicating the size and area of each lot and/or block shown on the plat including streets, easements, setback lines, and other features relevant to the subdivision. A plat is intended to be filed for record or has been filed for record and is usually prepared by a licensed surveyor or engineer. 
    Replat (Amended plat): Any change to a previously-approved and recorded subdivision plat. 
    Resubdivision: A further division of a lot or lots previously included in a recorded plat or subdivision. May include a replat. 
    Right-of-way: A strip of land occupied or intended to be occupied by a street, crosswalk, railroad, electric transmission line, oil or gas pipeline, water main, sanitary or storm sewer main, shade trees or other special use. 
    Street: Any public way. 
    Subdivider: Any person dividing or proposing to divide land so as to constitute a subdivision including any agent of the subdivider. 
    Subdivision (Platted subdivision): The division or redivision of land into two (2) or more lots or other divisions which is set forth on a plat and has been filed for record. The term may also refer to the process of subdividing or to the land or territory subdivided. 
(Code 1970, § 20-1; Ord. No. 4818, § 1, 12-18-00) 
Sec. 10-1.1. - Provisions. 
(a)  Jurisdiction: These regulations shall apply to all land located in the corporate limits of Cameron, Missouri. 
(b)  Applicability: The owner of land within this jurisdiction subdividing land into two (2) or more lots, and blocks or tracts or parcels, for the purpose of laying out any subdivision, building lots, tracts or parcels or any owner of any land establishing any street, alley, park or other property intended for public use or for the use of purchasers or owners of lots, tracts or parcels of land fronting thereon or adjacent thereto, shall cause a plat to be made in accordance with these regulations, unless otherwise exempted. Any lawfully existing plats recorded prior to the effective date of these regulations shall remain valid, and any replats or resubdivisions shall conform to these regulations. 
(c)  Exemptions: 
(1)  A change in the boundary between adjoining lands which does not create an additional or substandard lot. 
(2)  Land used for street right-of-way, a drainage easement or other public utilities subject to local, state or federal regulation, where no new street or easement of access is involved. 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 2, 12-18-00) 
Sec. 10-2. - Plat approval-Required prior to recording. 
(a)  No plat of a subdivision of land lying within the city shall be filed or recorded until it has been submitted to and a report and recommendation thereon made by the planning commission to the council and until the council has approved the plat as provided by law. 
(b)  No county recorder shall receive for filing or recording any subdivision plat required to be approved by the council or planning commission unless the plat has endorsed upon it the approval of the council under the hand of the city clerk and the seal of the city or by the secretary of the commission. 
(Code 1970, § 20-2) 
State Law reference- Approval of plats, RSMo 89.420 et seq. 
Sec. 10-3. - Same-Not to constitute acceptance of dedication to public use. 
    The approval of a plat by the planning commission does not constitute or effect an acceptance by the city or public of the dedication to public use of any street or other ground shown upon the plat. 
(Code 1970, § 20-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 89.430. 
Sec. 10-4. - Acceptance of streets; laying utilities in streets. 
(a)  Upon adoption of a major street plan and subdivision regulations, the city shall not accept, lay out, open, improve, grade, pave or light any street or lay or authorize the laying of water mains, sewers, connections or other utilities in any street within the city unless the street has received the legal status of a public street prior to the adoption of a city plan or unless the street corresponds in its location and lines with a street shown on a subdivision plat approved by the council or planning commission or on a street plan made by and adopted by the commission. The council may locate and construct or may accept any other street if the ordinance or other measure for the location and construction for the acceptance first submitted to the commission for its approval and approved by the commission or, if disapproved by the commission, is passed by the affirmative vote of not less than two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the entire membership of the council. 
(b)  The city shall not accept public infrastructure until the developer has submitted, in a form acceptable to the city, as-build drawings which accurately show the location and specifications of such infrastructure. Such drawings must be submitted to the office of the city clerk and clearly stamped "AS-BUILT". 
(Code 1970, § 20-4; Ord. No. 4718, § 1, 10-19-99) 
Sec. 10-5. - Access streets to conform to provisions prior to issuance of building permit. 
    No building permit shall be issued for and no building shall be erected on any lot within the city unless the street giving access to the lot upon which the building is proposed to be placed conforms to the requirements of section 10-4. 
(Code 1970, § 20-5) 
Sec. 10-6. - Sale or transfer of land by using subdivision plat prior to its approval prohibited. 
    No owner or agent of the owner of any land located within the city, knowingly or with intent to defraud, may transfer, sell, agree to sell or negotiate to sell that land by reference to or by other use of a plat of any purported subdivision of the land before the plat has been approved by the city council or planning commission and recorded in the office of the appropriate county recorder. The description by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document used in the process of selling or transferring shall not exempt the transaction from this section. The city may enjoin or vacate the transfer or sale or agreement by legal action and may recover the penalty in such action. 
(Code 1970, § 20-6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 89.450. 
Sec. 10-7. - Variances generally. 
    Where the planning commission finds that extraordinary hardships may result from strict compliance with this chapter, the commission may vary the regulations in this chapter so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured, provided that such variation shall not have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of the comprehensive city plan or this chapter. 
(Code 1970, § 20-7) 
Sec. 10-8. - Modifications for large developments. 
    The standards and requirements of this chapter may be modified by the planning commission in the case of a plan and program for a new town, a complete community or a neighborhood unit which, in the judgment of the commission, provides adequate public spaces and improvements for the circulation, recreation, light, air and service needs of the tract when fully developed and populated and which also provides such covenants or other legal provisions as will ensure conformity to and achievement of the plan. 
(Code 1970, § 20-8) 
Sec. 10-9. - Conditions for grant of variances or modifications. 
    In granting variances and modifications, the planning commission may require such conditions as will, in its judgment, secure substantially the objectives of the standards or requirements so varied or modified. 
(Code 1970, § 20-9) 
Sec. 10-10. - Public notification of proposed subdivision. 
    Notification of proposed subdivisions will be on planning and zoning agenda, posted on the city web page under planning and zoning agenda's and planning and zoning packets. The zoning officer shall place a sign, not less than three (3) square feet per face, upon the front yard, or as close as practical thereto, of the subject property. Said sign shall contain the message "zoning action pending"; shall show the telephone number of city offices; and shall be placed not less than ten (10) days prior to the planning and zoning meeting. The sign shall remain on the property until such time the proposed subdivision is accepted or rejected. Unauthorized removal, damage, or vandalism to said sign shall not invalidate the notification provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 5826, § 1, 5-5-14) 
Secs. 10-11-10-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PRELIMINARY PLAT 

Sec. 10-31. - Preparation. 
    On informally reaching conclusions as recommended in this article regarding his general program and objectives, the subdivider shall cause to be prepared a preliminary plat, together with improvement plans and other supplementary material as specified in this article. 
(Code 1970, § 20-14) 
Sec. 10-32. - Information, sketch plans and data. 
(a)  General subdivision information for the preliminary plat required by this article shall describe or outline the existing conditions of the site and the proposed development as necessary to supplement the drawings required in this section. This information may include data on existing covenants, land characteristics and available community facilities and utilities and may also include information describing the subdivision proposal such as the number of residential lots, typical lot width and depth, price range, business areas, playgrounds, park areas and other public areas, proposed protective covenants and proposed utilities and street improvements. 
(b)  A sketch plan on the topographic survey shall show in simple sketch form the proposed layout of streets, lots and other features in relation to existing conditions. The sketch plan may be a free-hand pencil sketch made directly on a print of the topographic survey. In any event, the sketch plan shall include either the existing topographic data listed in section 10-34 or such data as the planning commission determines is necessary for its consideration of the proposed sketch plan. 
(Code 1970, § 20-11) 
Sec. 10-33. - Scale and contents generally. 
    The preliminary plat required by this article shall be at a scale of two hundred (200) feet to one (1) inch or larger. The subdivider shall submit ten (10) copies of said plat at least thirty (30) days prior to consideration by the planning and zoning commission. The preliminary plat shall show all existing conditions required in section 10-34 and shall show all proposals including the following: 
(1)  Streets including names, right-of-way and roadway widths, approximate grades and gradients and including similar data for alleys, if any; 
(2)  Other rights-of-way or easements including location, width and purpose; 
(3)  Location of utilities, if not shown on other exhibits; 
(4)  Lot lines, lot numbers and block numbers; 
(5)  Sites, if any, to be reserved or dedicated for parks, playgrounds or other public uses; 
(6)  Sites, if any, for multifamily dwellings, shopping centers, churches, industry or other nonpublic uses exclusive of single-family dwellings; 
(7)  Minimum building setback lines; 
(8)  Site data, including number of residential lots, typical lot size, acres in parks, etc.; 
(9)  Title, scale, north arrow and date; and 
(10)  Sidewalks, as required by this chapter. 
(Code 1970, § 20-15; Ord. No. 4996, § 1, 6-17-03; Ord. No. 5298, § 1, 6-6-05) 
Sec. 10-34. - Topographic data. 
    Topographic data required as a basis for the preliminary plat in section 10-33 and in accordance with this article shall include existing conditions as follows, except when otherwise specified by the planning commission: 
(1)  Boundary lines including bearings and distances; 
(2)  Easements including location, width and purpose; 
(3)  Streets on and adjacent to the tract including names, right-of-way widths, locations, the type, width and elevation of surfacing, any legally established centerline elevations, and walks, curbs and gutters; 
(4)  Utilities on and adjacent to the tract including location, size and invert elevation of sanitary storm sewers, location and size of water mains, location of gas lines, fire hydrants, electric and telephone poles and street lights and, if water mains and sewers are not on or adjacent to the tract, the direction, distance to, and size of the nearest ones shall be indicated showing invert elevation of sewers; 
(5)  Ground elevations on the tract, based on a datum plane approved by the city manager, shall include, for land that slopes less than approximately two (2) percent, spot elevations at all breaks in grade, along all drainage channels or swales and at selected points not more than one hundred (100) feet apart in all directions shall be shown, and, for land that slopes more than approximately two (2) percent either the contours with an interval of not more than five (5) feet if ground slope is regular and such information is sufficient for planning purposes or the contours with an interval of not more than two (2) feet if necessary because of irregular land or need for more detailed data for preparing plans and construction drawings shall be shown; 
(6)  Subsurface conditions on the tract, if required by the planning commission shall include the location and results of tests made to ascertain subsurface soil, rock and groundwater conditions, the depth to groundwater unless test pits are dry at a depth of five (5) feet, and the location and results of soil percolation tests in individual sewage disposal systems are proposed; 
(7)  Other conditions on the tract including watercourses, marshes, rock outcrop, wooded areas, isolated preservable trees one (1) foot or more in diameter, houses, barns, shacks and other significant features; 
(8)  Other conditions on adjacent land including the approximate direction and gradient of ground slope showing any embankments or retaining walls, the character and location of buildings, railroads, power lines, towers and other nearby nonresidential land uses of adverse influence, the owners of adjacent unplatted land, and, for adjacent platted land, the subdivision plat shall be referred to by name showing the recordation date and number and showing approximate percent built up, typical lot size and dwelling type; 
(9)  Photographs, if required by the planning commission, with camera locations, directions of views and key numbers; 
(10)  Zoning on and adjacent to the tract; 
(11)  Proposed public improvements including highway or other major improvements planned by public authorities for future construction on or near the tract; 
(12)  Key plan showing location of the tract; 
(13)  Title and certificates including the present tract designation according to official records of the office of the appropriate recorder, the title under which the proposed subdivision is to be recorded with names and addresses of owners, a notation stating acreage, scale, north arrow datum, bench marks, and certification of the registered civil engineer or surveyor and the date of survey. 
(Code 1970, § 20-12) 
Sec. 10-35. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4849, § 1, adopted Apr. 17, 2001, repealed § 10-35, which pertained to a draft of protective covenants being filed with the preliminary plat and derived from Code 1970, § 20-16. 
Sec. 10-36. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4849, § 2, adopted Apr. 17, 2001, repealed § 10-36, which pertained to submission of a preliminary plat to the planning commission and derived from Code 1970, § 20-17. 
Sec. 10-37. - Submission of plans and data prior to application for conditional approval. 
    Prior to the filing of an application for conditional approval of the preliminary subdivision plan, the subdivider shall submit to the planning commission such plans and data as are specified in this article. 
(Code 1970, § 20-10) 
Sec. 10-38. - Informing subdivider whether plans and data comply with objectives of this chapter. 
    Within thirty (30) days after submission, the planning commission shall inform the subdivider that the plans and data as submitted or as modified do or do not meet the objectives of this chapter. When the commission finds the plans and data to not meet the objectives of this chapter, the commission shall express its reasons therefor. 
(Code 1970, § 20-13; Ord. No. 5298, § 2, 6-6-05) 
Sec. 10-39. - Action of planning commission generally. 
    Following review of the preliminary plat and other material submitted for conformity to this chapter, the planning commission shall, if approved, express its approval as conditional approval and state the conditions of such approval, if any, or, if disapproved, the commission shall express its disapproval and its reasons therefor. 
(Code 1970, § 20-18) 
Sec. 10-40. - Notation of action taken by planning commission; disposition of copies. 
    The action of the planning commission on the preliminary plat required by this article shall be noted on two (2) copies of the plat, referenced and attached to any conditions determined. One (1) copy shall be returned to the subdivider and the other retained by the planning commission. 
(Code 1970, § 20-19) 
Sec. 10-41. - Effect of approval. 
    Conditional approval of a preliminary plat required by this article shall not constitute approval of the final plat. Rather, it shall be deemed an expression of approval to the layout submitted on the preliminary plat as a guide to the preparation of the final plat which will be submitted for approval of the planning commission and for recording upon fulfillment of the requirements of this chapter and the conditions of the conditional approval, if any. 
(Code 1970, § 20-20) 
Sec. 10-42. - Term of preliminary plat. 
    A preliminary plat shall be valid for a term of two (2) years from the date of approval by the planning and zoning commission during which time the developer must receive approval of the final plat (see Article III, Final Plat). 
(1)  Following expiration of a preliminary plat, in order to be reconsidered, the preliminary plat and all accompanying documentation, fees, forms and applicatio materials must be submitted anew in its entirety. 
(2)  Prior to the expiration of the preliminary plat and upon written request of the subdivider, the planning and zoning commission may grant an extension. The term of said extension shall be at the discretion of the commission, however it shall not exceed one (1) year. No more than two (2), one-year extensions, for total extensions of two (2) years, may be approved. 
(Ord. No. 5246, § 1, 11-15-05) 
Sec. 10-43. - Pre-construction meeting. 
    Following approval of the preliminary plat by the planning and zoning commission, the developer shall attend a pre-construction meeting with representatives from the city's utility, zoning, public works and administrative departments. The purpose of the pre-construction meeting is to ensure understanding and compliance with the requirements set forth in this chapter and to review documents, drawings, specifications and plans for improvements submitted by the developer. 
(Ord. No. 5244, § 1, 11-15-05) 
Secs. 10-44-10-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FINAL PLAT 

Sec. 10-61. - Submission. 
    Applications for approval of the final plat required by this chapter shall be submitted in writing to the planning commission at least thirty (30) days prior to the meeting at which the final plat is to be considered. 
(Code 1970, § 20-22; Ord. No. 5394, § 1, 9-17-07) 
Sec. 10-62. - Conformance to preliminary plat. 
    The final plat required by this chapter shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat as approved and, if desired by the subdivider, may constitute only that portion of the approved preliminary plat which he proposes to record and develop at the time, provided that such portion conforms to all requirements of this chapter. 
(Code 1970, § 20-21) 
Sec. 10-63. - Form and content. 
    The final plat meeting the requirements of this article shall be drawn in ink on tracing cloth or mylar on sheets seventeen (17) inches wide by twenty-one (21) inches long and shall be at a scale of one hundred (100) feet to one (1) inch or larger. Where necessary, the plat may be on several sheets accompanied by an index sheet showing the entire subdivision. For large subdivisions, the final plat may be submitted for approval progressively in contiguous sections satisfactory to the planning commission. The final plat shall show the following: 
(1)  Primary control points, approved by the city manager, or descriptions and ties to such control points to which all dimensions, angles, bearings and similar data on the plat shall be referred; 
(2)  Tract boundary lines, right-of-way lines of streets, easements and other rights-of-way and property lines of residential lots and other sites with accurate dimensions, bearings or deflection angles and radii, arcs and central angles of all curves; 
(3)  Name and right-of-way width of each street or other right-of-way; 
(4)  Location, dimensions and purpose of any easements; 
(5)  Number to identify each lot or site; 
(6)  Purpose for which sites, other than residential lots, are dedicated or reserved; 
(7)  Minimum building setback line on all lots and other sites; 
(8)  Location and description of monuments; 
(9)  Names of record of owners of adjoining unplatted land; 
(10)  Reference to recorded subdivision plats of adjoining platted land by record name, date and number; 
(11)  Certification by the surveyor or engineer certifying the accuracy of the survey and plat; 
(12)  Certification of title showing that the applicant is the landowner; 
(13)  Statement by the owner dedicating streets, rights-of-way and any sites for public uses; 
(14)  Title, scale, north arrow and date; 
(15)  Location and width of all sidewalks as required by this chapter. 
(Code 1970, § 20-24; Ord. No. 4996, § 2, 6-17-03) 
Sec. 10-64. - Accompanying documents and exhibits. 
    The application for approval of the final plat required by this chapter shall be accompanied by the original and two (2) copies of the final plat and other exhibits required for approval prepared as specified in this article. 
(Code 1970, § 20-23) 
Sec. 10-65. - Cross sections and profiles of streets. 
    Cross sections and profiles of streets for the final plat required by this chapter showing grades approved by the public works superintendent shall be drawn to city standard scales and elevations and shall be based on a datum plane approved by the city manager. 
(Code 1970, § 20-25) 
Sec. 10-66. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4849, § 1, adopted Apr. 17, 2001, repealed § 10-66. Former § 10-66 pertained to filing protective covenants with the application for final plat approval and derived from Code 1970, § 20-26. 
Sec. 10-67. - Certificates, affidavits, endorsements or deductions. 
    Such other certificates, affidavits, endorsements or deductions as may be required by the planning commission in the enforcement of this chapter shall be filed with the application for the approval of the final plat. 
(Code 1970, § 20-27) 
Sec. 10-68. - Forwarding of planning commission recommendations to council. 
    Within sixty (60) days after the submission of a final plat required by this chapter to the planning commission, the commission shall forward their recommendation to approve or disapprove the plat to the council, otherwise the plat is deemed approved by the commission, except that the commission, with the consent of the applicant for the approval, may extend the sixty-day period. The grounds of disapproval of any plat by the commission shall be made a matter of record. 
(Code 1970, § 20-28) 
Sec. 10-69. - Lot splits. 
(a)  General: This section provides for the issuance of building permits in platted lots further divided into not more than two (2) tracts without the need to replat said lot. 
(b)  Application procedure: Requests for lot split approval shall be made by the owner of the land or contract purchaser and shall include: 
(1)  Five (5) copies of a scale drawing. 
(2)  Legal description and dimensions of the lots to be created. 
(3)  Location, nature and dimensions of any existing structures thereon. 
(4)  Certification by the licensed engineer or registered land surveyor who prepared the drawings. 
(c)  Requirements for lot splits. No lot split shall be approved if: 
(1)  A new street, alley or other public improvement, or vacation thereof, is proposed. 
(2)  There is less street right-of-way than required by this chapter. 
(3)  Such split will result in a tract without direct access to a public street. 
(4)  A substandard-sized lot or parcel will be created. 
(5)  The lot has been previously split in accordance with these regulations. 
(d)  Approval by the planning and zoning commission: The commission shall, within sixty (60) days of application, in writing, either approve, disapprove or continue for cause those applications which, in the opinion of the commission, do not comply with these regulations. If action is not taken within the sixty-day period, such lot split shall be deemed to have been approved. The acknowledged endorsement by the commission must appear on the drawing in a form similar to the following: 
This lot split, as described and shown hereon, has been submitted to and ratified by the Cameron Planning and Zoning Commission under the authority of the Mayor and Council of the City of Cameron, Missouri this _______ day of _______, 20___. 
___________ 
Chairman 
___________ 
Secretary 
___________ 
City Clerk 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 3, 12-18-00) 
Sec. 10-70. - Minor subdivisions. 
(a)  General: Minor subdivisions of no more than five (5) lots may be approved by the planning and zoning commission in an expedited, single-step process. 
(b)  Requests for minor subdivision approval shall be made by the owner or contract-purchaser of the land and shall include five (5) copies of a plat, survey or similar drawing which shall show: 
(1)  Existing streets including name and right-of-way width. 
(2)  Easements including width and purpose. 
(3)  All existing and planned utilities including fire hydrants. 
(4)  Lot lines, lot numbers, block numbers and dimensions. 
(5)  Front and real setback lines. 
(6)  Title, scale, north arrow and date. 
(7)  Certification by the licensed engineer or registered land surveyor who prepared the documents. 
(c)  Requirements for minor subdivision: No minor subdivision shall be approved if: 
(1)  A new street, alley or other public improvement, or vacation thereof is proposed. 
(2)  There is less street right-of-way than required by this chapter. 
(3)  Lots will result without direct access to a public street. 
(4)  A substandard-sized lot will be created. 
(d)  Approval by the planning and zoning commission: The commission shall, within sixty (60) days of application, in writing, either approve, disapprove or continue for cause those applications which, in the opinion of the commission, do not comply with these regulations. If action is not taken within the sixty-day period, such minor subdivision shall be deemed to have been approved. The acknowledged endorsement by the commission must appear on the plat in a form similar to the following: 
This minor subdivision, as described and shown hereon, has been submitted to and ratified by the Cameron Planning and Zoning Commission under the authority of the Mayor and Council of the City of Cameron, Missouri this _______ day of _______, 20___. 
___________ 
Chairman 
___________ 
Secretary 
___________ 
City Clerk 
(Ord. No. 4818, § 3, 12-18-00) 
Sec. 10-71. - Performance surety. 
(a)  Prior to final plat approval by the city council, or issuance of any building permit therein, all proposed public improvements as shown on the preliminary plat must be completed, inspected, and approved by city staff. 
(b)  Alternatively to subsection (a) above, the developer may provide a performance bond, escrow account, cash bond, irrevocable letter of credit, certificate of deposit or other approved surety under terms and conditions established by the city, in a mutually agreeable amount sufficient to ensure satisfactory construction, installation and dedication of the proposed public improvements. 
(1)  A professional engineer, registered in the State of Missouri, may establish the amount of required bond or surety. Said amount may also be established by bona fide bid documents. 
(2)  A performance bond issued to the general contractor in the amount of one hundred (100) percent of the public improvements will be accepted as performance surety if the city is named as an additional obligee. 
(3)  The subdivider shall satisfactorily complete all public improvements as shown on the plat within two (2) years of surety approval or be in default. 
(4)  The obligations of this section are not transferable and no building permit shall be issued to any person except the developer submitting performance surety who is named on the surety instrument as set forth above. 
(Ord. No. 4871, § 1, 9-4-01; Ord. No. 5350, § 1, 1-16-07) 
Sec. 10-72. - Maintenance guarantee. 
(a)  In addition to actual construction of proposed public improvements or a performance surety as specified in section 10-71, the subdivider must furnish surety to the city in the form of a maintenance bond, irrevocable letter of credit, certificate of deposit, cash bond or other approved surety guaranteeing the maintenance of proposed public improvements in the event of defective material or workmanship. 
(b)  The amount of the surety shall be for fifty (50) percent of the full cost of construction and its term shall be a minimum of twenty-four (24) months after completion and acceptance of all proposed public improvements by the city. 
(Ord. No. 4871, § 2, 9-4-01; Ord. No. 5330, § 1, 11-21-06) 
Secs. 10-73-10-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DESIGN STANDARDS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-86. - Dedication, reservation or acquisition of open spaces. 
    The planning commission may require, under the terms of this chapter, the dedication, reservation or acquisition of lands and open spaces necessary for public uses indicated on the comprehensive city plan. 
(Code 1970, § 20-29) 
Secs. 10-87-10-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STREETS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4312, adopted July 5, 1995, provided by title for the establishment of minimum standards for street specifications for the city. Such standards are not set out herein, but are on file in the office of the city clerk. 

Sec. 10-106. - Relationship to existing streets; layout of minor streets. 
    The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade and location of all streets for subdivisions under the requirements of this chapter shall be considered in their relation to existing and planned streets, to topographical conditions, to public convenience and safety and in their appropriate relation to the proposed uses of the land to be served by such streets. The plat should provide for the continuation or appropriate projection of existing principal streets in surrounding areas. Minor streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic will be discouraged. 
(Code 1970, § 20-30) 
Sec. 10-107. - Reserve strips controlling access. 
    Reserve strips controlling access to streets in subdivisions meeting the requirements of this chapter shall be prohibited except where their control is definitely placed in the city under conditions approved by the planning commission. 
(Code 1970, § 20-31) 
Sec. 10-108. - Jogs. 
    Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred twenty-five (125) feet in subdivisions meeting the requirements of this chapter shall be avoided. 
(Code 1970, § 20-32) 
Sec. 10-109. - Tangents between reverse curves. 
    A tangent at least one hundred (100) feet long shall be introduced between reverse curves on arterial and collector streets in subdivisions meeting the requirements of this chapter. 
(Code 1970, § 20-33) 
Sec. 10-110. - Angle of intersection. 
    Streets in subdivisions meeting the requirements of this chapter shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible at right angles, and no street shall intersect any other street at less than sixty (60) degrees. 
(Code 1970, § 20-34) 
Sec. 10-111. - Rounding property lines at intersections. 
    Property lines at street intersections in subdivisions meeting the requirements of this chapter shall be rounded with a radius of ten (10) feet or of a greater radius where the planning commission may deem it necessary. The commission may permit comparable cutoffs or chords in place of rounded corners. 
(Code 1970, § 20-35) 
Sec. 10-112. - Widths and locations. 
    The minimum right-of-way widths for streets in a subdivision meeting the requirement of this chapter shall conform to widths and locations designated on the major street plan of the city and shall be as follows: 
(1)  Residential streets: Fifty (50) feet. 
(2)  Light commercial streets: Sixty (60) feet. 
(3)  Heavy commercial street: Seventy (70) feet. 
(Code 1970, § 20-36; Ord. No. 4913, § 1, 3-19-02) 
Sec. 10-113. - Half streets. 
    Half streets shall be prohibited except where essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision in conformance with the requirements of this chapter and where the planning commission finds it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other half when the adjoining property is subdivided. Wherever a half street is adjacent to a tract to be subdivided, the other side of the street shall be platted within such tract. 
(Code 1970, § 20-37) 
Sec. 10-114. - Dead-end streets. 
    Dead-end streets, designed to be so permanently (i.e. a cul-de-sac), in subdivisions meeting the requirement of this chapter shall not be longer than seven hundred fifty (750) feet and shall be constructed with a traffic circle at the closed end of the street, or other similar means for traffic to turn around having an outside roadway diameter of at least seventy eight (78) feet. 
(Code 1970, § 20-38; Ord. No. 4526, § 1, 7-15-97; Ord. No. 4754, § 1, 4-18-00; Ord. No. 6061, § 1, 3-4-19) 
Sec. 10-115. - Names. 
    No street names in subdivisions meeting the requirements of this chapter shall be used which will duplicate or be confused with the names of existing streets. Street names shall be subject to the approval of the planning commission. 
(Code 1970, § 20-39) 
Sec. 10-116. - Sidewalks. 
    Prior to the issuance of any occupancy permit for any lot in any subdivision established after the date of enactment of this section, the owner shall construct concrete sidewalks along each public street within and adjacent to the subdivision according to the following standards: 
(a)  Any subdivision established after the enactment of this section shall have no longer than five (5) years from the date of acceptance of the "final plat" to install required sidewalks. If a lot is sold within this time period, the new owner of each lot shall have no longer than three (3) years from the date of purchase to install required sidewalks. 
(b)  In the event that any owner fails to install sidewalks as required herein, the city may install said sidewalks and place a special tax assessment upon the property for the cost of said installation as permitted by RSMo Chapter 88. 
(c)  Sidewalks shall be a minimum four (4) inches thick Portland cement concrete on aggregate sub base; driveway crossings shall be a minimum six (6) inches thick, with reinforcement. 
(d)  The minimum sidewalk width shall be five (5) feet. 
(e)  Sidewalks shall be installed on both sides of all streets within the subdivision and along any adjacent streets. 
(f)  The inside (lot side) edge of the sidewalk shall be located within the street right-of-way and one (1) foot from the property line. 
(g)  Sidewalks must be shown on all plats submitted for approval by the city. 
(h)  The superintendent of public works may have additional specifications for certain applications and will provide requirements for commercial or industrial installations. 
(i)  All sidewalks shall conform to current accessibility standards of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). 
(j)  Public sidewalks shall be natural concrete gray tone in color and shall have a uniform, level, broom finish texture. No cobblestone, stamped or other irregular finish shall be permitted other than required by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) 4.29.2 and APPA A4.29.2, Detectable Warnings on Walking Surfaces. 
(Ord. No. 4996, § 3, 6-17-03; Ord. No. 4996, § 1, 6-17-03; Ord. No. 5306, § 1, 7-18-06; Ord. No. 5725, § 1, 5-21-12) 
Sec. 10-117. - Shared private driveways. 
    In "R-1" and "R-2" zoning districts, private driveways shall provide access to no more than two (2) single-family residences or no more than two (2) duplexes. Such shared driveways shall be located between the two (2) adjacent dwellings. 
(Ord. No. 5160, § 1, 8-17-04) 
Sec. 10-118. - Adjacent street improvements. 
    Where a subdivision, minor subdivision or development occurs adjacent to a street which does not have improvements meeting city standards including curb and gutter, the developer shall be required to install curb and gutter plus associated storm water and other improvements along the side of the street(s) adjacent to said development. 
(a)  The scope and nature of the required improvements shall be determined by the city manager or the director of public works according to standards established by the American Public Works Association and the City of Cameron and may include additional street right-of-way in order to comply with the city's street width standards. 
(b)  Said curb and gutter, storm water and other improvements shall be shown on the plat or drawings required. 
(c)  In the event that a large portion of a neighborhood, or street(s) along adjacent blocks, do not have curb and gutter and/or storm sewer at the time of plat submission, then the city manager or public works director may determine that said section of street adjacent to the proposed development is exempt from this requirement. 
(d)  In the event that subsection (c), above, is implemented, then the developer shall pay to the city an amount equal to the cost of street improvements including curb and gutter installation and storm sewer to be used for future installation by the city at such time as neighborhood development warrants it. The cost shall be determined by an estimate prepared by an engineer registered and licensed by the State of Missouri and in a form acceptable to the city. Final project approval shall not be granted until such fee has been paid to the city. 
(Ord. No. 5245, § 1, 11-15-05) 
Secs. 10-119-10-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ALLEYS 

Sec. 10-131. - Required in commercial and industrial districts; exception. 
    Alleys shall be provided in commercial and industrial districts in subdivisions meeting the requirements of this chapter except that the planning commission may waive this requirement where other definite and assured provision is made for service access such as off-street loading, unloading and parking consistent with and adequate for the uses proposed. 
(Code 1970, § 20-40) 
Sec. 10-132. - Width. 
    The width of an alley in a subdivision meeting the requirements of this chapter shall be twenty (20) feet. 
(Code 1970, § 20-41) 
Sec. 10-133. - Intersections. 
    Alley intersections and sharp changes in alignment in subdivisions meeting the requirements of this chapter shall be avoided, but, where necessary, corners shall be cut off sufficiently to permit safe vehicular movement. 
(Code 1970, § 20-42) 
Sec. 10-134. - Dead-end alleys. 
    Dead-end alleys shall be avoided where possible in subdivisions meeting the requirements of this chapter but, if unavoidable, shall be provided with adequate turnaround facilities at the dead end, as determined by the planning commission. 
(Code 1970, § 20-43) 
Sec. 10-135. - Private alleys prohibited. 
    Privately owned alleys are prohibited and all alleys shall be publicly owned with public access allowed. 
(Ord. No. 5160, § 2, 8-17-04) 
Sec. 10-136. - Alley paving requirements. 
    Public alleys constructed following the date of approval of this section shall meet the following standards: 
(1)  The alley right-of-way shall be twenty (20) feet in width. 
(2)  Alleys shall be continuous through the block and connect public streets or shall be constructed with a cul-de-sac one hundred (100) feet in diameter. 
(3)  Alleys shall be constructed with a concrete or asphalt surface which shall conform to the city's street construction specifications. 
(4)  The width of the alley shall be twenty (20) feet measured from the back of the curb. 
(5)  Alleys shall be constructed with concrete curb and gutter which shall conform to the city's curb and gutter specifications. 
(Ord. No. 5160, § 2, 8-17-04) 
Secs. 10-137-10-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - EASEMENTS 

Sec. 10-151. - Required for utilities. 
    Easements across lots or centered on rear or side lot lines in subdivisions meeting the requirements of this chapter shall be provided for utilities where necessary and shall be at least sixteen (16) feet wide. 
(Code 1970, § 20-44) 
Sec. 10-152. - Storm water or drainage easements. 
    Where a subdivision meeting the requirements of this chapter is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream, there shall be provided a storm water easement or drainage right-of-way conforming substantially with the lines of such watercourse and such further width or construction or both as will be adequate for the purpose. Parallel streets or parkways may be required in connection therewith. 
(Code 1970, § 20-45) 
Secs. 10-153-10-165. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - BLOCKS 

Sec. 10-166. - Criteria for determining widths, shapes and lengths. 
    The lengths, widths and shapes of blocks in subdivisions meeting the requirements of this chapter shall be determined with due regard to: 
(1)  Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special needs of the type of use contemplated; 
(2)  Zoning requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions; 
(3)  Needs for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of street traffic; 
(4)  Limitations and opportunities of topography. 
(Code 1970, § 20-46) 
Sec. 10-167. - Lengths. 
    Block lengths in subdivisions meeting the requirements of this chapter shall not exceed one thousand eight hundred (1,800) feet or be less than four hundred (400) feet. 
(Code 1970, § 20-47) 
Secs. 10-168-10-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - LOTS 

Sec. 10-181. - Appropriateness of dimensions. 
    The lot size, width, depth, shape, orientation and the minimum building setback lines shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision contemplated by this chapter and for the type of development and use contemplated. 
(Code 1970, § 20-48) 
Sec. 10-182. - Dimensions to conform to zoning and certain other regulations. 
    Lot dimensions in subdivisions meeting the requirements of this chapter shall conform to the requirements of the zoning regulations and the following: 
(1)  Residential lots where not served by a public sewer shall not be less than one hundred (100) feet wide nor less than fifteen thousand (15,000) square feet in area. 
(2)  Depth and width of properties reserved or laid out for commercial and industrial purposes shall be adequate to provide for the off-street service and parking facilities required by the type of use and development contemplated. 
(Code 1970, § 20-49) 
Sec. 10-183. - Corner lots. 
    Corner lots for residential use in subdivisions meeting the requirements of this chapter shall have extra width to permit appropriate building setback from and orientation to both streets. 
(Code 1970, § 20-50) 
Sec. 10-184. - Access to existing public street required. 
    The subdividing of the land as required in this chapter shall be such as to provide each lot, by means of public street, with satisfactory access to an existing public street. 
(Code 1970, § 20-51) 
Sec. 10-185. - Double frontage or reverse frontage lots; planting screen easement. 
    Double frontage and reverse frontage lots in subdivisions meeting the requirements of this chapter should be avoided except where essential to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. A planting screen easement of at least ten (10) feet, and across which there shall be no right of access, shall be provided along the line of lots abutting such a traffic artery or other disadvantageous use. 
(Code 1970, § 20-52) 
Sec. 10-186. - Angle of side lot lines. 
    Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles or radial to street lines in subdivisions meeting the requirements of this chapter. 
(Code 1970, § 20-53) 
Secs. 10-187-10-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 10-211. - Monuments. 
    Monuments in subdivisions meeting the requirements of this chapter shall be placed at all block corners, angle points, points of curves in streets and at intermediate points as shall be required by the city manager. The monuments shall be of such material, size and length as may be approved by the city manager. 
(Code 1970, § 20-54) 
Sec. 10-212. - Utilities and streets. 
    Utility and street improvements shall be provided by the developer in each new subdivision in accordance with the standards and requirements listed below: 
(1)  Public water and sewer. Construction and design guidelines as developed by the Missouri Department of Natural Resources and the American Public Works Association, Sections 2500 and 2900. In addition, the City of Cameron has developed supplemental design guidelines for construction (City of Cameron Utilities Water/Sewer Design Guidelines). 
(2)  Lift stations. The City of Cameron Utilities Lift Station Design Guidelines are to be used in addition to the Missouri Department of Natural Resources 10 CSR 20-8 Design Guide for Lift Stations. 
(3)  Public streets, alleys, curbs and gutters. Standard Specifications and Design Criteria, Volume I, Division II, Section 2200, Paving, Standard Specification and Design Criteria, Volume II, Division V, Section 5200, Streets, and Division III, Standard Drawings Volume III, Drawing Numbers C-1, ST-1, ST-2, SW-1, UD-1, and JB-1 as published by the Kansas City Metropolitan Chapter of the American Public Works Association (KC-APWA), except as shown in the City of Cameron, Amendments and Additions to APWA Street Specifications. 
(4)  Street name signs at all intersections as per city specifications. 
(Code 1970, § 20-55; Ord. No. 5332, § 1, 11-21-06) 
Sec. 10-213. - Time for installation or construction. 
    All of the improvements required in this article shall be installed or constructed in accord with the specifications in section 10-212 prior to the approval of the final plat by the planning commission except that, in lieu of the completion of the work and installation of the improvements previous to the final approval of a final plat, the council may accept a bond, in an amount and with surety and conditions satisfactory to the council, providing for and securing the actual construction and installation of the improvements and utilities within a period specified by the council and expressed in the bond. 
(Code 1970, § 20-56) 
Sec. 10-214. - Tentative approval of final plat prior to installation. 
    The council may give tentative approval of the final plat previous to the installation of improvements required in this article, but any tentative approval shall not be entered on the final plat. 
(Code 1970, § 20-57) 
Secs. 10-215-10-235. - Reserved 
ARTICLE VI. - STORM WATER MANAGEMENT[3] 
Footnotes:
